Transported for Life .
There were three other indictments against the prisoner.
Before Mr. Baron Gurney.

1925.
WILLIAM NOWLAND
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Patrick Preston
, and cutting and maiming him in the head, with intent to kill and murder him .
TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating his intent to be to disable him, or do him some grievous bodily harm.

PATRICK PRESTON. I am a tailor , and live in Dean-street, Shadwell. On the 12th of August I lived in George-street, Ratcliff
; I had been to Greenwich that day, and got very tipsy.

MARGARET PRESTON. I am the prosecutor's wife. On the night of the 12th of August, he was very drunk - he was in company with the prisoner and more of his friends - the prisoner was also drunk; my husband was sick - the prisoner helped him up stairs to bed, and helped all his clothes off except his trousers; I was putting my baby to bed at this time - my husband was laying on the bed; the prisoner assisted to take off my husband's trousers, but he would not let him, and the prisoner went down stairs - my husband followed him with all his clothes off but his trousers; they were not gone many minutes - I followed them down, and when I got down, I saw them wrangling together and fighting - they had hold of each other; I went between them to part them, and received a scaron my left hand; I then observed some blood on my husband - I called Murder! I found he was hurt on the head and body - a surgeon attended him afterwards; when my husband went out of the room after the prisoner, he ran down following him - I was sober.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Were you one of the party at Greenwich? A. Yes; I was confused; my sister is married to the prisoner - we had been happy and comfortable; I suppose I was two or three minutes in the room before I followed them down, and when I got down they were struggling.

PATRICK PRESTON re-examined. I do not remember the prisoner putting me to bed, or pulling my clothes off; I remember his trying to take my trousers off; I told him I would not let any body take them off; he gave me some saucy answer, and them went down stairs - I went after him, but how it began, or how I got on after I got down I do not know; I do not know what passed till I found my neck bleeding, and he said, "Now I have you;" who first struck I do not know, but I was cut - I do not know whether supper was going on then.
MRS. PRESTON. Supper was over; nobody is here who was present when they got down stairs.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1926.
JOHN ANDREWS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 1 mare, price 18l. , the property of
Henry Gray
.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

CHARLES MOULTON
. I am a farmer , and live at Crouch-end, near Hornsey
- Gray's mare was at my premises at grass. On the 24th of July, about eight o'clock in the evening, I saw her safe, and missed her at six next morning; the gates of the field were locked, as I had left them, but there was a gap broken down, communicating with a field next to a wood - I traced the mare's feet through the wood, and there was grey hair scraped off on the gate-post - this was a grey mare; I saw her next in Gray's possession; she had two fore-shoes on when stolen, but no hind-shoes.

JOSEPH COX
. I keep the Tiger's Head, in the New North-road, four or five miles from Crouch-end. On Wednesday morning, the 26th of July, I saw the prisoner in my skittle-ground, behind my house, about half-past eight o'clock, and he had a grey mare there - there is a side door to the ground, communicating with the street; it was fastened, but a person climbing over the wall could unfasten it inside; I have since seen a mare at Worship-street, in the officer's possession, which I believe to be the same - I told the prisoner there was no room for any thing there - I went out in about half an hour, leaving him and the mare there, but desired him to go away -I was out all day; Larman, the farrier, lives about a quarter of a mile from my house; I did not send any horse to him to be shod.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you know a man named Taylor in this transaction? A. He was charged with this at Worship-street; the prisoner said
Harry Taylor
gave him the horse to be shod, and I saw that man outside the Court this morning - it was another man, named
James Taylor
, who was taken up with the prisoner.

JOSEPH LARMAN
. I am a farrier, and live in Philip-street, Kingsland-road. On Tuesday morning, the 25th of July, the prisoner brought a grey mare to my place to have two hind-shoes put on; he said it was Cox's mare - I said I had been with Cox the day before, and he had got none like it; he then said it had come home early that morning; my man put the shoes on, and booked them to Cox; he took the mare away - I saw the same mare afterwards at Worship-street.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you ask who desired him to get it shod? A. No; he said it was Mr. Cox's.

FREDERICK MASON
. I am in Larman's employ. I shoed the mare, and saw the same mare at Worship-street, but the shoes were so worn, I could not identify them.

JEREMIAH EVANS
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the 26th of July, on the approach to the London-bridge, on the grey mare; the witness saw the same mare at Worship-street.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ask from whom he had it? A. I did; he said it was given him to take care of by two men, and he was to wait there till they returned - he said at the watch-house that they appeared to be brothers, and that one of them was named Harry - I asked what house they used; he said he had seen
Harry Taylor
several times at a house in Smithfield; he afterwards mentioned the Tiger, at Hoxton; I went and apprehended
Harry Taylor
there; and while I went out with Cox to look for
James Taylor
, he came into Cox's house, and was taken - the prisoner was on the mare coming towards the bridge, not standing still.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Did he say where he received the mare from the two men? A. He said at the watch-house that he had it from them at the Rosemary-branch; Harry Taylor was discharged by the Magistrate, and the Grand Jury ignored the bill against James.

HENRY GRAY
. I am a livery-stable keeper, in Earl-street. This grey mare is my property, and worth 18l.
Prisoner's Defence. Taylor gave the mare into my possession at the Rosemary-branch, and told me to go to London-bridge, and wait for him.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Life .
Before Mr. Baron Gurney.

1927.
THOMAS BAYNHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , at St. George, Bloomsbury, 1 purse, value 1s.; 2 sovereigns, 3 half-sovereigns, and one 10l. Bank note, the property of
George Kent
, in his dwelling-house .
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

MARY KENT
. I am the wife of
George Kent
, a butcher , who lives in Upper King-street, in the parish of St. George, Bloomsbury
; in August last the prisoner was our foreman , and had been in our service about four months - he had received notice to quit, and was to leave on the Saturday night. On Wednesday, the 15th, Mr. Hanson was in the counting-house with my husband - I was in the shop, taking money; Mr. Kent called me away to get Mr. Hanson a glass of wine - I had a purse, containing a 10l. Bank of England note, and some money rolled up in it - I do not know how much; there weretwo sovereigns and three half-sovereigns rolled up in a piece of paper, and besides that there was other money in the purse - I was absent from the shop less than five minutes; I had left my purse on a counter by the counting-house - I believe the prisoner was in the shop when I left; when I came back I missed my purse - he was there; I mentioned my loss, in his hearing, immediately; he said he was sorry, and went out with Mr. Hanson, to search for a man named Moore, at the public-houses in the neighbourhood - he said he had no doubt Moore was the thief; Moore is a poor man, who was in the shop when I left, and was gone when I returned - the prisoner had 8s. a week, with his board and lodging.

LUCY JONES
. I live with my parents in Great Russell-street. I was in Mr. Kent's shop on the Wednesday, and saw Mrs. Kent's purse on the shopboard; I saw the prisoner go and lay a piece of paper on the top of the purse; after that I saw him take the paper back again, and lay it where he had taken it from; I did not then see the purse - the prisoner had an apron on - I saw him shuffling in his pocket a good deal, with his hand under his apron; he was quite near the place where the purse was in then; the sheet of paper was taken away after that - after shuffling in his pocket, I saw him go backwards into the yard; he returned to the shop before Mrs. Kent - when she came into the shop, the purse was missed; Moore was in the shop at the time - the prisoner cut a piece of skin off some beef, Moore came there for it, and then went away - he did not interfere with the purse at all.
Q. Did you not tell the Policeman you saw Moore take up the purse, and go out with it? A. I did not.
Prisoner. She said Moore took up the purse, and dropped something at the door - master knows the same, and Mrs. Kent too. Witness. I never told any body so.

GEORGE JARVIS
. I am apprentice to Mr. Kent. Shortly before the purse was lost, I knew the prisoner was going to leave; and he told me two or three days before the purse was lost, that he had but one sovereign to take him into the country; he said he should try to get a sovereign, or half a sovereign, from his aunt.

JOHN MOORE
. I live at No. 12, Princes-street, Red Lion-square. On the day this purse was lost I went to the shop to purchase some meat - I had been a customer there many times before; I did not see the purse on the board, and did not interfere with it in any way - the prisoner served me; I had a towel to taken my meat in - no paper was used to wrap it in; I always had paper previous to that, but not then; I heard I was suspected of this, and went to Kent's directly about it.

THOMAS REEVE
. I am shopman to Mr. Harris, of the Strand. On Monday, the 20th of August, the prisoner came and purchased wearing-apparel at our shop, and paid me a 10l. Bank note; I gave him eight sovereigns and some silver out of it - I asked his name, he said
William Williams
, which I wrote on the note - the policeman has it; here is this name on it in my writing - it is the note he paid me.

ANN GINARD
. I keep a public-house; the prisoner lodged with me before he went to Kent's; he went from my house there - he owed me a few weeks rent; he told me he was poor, and could not pay then; he never paid me - I said he should pay me when he could.

WILLIAM WILSON
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner on the 20th of August, and told him it was on suspicion of robbing his master of a 10l. note and some sovereigns; he said he was willing to go with me; I said I must search him - he said "Well, you may search me, I have some money about me;" I found six sovereigns and 13s. on his person, and in his box in a room at Mrs. Ginard's, I found two sovereigns and two half-sovereigns screwed up in this paper; he said there were two sovereigns and two half-sovereigns in it, and that he had taken half a sovereign from it from that morning.

COURT. Q. Did you find on him any of the articles he had purchased? A. Yes; I asked where he bought them - he said he had them from his aunt; I asked where she lived, he refused to tell me; when he got to the station-house, he said a woman had purchased them for him, and before the Magistrate he said he had bought them at a shop in Middle-row, Holborn (this was not taken down) I went to several shops there, but could find no person who had sold them; I afterwards found out Harris.
THOMAS REEVE. This is the waistcoat and shirt I sold him.
MRS. KENT. These sovereigns and half sovereigns were wrapped in paper of this kind, and in this manner; I had just taken the note, and did not know the number -I know it had no writing on the back.
Prisoner's Defence. It was my own money.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Life .
First London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1928.
CHARLES REX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Philip Hardwick
, from his person .

PHILIP HARDWICK. I am an architect , and live in Russell-square. On the 11th of July, about nine o'clock in the morning, I was in Fleet-street, near Bridge-street
, and felt a pressure, and my pocket was lighter than before; I turned round, and found the prisoner close at my elbow - he appeared alone; nobody but him was near enough to take my handkerchief - I collared, and gave him in charge; I saw my handkerchief about a yard from him, laying in the carriage-road - I saw it taken up; he asked what I meant by collaring him, and denied the charge: Mr. Hudson was with me.

MR. HUDSON. I am a Prothonatary of the Court of Common Pleas. I was with Mr. Hardwick, who seized the prisoner, and crossed the road - I saw the prisoner at that instant throw the handkerchief down, which I took up and gave to Mr. Hardwick.

WILLIAM ELMES
. I am a constable. The prisoner was brougth to the watch-house with this handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. For him to say nobody was near me is false; there were a number of people passing at the time I was.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Life .

1929.
JOHN BIRD
was indicted for
feloniouslyforging a receipt for the sum of 1s. 6d., with intent to defraud
Thomas Allan
and another .
SECOND COUNT, for uttering the same.

THOMAS ALLAN
. I am a warehouseman , and live in Friday-street, Cheapside
, and have a partner; the prisoner was our porter ; he carried goods to different wharfs and booking-offices. On the 16th of July our packer gave him a box to carry to the wharf - On the 23rd of July he produced to me two receipts for 1s. 6d. each, for wharfage and shipping charges; here is one signed "Beloe;" I paid him 1s. 6d. for that - I suspected it at the time.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long was he in your employ? A. About six weeks as porter; he gave me notice to quit on the Monday morning after I kept the note back - our porters occasionally employ journeymen carters as they pass along to take goods to the wharfs, but not by our order - that is the cheapest way, but I never saw him employ them; I believe our porters have done so, by their charging it in their books - they sometimes have a heavy load, and give a man 3d. or 6d. to assist if he is going their way; they frequently charge me for "a pitch;" they have no authority from me to employ chance carters - when I have found they had got a cart to assist, when they did not want it, I have objected to their charge, and they have said the load was too heavy.

DANIEL BELOE
. I am clerk to Mr. Wilson, of Smith's wharf, Tooley-street. Part of this receipt is in my writing; I wrote it for 1s., it has been altered to 1s. 6d. - I am positive it was only for 1s. when I signed it; the 6d. is not in my writing.
Cross-examined. Q. How many of these do you sign in a day? A. I may sign fifty - I enter them in a book, which I have here; I cannot say whether the prisoner is the person who paid me 1s.

JOSEPH RENSHAW
. I am a Policeman. I received the prisoner in charge.

Prisoner's Defence. I was a perfect stranger to the trade, and got a carter to take the goods to the wharf - I stood by the cart; they got the receipts from the wharf, and gave them to me as they are - if they were altered, it was before they came into my hands.
NOT GUILTY .

1930.
JOHN BIRD
was again
indicted for a like offence .

WILLIAM ELDRIDGE
. I am clerk of Hayes' wharf. -This receipt is mine; I gave it for 1s., but 6d. has since been added - I cannot identify the person who brought the goods.
NOT GUILTY .

1931.
SAMUEL BARTLETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of July
, 11 carved ivory knobs, value 36s.; 20 ivory hooks, value 23s., and 11 ivory fists, value 22s., the goods of
Charles Houlden
, his master .

CHARLES HOULDEN. I am an ivory-turner , and live in Fitchett-court, Noble-street
- the prisoner had been my apprentice about eighteen months, I missed goods several times - I received information, and went to Kenn's umbrella-shop, Bagnigge-wells, and found these goods, which are worth about 3l. - I am quite certain they are mine; I took Kenn to my place, called the prisoner into his presence, and asked if he knew any thing of those goods; he said he did not - Kenn said he had bought them of him; the prisoner then asked me to forgive him.

WILLIAM KENN
. I keep an umbrella-shop, near Bagnigge-wells. On the 2nd of July the prisoner brought these goods to my shop, and I bought them of him for 2l. 5s. - he offered them for 2l. 15s., and said he made them - I had bought of him before; I saw Mr. Houlden on the 24th, who claimed them - I went to his house with him, and directly the prisoner was produced, I said he was the person - he denied it at first, but afterwards said it was his first offence, and hoped to be forgiven.

WILLIAM COLYER
. I received him in charge, and heard him ask for pardon.
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

1932.
SAMUEL BARTLETT
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of May
, 60 ivory hooks, value 2l. , the goods of
Charles Houlden
.

CHARLES HOULDEN
. I found these goods in possession of Clark, about the 19th of May, and am sure they are mine - there were one hundred and forty-three hooks; more than ninety-five of them are ivory.

ANTHONY CLARK
. I live in King's-road. About the 19th of May I bought some ivory hooks of the prisoner for 20s.; I bought another lot afterwards.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 18.

1933.
SAMUEL BARTLETT
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of May, 12 parasol handles, value 30s. , the goods of
Charles Houlden
.

WILLIAM KENN
. About the 14th of May
I bought these twelve parasol handles of the prisoner for 21s.
CHARLES HOULDEN. They are mine, and worth 30s.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1934.
JOSEPH MATHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 18 1/2 yards of printed cotton, value 9s. , the goods of
Thomas Matthews
.

JOHN MALLET. I am shopman to
Thomas Matthews
, a linen-draper , of Aldgate
. This cotton hung about four feet within the door - I saw the prisoner come into the shop, and take it: I pursued, and took him about fifteen yards off, with it on his arm.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I am a constable. I received him in charge; he said he did not care any thing about it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never had it in my possession.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1935.
EDWARD WARREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 box, value 1s., and 12lbs. of indigo, value 2l. 12s., the goods of
James Mark Siordet
and others .

SECOND COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Thomas Pearson
.

THOMAS PEARSON. The prosecutor employed me to send this box to St. Katherine's-docks - I delivered it to the prisoner in St. Helen's-place, Bishopsgate
, to take there, on the 4th of August, about noon, and never saw it afterwards - it was to be exported; I am clerk to the prosecutor's agent; the prisoner was quite sober - he afterwards stated that he met a young man, who asked him to drink at apublic-house at the corner of Swan-street, Minories, and that he put the box on the tail of a waggon, which went away with it.

SAMUEL EVANS
. I am an export wharfinger, at St. Katharine's-docks. I have seen the prisoner repeatedly at the docks - he never brought the box of indigo to the docks.

THOMAS WHEELER
. On the 4th of August I saw the prisoner in Crutched-friars, with a box - I cannot say it was the same box, nor tell the time.

JOHN THOMPSON
. I took the prisoner on the 15th of August - he said he had lost the box, and knew nothing more about it.

THOMAS PEARSON. I have never found the box - I employed him several times; he was recommended to me as particularly honest - he moved from his lodging the next morning, and could not be found: I found it was not delivered, about an hour after - I had told him to call on me at the Bell, in Aldgate, to be paid; he was to wait there for me - he came, and was informed I was gone to the docks; I returned there in a quarter of an hour; he did not come again - I never heard he had lost it till he was apprehended.
Prisoner's Defence. I lost it, and got some employment at Brook's wharf.
THOMAS WHEELER. I was sitting on a step when I saw him, and do not know which way he came - he could have gone up John-street to the docks from there.
NOT GUILTY .

1936.
RICHARD SHEA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 5 sovereigns, the monies of
Lucas Houghton
and another .

ALFRED BREWSTER
. I am in the employ of
Lucas Houghton
and another, law-stationer s, Chancery-lane
. On the 31st of August, about five o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came into the shop and asked for a halfpenny pen; he put down sixpence, and I gave him a pen and 5 1/2d. - he stood at the counter; I was making up my accounts, and this money was on the counter - immediately I gave him the pen, I saw him snatch the five sovereigns out of the bowl; he got out of the shop, but was caught by two officers, without my losing sight of him - he fell on the ground, and the three sovereigns were under him; the other two were never found - I asked what he had done with the other two; he said the man who had picked the others up, was as likely to have them as him.

RICHARD COWDEROY
. I am a constable. I found the prisoner in the watch-house. I have the three sovereigns, and 5 1/2d., which I found in his pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I came out of his shop, and shut the door; I proceeded fifty yards, and heard a cry of Stop thief! - seeing a man run, I ran after him, and by St. Dunstan's church, I stopped, seeing I was pursued.

ALFRED BREWSTER
. He shut the door as he ran out, but I caught sight of him immediately.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1937.
GEORGE JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 umbrella, value 2s., the goods of
Jonas White
, in a certain vessel on the navigable river Thames .

JONAS WHITE. I keep an hotel in Covent-garden. I went on board a Margate vessel on the 7th of July, at nine o'clock in the morning, and in about five minutes my umbrella was gone; I had put it on the cabin stairs - I am certain I had not dropped it.

JOHN RANGECROFT
. I am an officer. On the 7th of July, about five or ten minutes to nine o'clock, in the morning, just before the bell rung, I was informed a man had gone up the passage with an umbrella; I pursued, and took the prisoner with it about two or three hundred yards from the Margate packet - I asked how he came by the umbrella; he said he had picked it up on the stairs - the vessel laid near the stairs; I secured him - I saw White next day, when he returned.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found it at the bottom of the stairs, on the platform; I thought a person had dropped it coming out of a vessel.
NOT GUILTY .

1938.
JOHN JAMES, alias JONES
, and
GEORGE SARGENT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 watch-case, value 10s., the goods of
William Peak
, from his person .

WILLIAM PEAK
. I am a hair-dresser , and live in Long-lane
; I was in company with one of the prisoners one night, but was not intimate with him. On the 28th of August, between eleven and twelve o'clock in the morning, the prisoners came into my shop, and were talking to each other about watches; Jones said to me, "Let us look at your watch" - I gave it him from my waistcoat pocket; he took the case off, and pretended to look at the works - he gave Sargent the watch to look at, keeping the case himself; he then pretended to look out of doors, and whipped round the corner - I did not see him go away; Sargent gave me the inside of the watch, and said he would go and look after him, and they both whipped round the corner, and never returned; directly I looked out of doors, they were gone - I received information between ten and eleven o'clock that night, and went to the Queen's-head, Queen-street, Holborn; I found them there with a party, and charged them with taking my case, which they denied - I have not found it; it was silver, and worth 10s.

Sargent. Q. How long had we been in your shop before a person came to be shaved? A. They were there about seven minutes altogether; I cannot recollect any body coming to be shaved - I had summoned a person to Guildhall about an image he had broken; I did not say I was in debt 18s. - I said nothing about pawning my watch for 1l.; I was once in the House of Correction for an assault, but was never charged with felony, or a dishonest act - I never threatened to cut my mother's throat; I never told you I had stolen a hone - I knew Jones by sight, having seen him about nine months ago, with a neighbour's son; you kept talking to me about the weather, while Jones went off with the case.

JOHN MURDOCH
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoners; they denied the charge.

Sargent's Defence. Jones called and asked me to take a walk; I had been ill - as we returned I wanted shaving; he said a friend of his kept a shop in Long-lane - I went, and was shaved; a person came and spoke to him aboutGreen, who he had summoned to Guildhall - after he was gone, he said he was 18s. in debt, and should be obliged to pawn his watch: he took it out, and asked us if it would fetch 1l. - I said I was no judge, and he put it into his pocket again; he showed us a hone which he said had been stolen, and the person sold him the duplicate - we soon after bid him good morning, and left both together.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined One Year .

SARGENT -
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Transported for Life .

1940.
JAMES KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 hat, value 10s., the goods of
Charles Hong
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

CHARLES HONG. I live at Mr. Jones', the Two Brewers', public-house, Leadenhall-market
. On the 1st of August, about ten o'clock at night, the prisoner came in and called for a glass of porter; my hat hung by the yard door, in the passage - he asked me to show him backwards: he would pass my hat - he came out of the yard, drank part of his porter, and wanted me to take the rest; I saw some bulk under his coat, and suspected him - he left the house, and in half a minute I missed my hat; I went and overtook him about ten yards off - he ran about two hundred yards; I followed, and saw him stop, then walk on a few paces, and pull my hat from under his coat - I immediately collared him, and gave him in charge; he had his own hat on.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I took it by mistake, being intoxicated. Witness. He was perfectly sober.

SAMUEL PECK
. I am a constable. I received him in charge.

WILLIAM GLEED
. I am an officer. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction - (read) - I was present in this Court when he was convicted, and know he is the man.

Prisoner's Defence. I had come out of the House of Correction that morning, after eight months' confinement, and not having drank any beer there, the spirits I took had got effect on me; I do not know what occurred.

GUILTY . Aged 36. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
NEW COURT. TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 11.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1941.
BENJAMIN PHILLIPS
and
JAMES REARDON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 half-sovereign , the money of
Peter Poland
.
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

ANGELINA WILCOX
. I am in the service of Mr. Peter Poland. On the 12th of July I was at the back of his shop, No. 351, in the Strand
, between the hours of twelve and one o'clock - I had counted the money in the till about two hours before; there were eight half-sovereigns and some other money - no other person had been to the till; I saw Reardon come to the door, he appeared to be looking about - he then came into the shop, and asked for a situation; I said I did not know of one - he came about half way into the shop, and I answered him as I sat down - a woman then came into the shop; I got up to answer her, and found Phillips in the shop, with his hand in the till - that was a few minutes after Reardon had asked for a situation: I did not see Reardon when Phillips was at the till - I asked Phillips to give me the money he had taken from the till; he said he had none; I asked him again - he said he had not, and walked out; the officer took him, and took a half-sovereign from his hand.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not at first say you had lost three half-sovereigns? A. Yes, but I afterwards recollected I had given out two at the time I counted the money; there had been ten, before I gave out the two, and I left eight - there had been no customers in - the till was not locked; there was another person there who attended to the shop, but she had not been to the till - Phillips was laying across the counter, and I saw his hand in the till.

JOHN KENT
(Police-constable C 171). I was in the Strand, and observed the two prisoners on the other side of the way, not far from Mr. Warren's; I followed them - they were in company; they went, I suppose, into twenty different shops, and when they came out, I or my brother officer went and inquired what they had been for; when they came to Mr. Poland's, I saw Phillips go in, and Reardon stood at the window, and make several motions with his head and his fingers; Phillips then came out, and Reardon went in - he then came out, and went a little way off; a woman then went in, and we crossed - Phillips was just coming out, and Stone took him - I went and took Reardon, who was then running.

GEORGE STONE. I was with Kent, and saw Phillips go into the shop - Reardon waited outside, and made motions to him; then Reardon went in, and came out again - a woman then went in; Phillips came out - I stopped him, and found a half-sovereign in his right hand.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe you caught Phillips by the throat? A. No; we were both in plain clothes.
Phillips' Defence. The young lady said she missed three half-sovereigns, and the officer seized my throat, put his fingers into my mouth, and nearly strangled me.
Reardon's Defence. I went to get a situation, and when I came out, the officer took me.

PHILLIPS -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

REARDON -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1924.
SIDNEY HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 4 yards of fringe, value 13s., the goods of
John Peters
, his master .

JOHN PETERS. I am a fringe manufacturer . The prisoner had been three weeks in my service before the 1st of August, and he had been with me before he went to sea - he had a box of goods to sell for me, and on the 1st of August, when he came home with his box, he put it down close by a quantity of worsted fringe; he told me he wanted a gross of Waterloo cord braid; I stepped for it - he went out with it, and when he was gone I missed the articles stated - he was to have returned with the money for the braid which he had of me, but he did not; I thought he might have put it into his box, but I looked, and found the box was emptied of what he had taken out in it in the morning; I went out, and a friend directed me to a public-house, where the prisoner was smoking a cigar; I called him out, and asked what he had done with my property; he said he did it with a view to get transported - he afterwards offered me 3s. in part of payment; he had a commission on what he sold.
Prisoner. Q. Did you ever receive money from me? A. Yes, when you returned home, and gave an account of what you sold.
COURT. Q. Was any body on the premises who could have taken it but him? A. No; he put his box on the ground on the counter, close to the fringe - I missed 4l. worth of goods out of his box.

WILLIAM HOWARD
. I was in the Police, but am now going to sea. I received the prisoner on the 1st of August - I found on him 3s.; he said he supposed he should be transported.

GUILTY . - Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1943.
MARY LYONS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 2 blankets, value 3s.: 1 counterpane, value 3s.; 2 rugs, value 3s.; 1 tea-board, value 1s.; 1 lookingglass, value 5s.; 3 glasses, value 2s.; 2 saucepans, value 3s.; 2 canisters, value 2s.; 1 jar, value 1s.; 1 basket, value 1s.; 4 shells, value 4s.; 1/2lb. weight of tea, value 3s.; 1/2 lb. weight of chocolate, value 1s.; 7 lbs. weight of soap, value 3s.; 8 lbs. weight of sugar, value 4s.; 50 shells, value 1s., and 4 sovereigns , the property of
William Wells
.

WILLIAM WELLS. I am a seafaring man , and live in Charles-street, Bethnal-green
- I lived with the prisoner, and we had a number of articles in our common use; I made a regular distribution of them on the 24th of July - we were going to breakfast at my brother's; but before she went she threw a red purse on the table, and said I had better put the rest of my money in that, which I did, and locked it up; I then went out - I went to my sister's; the prisoner came there to me the next day, and we set out to go home; she came home part of the way, and then left me; after that she got a van, and took away the property stated; when I came home I missed it - the chest had been broken open, and four sovereigns taken from it; it was her purse I put the money in - she used to earn money sometimes, and that was most likely spent in common; she went by my name.
NOT GUILTY .

1944.
THOMAS KNOWLES
and
THOMAS WILLIAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Ralph Brown
, from his person .

RALPH BROWN
. I am a carpenter , and live in Henry-street East, Bedford-square. On the evening of the 24th of July, I was walking in High-street, St. Giles'
- I saw Knowles in the custody of Stone; I felt my pocket, and missed my handkerchief, which I saw in Stone's hand.

GEORGE STONE
(Police-constable C 99). On the 24th of July, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I was in High-street, and saw the two prisoners together at the corner of Oxford-street - when Mr. Brown passed they followed him to the church, when Knowles put his hand in and picked his pocket - Williams was close to him at the time; I went in between them, and secured Knowles; he put his hand behind him, as if to give the handkerchief to Williams, but I took it, and Williams ran off.

Knowles. You swore that Williams was several yards from me; you are not the man who took me, it was a man in plain clothes. Witness. We were both in plain clothes- Williams was close to you; they were both very desperate indeed; they laid on the ground, and said they would not go.

THOMAS FARRANT
(Police-constable C 42). I was with Stone, and pursued Williams - he made great resistance, and fought terribly; I got him into a public-house, and when I had handcuffed him I went out to assist Stone - they raised a mob of five or six hundred persons; the prosecutor was forced to assist to get them along.

KNOWLES -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1945.
GEORGE HARRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 37 lbs. weight of sugar, value 1l. 3s. , the goods of
Mary Lewis
.

MARY LEWIS. I am a widow , and keep a grocer's-shop in Upper Marylebone-street
. On the morning of the 3rd of August, I missed a loaf of sugar from my door - it was brought back by Onslow and the officer.

GEORGE ONSLOW
. I live in Phillips'-gardens, St. Pancras, and am a marble polisher. I saw the prisoner and another with him; I saw the prisoner take an apron from before him, and throw it over the sugar, which the other carried - I crossed the road, and saw the prisoner and the other run off with it; I pursued, and took the prisoner - the sugar was dropped, and I took it up and told the officer; the other got off.

WILLIAM BARRY
(Police-constable H 59). I was passing near Tottenham-street. Onslow called me, and pointed out the prisoner; I went and took hold of him - he asked what was the matter: I said I would soon tell him- I took him to the sugar, and told him he was charged with stealing that; he said he was innocent, that he had only been standing in company with the man who took it- he had a dark green cap on.

JOHN RHYND
. I am a drawing-master, and live in Titchfield-street. I was passing the prosecutrix's shop, and saw the prisoner take the sugar down - he took it to the corner, where there was another person standing, waiting for him - there was no cloth over the sugar; he had a green cap on.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1946.
DANIEL HOPKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Habgood
, from the person of
Mary Ann Habgood
.

ELIZABETH ROACH
. I am the wife of
Richard Roach
. of Virginia-row
- he is a mariner. On the 10th of July I was looking out at my window, and saw Mrs. Habgood with her child, standing at the door of the Bird Cage - I saw the prisoner take the necklace off her baby's neck, as she stopped to change her arms; I called to her immediately - two men followed the prisoner, and brought him back.

ANN HARGOOD. I am the wife of
Thomas Habgood
- we live in Church-street. I was carrying my child , whose name is
Mary Ann
, in my arms, when the prisoner wasbrought back, and this necklace was produced - it is the one my child had on.

MARTHA CADMAN
. I live in Virginin-row. I was in the street, and heard the alarm; I saw a boy run past me, but I cannot say that it was the prisoner; he threw down this necklace - I took it up.

GEORGE BENNETT
. I live in Kingsland-road. On the evening of the 10th of July I was with the officer near the Bird Cage: I heard Mrs. Roach say the boy had taken the child's necklace - I saw this necklace on the ground; the prisoner had ran past that spot - I followed and took him; I saw the same necklace picked up by Cadman, and given to the officer.

JOHN WINTLE
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had not taken the necklace from the child, but seeing it fall, was tempted to take it up. He received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 13.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Ten Days .

1947.
HENRY HOWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of July , 1 pair of trousers, value 5s., and 1 handkerchief, value 3s. , the goods of
Daniel Miller
.

DANIEL MILLER
. I live in Bridge-row, Paddington
, and am a brick-maker ; the prisoner lodged with me and worked for me. On the 23rd of July I got up early and went to work - he did not come to work; I went to look after him - I found him coming out of the house; I went into my room, and missed these articles: I went and found him - he had my trousers on under his own; I asked what he was going to do with them - he said to pawn them, to get a shilling or two to go to Wormwood-scrubs; I found the handkerchief in his hat.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Had you been accustomed to use each others things? A. No; I had lent him a pair of shoes to pawn, to pay me some money I had advanced for him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

1948.
JAMES HEALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 coat, value 20s. , the goods of
William Crawshaw
.

CHARLES HILL
. I live with my father at the Southampton Arms, Tottenham-court-road
. On the morning of the 26th of July I was looking out at the window - I saw the prisoner go up into a cab, and take a coat up and put it on his back; he walked into Southampton-court, and came back without it - I told the driver of it.
Prisoner. Q. Why did not you give the alarm directly I took it? A. I knew you was about among the cabs - you had been feeding the horses with bay; I have had no quarrel with you.

WILLIAM CRAWSHAW
. I am driver of the cab No. 1057 . I lost my coat on the 26th of July; I saw it again the same morning, in the hands of the Policeman; the prisoner came back to the stand, and began to feed the horses - I do not know whether he had been in the habit of doing so.

Prisoner. Q. When I was taken you asked the witness what sort of a coat it was, and what did he reply? A. I asked him whether he saw the coat taken from the cab, with the grey horse - he said Yes; that it was a coat with three or four capes, and it has three - he said he saw you get up, take it up, and put it on, look round and then go off with it on your back.

DAVID LAING
(Police-constable E 58). I took the prisoner on the stand in Tottenham-court-road, on the 26th of July; a lodging was pointed out to me at No. 5, Southampton-court - the prisoner had lodged there, but left the Saturday before and was gone to No. 7; I went there, and found this coat in the back room first floor.

ELIZABETH HADLEY
. I am the wife of
George Hadley
; we live at No. 7, Southampton-court. The prisoner hired our first floor back room on the 21st of July, and slept there till the Thursday; the coat was found there - the street door was on the spring-lock, but could be opened outside; no one had occupied that room after he slept there - he had not given it up.
Prisoner. Q. Was there not another man in the room? A. There was while you were there, but not afterwards.
The prisoner put in a long written Defence, stating that he had not been at Hadley's lodgings after the night of the 22nd, on account of two other men sleeping there: and declaring his innocence.

CHARLES HILL
re-examined. Q. When did you tell the prosecutor you had seen the coat taken? A. When he was making inquiry for it, which was about five minutes before six o'clock - it had been taken about a quarter of an hour before.

DAVID LAING
. I found the coat about seven o'clock.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1949.
WILLIAM FRASER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Mackewen
, from the person of
Sarah Mackewen
, his wife
.

SARAH MACKEWEN. I am the wife of
John Mackewen
; he is a horse-doctor ; I sell fruit in the market . On the morning of the 31st of July, the prisoner came to me in Spitalfields-market
, a little before seven o'clock; he asked for a pottle of raspberries, and offered 3d. for them, which I said I could not take - he went away and came back, and told me to tie him up a pottle; while I did that, I felt his hand in my pocket - I held his hand, and said,"You little rogue, you have got your hand in my pocket:" I took it out - he had some silver in it, and some copper: I saw one half-crown - I gave him into custody; he said it was his parents' money not mine, but what his mother had given him: I had a good deal of silver in my pocket, and some half-crowns.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Did you see his hand in your pocket? A. No, but I felt it - it was outside my pocket when I saw the half-crown in it; I cannot swear that the half-crown was not in his hand before: I did not see him with any newspapers.

THOMAS STONEHOUSE
(Police-constable H 81). I took the prisoner when the prosecutrix had hold of his hand; I found one half-crown and 1 1/2d. in his hand, and 6d. worth of half pence, and 2s. 6d. in his pocket.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, denying that he had touched the prosecutrix's pocket; and stating that the money in his hand he had received for newspapers which he had sold in the street.

REBECCA FRASER
. I am mother of the prisoner - he gets his living by buying and selling newspapers. On the morning of the 31st of July he had two half-crowns from me to purchase newspapers.
NOT GUILTY .

1950.
THOMAS DEADMAN
and
JAMES YEOMANS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 1 cap, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
John Higginson
; and that Deadman had been before convicted of felony .

JOHN HIGGINSON
. I am a hatter , and live in Crawford-street, Marylebone
. On Saturday, the 7th of July, I was in my shop, and had three gentlemen there; my attention had been called to my shop door, from having previously seen the prisoner lurking about, and I had told him to go off - I saw Deadman take the cap from about one yard inside the door; I pushed the gentleman on one side, and pursued him - he had not got past the window before he saw me; he gave the cap to Yeomans, then pulled off his shoes, and ran off; I pursued, gave an alarm, and he was taken.

ROBERT DOCKERY
(Police-constable D 56). I heard an alarm, went to the spot, and took Deadman.

THOMAS HENRY THOMPSON
(Police-constable D 4). I apprehended Yeomans on the 9th of July - I charged him with being in company with Deadman; he said he had left him at seven o'clock in the evening at the corner of Seymour-place, which is but a few yards from the prosecutor's.
Deadman's Defence. I was walking along, and the gentleman said I took his cap.
Yeoman's Defence. I never saw it.

THOMAS HARRISON
. (Police-constable D 13). I have a certificate of the conviction of Deadman, which I got at Mr. Clark's office; I took the prisoner at that time, and know he is the person.

DEADMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 12.

YEOMANS -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .

1951.
JONATHAN CRASKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 9 yards of cotton, value 4s. 10d., the goods of
William Powell
and another .

JAMES WHITE BURGOYNE
. I live in James-place, Marlborough-row, Chelsea. I was at the corner of Berners-street
on the 30th of July, and saw this piece of cotton drop from the prosecutor's doorway - the prisoner took it up, put it under his coat, and ran away with it; I followed him, and gave him into custody - this is the cotton; I do not know what caused it to full.

JOHN ADAMS TOMLINS
. (Police-constable D 24). I took the prisoner, and found these two pieces of printed cotton concealed in the breast of his coat.

WILLIAM POWELL
. I am a linen-draper , and have one partner - we live at the corner of Berners-street; this is our property, and has our mark on it - I cannot account for its falling, but I am quite confident there must have been some hand applied to it.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1952.
GEORGE McNAMARA
and
GEORGE DIXON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Josiah Hammond
, from his person .

JOSIAH HAMMOND. I live in Chancery-lane, and am a surgeon . On the morning of the 6th of September I was passing through Cursitor-street
- my attention was called to the state of my pocket; I felt, and missed my handkerchief - I saw McNamara in front of me; I ran up to him, and the gentleman who had spoken to me produced Dixon; the handkerchief was taken from him by Mr. Alexander - he said he picked it up from the street.

ROBERT ALEXANDER
. On the morning of the 6th of September I was in my shop in Cursitor-street; I saw McNamara raise the skirt of the prosecutor's coat with his right hand - he took the handkerchief out with his left hand, and gave it to Dixon, who put it into his breast; I ran out, took Dixon, and took the handkerchief from him.
GEORGE GRAY (Police-constable A 42). I took the two prisoners.(Property produced and sworn to.)
McNamara's Defence. I was walking on the other side of the street, and heard some person call out; I looked, and saw the prosecutor, who said I had stolen his handkerchief, but I was on before him.
Dixon's Defence. I was going after a situation, saw the handkerchief on the ground, and took it up.

McNAMARA -
GUILTY Aged 12.

DIXON -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1953.
GEORGE CAPSEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
George John Parry
, from his person .

FREDERICK MILES
(Police-serjeant G 14). On the 3rd of August I was on duty in Goswell-street; I saw the prisoner and two others following the prosecutor and a lady - I followed them, and saw the prisoner take up the prosecutor's coat, and take the handkerchief; I took him - this is the handkerchief.

GEORGE JOHN PARRY
. I am a solicitor . This is my handkerchief - I lost it from my pocket about half-past seven o'clock, on the 3rd of August, in Goswell-street
, on my way to Pentonville; I was walking with a lady, and did not miss it till the officer told me of it.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1954.
MARY BELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 4 handkerchiefs, value 6s., and 1 cap, value 4s. , the goods of
William Heaven
.

SARAH HEAVEN
. I am the wife of
William Heaven
- we live in Vincent-street, Westminster
; the prisoner worked for me at ironing. On Saturday, the 14th of July, I missed a cap from the laundry; I went to her lodging on the Monday, and found it on her head - I had her taken up, and then found a crape shawl and some handkerchiefs; they were clean, and were taken from my house, where they had been ironed - she never took things home to iron.

JAMES WATSON
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Strutton-ground. I have a shawl, pawned by the prisoner on the 25th of June.

JAMES HOPPER
(Police-constable B 132.) I took this cap off the prisoner's head, at the lodging.
Prisoner. I have had a deal of trouble - I had a sick husband and a child for nine months.
MRS. HEAVEN. She had 15s. a week when she worked, and I did what I could for her besides.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Confined Three Months .

1955.
JOHN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 28 yards of printed cotton, value 1ls. , the goods of
William Smith
.

EDWARD ABEL BARNES
. I am shopman to Mr.
William Smith
, a linen-draper , of Titchfield-street
. This print was just at the entrance of the door, with others, on the 10th of August - it was not beyond the house; it laid on a piece of flannel; the prisoner was brought in with it.

WILLIAM NASH
. On the 10th of August, in the afternoon, I was coming along Titchfield-street - I saw the prisoner put a piece of print into his apron, close to the prosecutor's door - he ran off; I pursued, and the officer took him.

WILLIAM PLUME
(Police-constable E 41.) I took the prisoner in Riding-house-lane - I saw him running.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1956.
THOMAS BLOOMFIELD
was indicted for
feloniously forging, on the 7th of July , a request for delivery of goods , which is as follows:
SIR, - I shall be very much obliged to you if you will let the bearer have two stoves; they must both be two feet wide.
Your obedient servant, J. FURGUSON.

with intent to defraud
Joseph Tansley
; against the Statute, &c.
SECOND COUNT, for uttering the same.

THOMAS LABRUM
. I am shopman to Mr.
Joseph Tansley
, ironmonger , of Dean-street, Westminster
- I know the prisoner, from his having come to our shop for goods for his master, Mr. Ferguson. On the 7th of July he applied for two stoves: I delivered him one - he said he would bring the order for them in a few days; on the 10th he brought this paper, and had the other stove - I think it was sixteen inches; he said they were for Mr. Ferguson, who had taken a house at Walham-green, and he should want these stoves, and a variety of other articles, to furnish it - I think I could not have stated before that he had the first on the 5th or 6th; this deposition has my signature to it - I think what I say now is true, within a day or two.

JOSEPH TANSLEY. I was at my shop on the 10th of July, when the prisoner produced this paper; I did not see it to read it - he came for a stove then, and he had had one the day before, when I was out - when I saw him on the 10th, my young man let him have a stove in my presence; I did not give the order for it - I was busy at the time; I think the stove the prisoner had then was a twenty-two inch one, and the one he had before was a twentyfour inch.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You did not take particular notice of what was passing? A. Yes, I did; I was serving another customer at the time - my son, who is thirteen years old, was at the end of the shop; the prisoner took a recess eliptic stove, and, to the best of my recollection, it was a twenty-four inch; it was twenty-two or twenty-four - I have not looked at the book; the first was entered on the 7th of July, by my clerk - I know Mr. Ferguson, and know his hand-writing; I do not think my clerk did - he has been with me since November; in the beginning of this year, Mr. Ferguson has sent orders.
THOMAS LABRUM re-examined. Q. Can you take upon yourself to say that the two stoves were delivered in consequence of this paper? A. Yes, they would not have been delivered without.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you on your oath at the Police-office? A. Yes; I did not say at the office that the paper was delivered the first time - my deposition was read, and I signed it, but there might be a few words I did not hear - there were a great many people there, and there might be a mistake; I heard the greater part of it - the prisoner had brought genuine orders on former occasions, and when he came for the first of these stoves I asked if he had brought an order; he said No, but he would bring it when he came again: if he had come without an order the second time, I should have suspected him.

THOMAS FERGUSON
. I live in Cannon-row, and am a clerk. I know the prisoner, and employed him about two months, as a painter; he left me about the middle of May: I have sent him with orders to Mr. Tansley, but this order is not my writing, nor any part of it - it was not written by my authority or direction; I know nothing of it - the prisoner did not bring me, on the 5th, 6th, 7th, or 10th of July any stoves from Mr. Tansley.
Cross-examined. Q. Is this at all like your writing? A. No, it is not.
COURT to THOMAS LABRUM. Q. Did you believe this to be Mr. Ferguson's hand-writing? A. Yes.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you think it was at all like his writing? A. We do not, in the hurry of business, take the trouble to examine letters; I never saw a note of Mr. Ferguson's begin with a small i, nor ever saw his name spelt Furguson.

WILLIAM MILLER
(Police-constable B 42). I received the prisoner into my custody from Mr. Ferguson - he begged Mr. Ferguson's pardon, asked him to stand his friend, and said he would see that he should be paid afterwards; I found this stove at the prisoner's father's.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not say he had been made the dupe of a person named Davis? A. No.
THOMAS LABRUM. This is the stove which he had on the 10th, after he had brought the written request; I know it by the marks on it.
GUILTY of uttering . Aged 24.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1957.
HARRIET WELLS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of July , six pairs of stays, value 16s.; 2 pair of shoes, value 5s., and 1 pair of stockings, value 1s., the goods of
Josias Tapley Toms
, her master .

ELIZA TOMS
. I am the wife of Josias Tapley Toms - we live in Turnstile
. The prisoner was in our service, and quitted about nine months ago, but was in the habit of coming when she thought proper - she had been at my house the day before I missed the shoes.

JOHN FOY
(Police-constable G 182). I received theprisoner, and I received some duplicates, but not in her presence.

WILLIAM WATSON
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I have one pair of stays - I do not know who pawned them.

GEORGE CHAPMAN
. I am apprentice to a pawnbroker. I have four pairs of stays - I cannot tell who pawned them.

THOMAS HARVEY
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker at Islington. I have a pair of shoes and a pair of stockings - I cannot tell who pawned them.

ANN EVERTON
. I live in Bunhill-row. The prisoner was in my service; I had some suspicion, and gave her into custody - I found thirteen duplicates in her box; I gave them to the officer.
GUILTY. Aged 18.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Six Weeks .

1958.
JOHN WALLIS
,
MARGARET WALLIS
, and
ELLEN WALLIS
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 14 pairs of stays, value 2l. 8s. , the goods of
William Thomas
.
The same evidence was given on the trial of the prisoners for receiving the said goods, for which, see Eighth Day, Old Court.
NOT GUILTY .

1959.
MARY SCREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of July , 1 cap, value 8d.; 1 shirt, value 1s.; 3 sleeves, value 6d., and 8 gloves, value 6d. , the goods of
Robert William Henderson
.

SARAH HENDERSON
. I am the wife of Robert William Henderson - we live in Queen-street
. The prisoner came to my room, and offered to help me work, on Thursday, the 23rd of July; she helped me, and I gave her tea - in the course of the afternoon, she asked me if I would let her sleep with me; I said I did not take lodgers, on account of my husband coming on Saturday night - she said she hoped she should get a situation before that; I gave her her victuals while she staid - I missed these articles on Saturday morning, and named it to her - she was very angry about it; I have since seen the articles in her box.

WILLIAM ELLIOTT
(Police-serjeant D 18). The prisoner was given into my charge at No. 36, Queen-street; I found a bunch of keys on her - I asked where her boxes where, and she told me they were at the Hop Pole, Edgware-road; she took me into the two pair front room, and sat down by two boxes - I asked if they were hers; she refused to answer - I then asked a woman if she had slept there; she said Yes, two or three nights - I asked if she had any boxes - she said, "Yes," these are them -I then found these things in them; the prosecutrix asked where her other box was - she refused to answer; we looked and found a black box, in a cradle, and in it I found the cap, gloves, and habit-shirt; the three gloves were in the first box.

SARAH HENDERSON
. The prisoner had one box at my house with the hinge off, but there was nothing in that - it was covered with leather; my cap was found in that box, and the other things in a hair trunk.
The prisoner put in a written Defence stating, that the articles were placed in her box without her knowledge.

GUILTY . Aged 58. -
Confined Three Months .

1960.
MICHAEL MULLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Michael Ryan
, from his person .

MICHAEL RYAN
, M.D. I live in Hatton-garden. On the 16th of August, I was in Hatton-garden
, at a few minutes past six o'clock; a person tapped me on the shoulder, and said my pocket was picked; I turned, and the prisoner was pointed out to me; he was taken, and I saw my handkerchief found on him.
Prisoner. Q. What part was it? A. Near Holborn; I did not miss it till I was told of it; I saw you down Charles-street, within a few yards of the turning.

RICHARD AUST MALTWOOD
. I am a constable. I was called, and found the prisoner making a very violent resistance; I saw this handkerchief produced at the office.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had been with my father and a few friends; in going home (being intoxicated) I stumbled against a man - I begged his pardon; he struck me, and I returned it; he said he would give me in charge; I tried to get away, and did not know where I was till I found myself in the watch-house next morning - I never saw the handkerchief.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Months .

1961.
JAMES SUTTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 8 live tame fowls, price 14s., and one sack, value 1s. 6d. , the property of
William Atley
.

JOHN RYAN
. (Police-constable L 142). On the morning of the 29th of August, I was in the Westminster-road, at a quarter before five o'clock; I saw the prisoner going towards the Marsh-gate with two small bags, and eight live fowls; I asked what he had got - he said some live fowls; he did not know what they were, but I found they were five cocks and three hens - I stopped him.

WILLIAM ATLEY
. I live at Park Farm, Hanwell
, about ten miles from the Westminster-road. My fowls were safe on the 28th of August - I have a good many about my hedges; I had employed the prisoner a great part of the summer, and he saw the fowls from time to time; this sack is mine, he made it into two to bring away the fowls.

AMELIA ATLEY
. I know these fowls - they are my husband's, and were safe on Monday night, the 28th; the prisoner had been discharged on the Saturday before.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Six Months .

1945.
CHARLES MORRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 1 hat, value 15s. , the goods of
Richard Watson
.

RICHARD WATSON
. I live in Buckingham-street, Fitzroy-square. On the 16th of July I went to a skittle-ground; I put my hat on a bench - the prisoner was sitting within a yard of me; I missed him in about five minutes, and my hat was gone.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. What are you? A. A tailor ; there were seven or eight people there- I was quite sober; I gave charge of a young man named
William Doe
, for receiving the hat - I did not receive 6s. from any person.

MARY HUNN
. I live in Charles-street, Lissongrove. The prisoner brought a hat to my lodgings, but I was not at home; I pawned it, and gave him the 6s. - my father afterwards gave me the money to get a hat out of pawn, but I cannot say that it was the same; the pawnbroker is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1963.
MARY GOUGH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 shawl, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
John Cuss
; and that she had been before convicted of felony .

ANN DONNELLEY
. I live in William-street, Portland-town
. My father-in-law, John Cuss, is a chimney-sweeper ; I have known the prisoner by sight about twelve months, carrying fruit about - on the 12th of July she came to where I live; she was not much in liquor. but she wanted to lay down; I put up this shawl at the window, to make it dark; I afterwards went into the yard; I missed this shawl, and saw an older one put up in its place - I called to a young man named Cox, who took this shawl from the prisoner's bosom.

RICHARD MOORE
. (Police-constable S 47.) I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was very much in liquor, and throw myself on your mercy.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Confined One Month .
The former conviction was not proved.

1964.
MARY DRISCOLL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 2 gowns, value 18s., and 1 shawl, value 2s. , the goods of
Eliza Patmore
.

ELIZA PATMORE. I am single , and lodge in Queen-street, Seven-dials
. On the 14th of July the prisoner left that house; she had lodged there for a fortnight -I missed two gowns, a cap, and a shawl; I found the prisoner in custody.

ROBERT WILSON MEAGLE
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Tottenham-court-road. I produce a gown and cap, pawned with me - I do not know by whom.

WILLIAM WILSON
. (Police-constable E 74.) I took the prisoner on the 16th of July; she told me she lodged in Church-street - I went there, and asked which was her room - the people of the house told me, and I found the duplicates there - the prisoner said she had made away with them, but she would restore them again.
R. W. MEAGLE. These are the duplicates I gave, in the names of Margaret Flynn and Ann Richardson.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. What the Policeman says is quite false; I got a drop of liquor, and do not remember what I did, but I did not say what he states.

GUILTY . Aged 21 -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1965.
THOMAS PITHARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 24 pairs of gloves, value 15s., and 30 skins, value 30s. , the goods of
Robert Pullman
.

ROBERT WILLIAM
PULLMAN. I am the son of Robert Pullman, of West-street
, a leather-dresser . On the 2nd of August I was in the first floor; the prisoner was in our service, and was my father's cousin -I came down, and heard some paper shuffling; I went to the spot, and saw Whitelock.

ROBERT WHITELOCK
. I am the prosecutor's porter. I saw the prisoner roll up some gloves and skins, and take them towards the door - I do not know what became of them; he was in the habit of taking gloves home for his wife to sew.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you not live next door to the prisoner? A. Yes; I sell gloves for the prosecutor.

JOHN BAYS
. I am an officer. I was in Earl-street, Seven-dials; and from information from Mrs. Reece, I went to her house, and found the property; I took her to the office.
MRS. REECE. The officer found the bundle on my premises - Mrs. Pithard gave it me to be sewn; I am in the habit of sewing for different persons.

COURT to ROBERT WHITELOCK. Q. Can you tell that it was the prosecutor's property which the prisoner took? A. No - I cannot recollect what I said before the Magistrate; I said I believed them to be what he took - I cannot say these are the same; I told the Magistrate that I saw the prisoner taking away the gloves produced - I do not know whether they are the same.
NOT GUILTY .

1966.
JOHN ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 4 glazed window-sashes, value 2l., the goods of
Mary Cock
, and fixed to a certain building ; against the Statute, &c.

GEORGE HURST
. I know Mrs. Cock's house - it is empty. On the 21st of July I saw the prisoner within four or five yards of that house, at half-past seven o'clock in the morning, with the sashes on his shoulder - I told my father, and he was taken the same morning.

THOMAS SEAL
(Police-constable G 145). I received information that the house had been broken into, and two men had been seen to leave it, and one of them carrying a number of sashes - I went one way, and saw the prisoner carrying these sashes; he went with them some distance, and then another man joined him; they then parted - I still followed the prisoner till he came near the station-house, and then I took him; he said a gentleman had given him 6d. to carry them to Bishopsgate-street.

MARY MOORE
. I had the key of the house - I had shown it to a person, and in a few days after there was an alarm, and these sashes were missing.

MARY ANN WILSWORTH
. The house is a leasehold-house, and belongs to my mother
Mary Cock
; she is a widow - I have seen these sashes fitted to the frame; the house had been locked, and there were marks of a forcible entrance.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that a man, whom he had met at Islington, had employed him to carry the sashes.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1967.
WILLIAM ROBINSON
was
indicted for embezzlement .

JOHN MUNRO LANGCAKE
. The prisoner had been in my service, but was not authorized to receive money.
NOT GUILTY .

1968.
THOMAS SMITH
,
GEORGE NORTH
, and
EDGAR BULLOCK
were indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of July , 1 purse, value 6d., and 35 shillings, the property of
Edward Hargraves
; and that the said
Thomas Smith
had been before convicted of felony .

EDWARD HARGRAVES. I am a labouring man , and live in Tothill-court, Tothill-street, Westminster. On the 28th of July, from one to half-past one o'clock in the morning, I was in Little Tothill-street, near Old Pye-street; I had received this money from a gentleman, and I am sorry to say he gave me a good deal to drink; I was the worse for liquor, but I remember I lost my purse and property - I had been into an eating-house at the corner of Little Tothill-street
, and when I left, the three prisoners went out with me; I do not know whether they went in with me, or after me - I believe I had some conversation with them in the house, but I do not know what about; I am not aware whether there were any other persons with them - we went down the Broadway, and turned down the first street on the left-hand - I was going along, and caught my foot against a stone, and nearly fell down; the three prisoners then seized hold of me, and snatched my purse out of my right-hand waistcoat pocket - it contained one sixpence, thirty-five shillings, and, I think, a shilling or two more; I suppose we had got two hundered yards from the eating-house - I am sure they were all round about me, and they all ran off round the corner immediately, and I saw no more of them; I went like a distracted man back to where I came from, and the eating-house keeper, hearing a noise, said he thought it was somebody outside with the cholera morbus - I told him what it was, and he said he knew the men who were with me when I quitted the house, and if he saw them that morning, he would have them apprehended; he begged of me to go home - I did, and went to bed - in about an hour and a half the Police-officers came to me, and said they had apprehended the men; I went with them- I have not seen my purse since, but I saw a purse with some money in it - I cannot swear that the prisoners are the three men.

GEORGE WOLFF
. I keep the eating-house. The three prisoners came to my house, and had their suppers - the prosecutor came afterwards, and sat down at the same table; he called for some pudding - I brought it, and asked for the money; he refused to give it me, and I took the pudding back - he then took out his purse, laid it on the table, and said," I have money to pay;" he was intoxicated; I then took the things off the table - he put the money into his purse, and went out, and the three prisoners followed him; he came back, and said he was robbed -I took him in, and told the Policemen of it.
Bullock. Q. Was there not a sixpence dropped? A. Yes.

THOMAS CREED
(Police-constable B 99). I took the prisoners, with the assistance of two other officers - I saw them leave the house with the prosecutor at half-past one o'clock in the morning - Bullock had hold of the prosecutor's arm, and the other two followed; I went back, and the keeper of the eating-house told me the prosecutor had some silver about him, and I had better look after them - I went, but lost sight of them; in about a quarter of an hour I passed the eating-house again, and heard of the robbery; I took the prosecutor to the watch-house, to take his name and address - I then went to Union-court, where I knew the prisoners lived; I met two of my brother officers - we went to their house; the door was locked - we stopped till about three o'clock - I was then coming away; my brother officer called me back, and he had the men in custody; I asked if they recollected being at the eating-house, and leaving it with a drunken man - they denied it; I sent for the prosecutor, and he identified them all - I found 11s. 9d. on Smith, 3d. on North, and 1 1/2d. on Bullock.
North. Q. Did I deny being at the cook-shop? A. Yes.
COURT to EDWARD HARGRAVES. Q. Is this receipt your writing? A. Yes, my Lord; I received this money from North's mother (read.)

Received in full of all demands, of Elizabeth North, 1l. 10s., in part of property taken from my person, on Saturday, the 28th of July, against my will, by George North, Thomas Smith, and Edgar Bullock. EDWARD HARGRAYES.

BENJAMIN TIMBRELL
. I am an officer. I know Smith- I have a certificate of his conviction in December, 1825- I was constable of the night when he was taken; I know he is the person.

Smith's Defence. I went into the shop - the prosecutor was there; he called for some pudding, and would not pay for it; he then took out his purse, and shook the money; a 6d. fell out, and Bullock gave it to him.

North's Defence. I went to a friend's between seven and eight o'clock; I had something to drink, and staid till nearly one - on my way home I went to this shop, and had a basin of soup, and some bread; I then went home, and found my wife was not at home - I went to my mother's, who said my wife was gone home; as I was going home I met the officers; they put a light before my face, and let me pass - I went on home, and when I got there the officers came, and took me.
Bullock's Defence. I went to the shop; the prosecutor came in, and called for some pudding; I went to my sister's, as I could not get in at home.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Life .

NORTH -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

BULLOCK -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1969.
RICHARD TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 2 handkerchiefs, value 6s. , the goods of
Maurice Welch
.

MAURICE WELCH. I work under a market-gardener . I lost my handkerchief on the 11th of July, out of my bedroom, at my sister's, where I lodge; I left the key over the door for my sister, when she came home from work, and when I came home in the afternoon I found the key in the door - I then missed the two handkerchiefs.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How high did you put the key? A. As high as I could reach; it was not possible for this little boy to reach to it - he has a brother very much like him.

WILLIAM HORLEY
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two handkerchiefs, which were pawned by the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

1970.
THOMAS TURNER
and
ALEXANDER CLARK
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 pair of boots, value 4s. , the goods of
George Green
.

GEORGE GREEN. I am a shoemaker , and live in Shoreditch
. On the evening of the 27th of July I was standing in my shop; my son called out, "A man has stolen some boots," and he ran after Turner, calling Stop thief! I took Turner - my son said, "That is the man that took the boots, but he gave them to another, who is gone the other way;" I looked, but could not find him; in about ten minutes my son said, "Here is the other boy," and he pointed to Clark - I took him; the boots have not been found.

GEORGE GREEN
, JUN. I am the prosecutor's son. Turner came to the shop, and cut the string of a pair of boots; he gave them to Clark, who ran away with them, and then they both ran away - I ran after Turner, and my father took him; I am sure he was the boy.

JOSEPH RYAN
(Police-constable G 216.) About half-past nine o'clock I was in Shoreditch, and heard the cry of Stop thief! I ran up; Clark was given to me, and I took him to the station - Turner was loitering about there, and Clark said to him, "I am pinned for them boots," and from the description I had received I took Turner - I found this knife on him, which the little boy says he thinks is the knife.

TURNER -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

CLARK -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

1971.
JOHN THORPE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 live tame goose, price 4s. , the property of
Esquire Duke
.

JOHN CANTY
(Police-constable N 168). I was on duty in Upper-street, Islington, at half-past one o'clock in the morning of the 26th of August; I saw the prisoner carrying a goose, and took him into custody - he was half a mile from the prosecutor's.
ESQUIRE DUKE. I know this goose to be mine; I had seen it safe the morning before, in a little paddock at the back of my house - I do not know the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw a man on Highgate-hill with some geese in a cart - his trace broke, and he asked me if I had a bit of string; I lent him a bit - a man came and asked if the geese were for sale; he said Yes, they were 3s. each: I said I would have one for half a crown and bought it.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1972.
EMMA VINCENT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 quilt, value 3s.; 2 sheets, value 2s., and 1 pillow-case, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Overton
.

THOMAS OVERTON. I live in Exeter-place, Chelsea
. The prisoner lodged with me eleven days; she came as a married woman - no man lived with her; I missed my property, and got the officer - she said she pawned them from distress, and gave the duplicates.

JOHN GAMMON
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce the articles.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY. Aged 29.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

1973.
SARAH YOUNG
was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 shawl, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
William Salter
; and that she had been before convicted of felony .

MARY SALTER
. I am the wife of William Salter, a porter ; we live in Long-acre
. On the 1st of August, my landlady called me - I went down and saw the prisoner at the bottom of the stairs; this shawl had been taken off a box inside the door of my room, while I was washing.

JEMIMA FARMER
. I saw the prisoner come along the passage of my house - I called the prosecutrix down; the prisoner had these sheets, but I did not see the shawl at that time - I knew she was a stranger, and asked what business she had there; she said she wanted a person named Taylor - I then asked where she got the sheets which she had under her shawl; the prosecutrix pulled the sheets from her, and this shawl dropped down - there is no owner found for the sheets.

JOHN DAY
(Police-constable C 134). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction - I know she is the person; I attended and saw her - she was ordered to be fined 1s. - (read).

GUILTY . Aged 55. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1974.
MARY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 1 set of boot-trees, value 10s., and 3 brushes, value 2s., the goods of
George Hanson
; and that she had been before convicted of felony .

JOHN NISBITT (Police-constable E 6). I stopped the prisoner near Russell-square on the 24th of July, at halfpast six o'clock in the morning; she had these articles on her - I asked what she had got: she said various articles which she had brought from Charlton-street, Somers'-town where she lived - that she was going to Mr. Ardin's, in Staples Inn, and she was laundress there; I then looked at the things, and asked her if he had said she was to carry a set of boot-trees there - she said she had heard of them, but she did not know whether she was to carry them that morning or not; I said, "I will go there with you:" we went a few steps, and then she said, "I am going to my daughter" - I then took her; this was about five hundred yards from the prosecutor's.

THOMAS BARRETT
. I am a footman to
George Hanson
, Esq . I lost these trees from a cellar in the front area on the morning in question - the gate is kept locked: I do not know the prisoner.

GEORGE BENCON
(Police-constable D 155). I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction - I know she is the person; she had fourteen days in Newgate.

GUILTY . Aged 54. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1975.
PATRICK BUCKLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 waistcoat, value 8s. , the goods of
Richard Carpenter
.

CHARLES SELLS
. I live with Mr. Richard Carpenter, he keeps a sale-shop at Brentford
; he lost a waistcoat on the 26th of August. I did not see it taken, but I heard it was gone - I went after the prisoner, who was about four hundred yards from the shop - he said he had not got it, but in coming back, he dropped it.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me take it, or drop it? ANo, but the people called out that he had dropped it, and there was no one near him; this is it.

Prisoner. I went to the shop, and came out again - this witness came after me, and said I had a waistcoat; I said I had not - he said, "Go back and free yourself;" I was going back, and some one dropped a waistcoat - he said I dropped it.

CHARLES SELLS
. He had been looking at some waistcoats, he brought one from the door, and asked the price of it, but none of them suited him; he went out - my master went to the door, and asked if I had sold one - I said No; I then missed it - there had been no one else there.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1976.
JAMES CREASLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , 1 pair of boots, value 13s. , the goods of
Mark Kerslake
.

MARK KERSLAKE
. I am a boot and shoemaker , and live in the Strand
. These are my boots.

CHARLES HIVOUTTERS
. I am a peruke-maker. I was near the prosecutor's shop, on the 20th of July, and saw the prisoner take a pair of boots down from the window, with the ticket; I ran after him - I found I could not overtake him, and called the Policeman.

WILLIAM BADDLEY
