. On the day stated, the prisoner came and took a pair of boots off the door of the prosecutor's shop - I pursued him, and never lost sight of him till he was taken - these are the boots.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent; I did not take them - a man gave them to me to hold.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1977.
WILLIAM COLEMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 1 jacket, value 2s.; 1 cap, value 6d., and 1 collar, value 3d. , the goods of
Henry Kimber
.

HENRY KIMBER. These are my articles - they were on the gravel, by the water-side, near Bow-common
- I did not see them taken, but a little lad told me they had run away with my things; I followed the gang up to Stepney-fields, and gave charge of them - I had seen the prisoner before I went into the water, and left him in charge of my clothes - he was a stranger to me; I gave an alarm, and the officer took the prisoner with the things.

WILLIAM CLAYTON
. I am an officer. The prosecutor told me he had lost his clothes. I took the prisoner the next morning in Angel-court, Shadwell; I told him I took him on a charge of stealing the jacket and other things; he said nothing, but the things were in the room - his mother gave them to me.(Property prodcued and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a very good character.
GUILTY. Aged 10.

Recommended to Mercy -
Judgment Respited
.

1978.
JOHN CASHMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 3 saucepans, value 9s., and 1 fryingpan, value 1s. , the goods of
Henry Benjamin
.

MARY CARTY
. I live at Mr. Benjamin's, on Saffronhill
- I left these articles safe in his yard. On the morning of the 24th of July, I was awoke by my master, who asked me if they were my mistress' property; I said Yes - there are palings all round the yard, and these things had been on the shelf, and on the washing-stool.
Prisoner. Q. Does not the door of the yard open into a court? A. Yes, I cannot say whether it was bolted.

RICHARD VERYAN
. About twenty minutes after five o'clock that morning, I was getting up; I heard a little rumbling in the court - I looked out, and saw the prisoner get over the palings of the prosecutor's yard; I saw him take one iron saucepan off a shelf - I called a Policeman, who came and took him.

JOHN WILLIAM TURNER
(Police-constable G 218). I went and took the prisoner in a house opposite the prosecutor's back door; he had some soap and some tins, which were taken out of the yard.

JOHN SMITH
(Police-constable G 33). I found the three saucepans and the frying-pan in the passage; when the officer took the prisoner, I found this piece of soap in his pocket, which had been in one of the saucepans.

MARY CARTY
. I lost a piece of soap, and I believe this is it, and the paper of pins.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been at a raffle till half-past four o'clock in the morning; I then went home with a young woman to Bridgewater-gardens; at half-past five I came to this court, where I had lived two or three years ago - I went into this yard to get some water to wash me, and took some out of one of these saucepans -I could not take these three saucepans and the frying-pan away.
NOT GUILTY .

1979.
THOMAS COLE
was
indicted for embezzlement .

JOHN JACKSON
. I live in Kingsland-road
, and am an earthenware-dealer . The prisoner was my errand-boy ; he used to receive money for me, and give an account when he returned - he absconded after receiving this money.

HANNAH MORGAN
. I paid the prisoner 10s. on the 1st of August for his master; he gave me this receipt -(read).
The prisoner handed in a petition, expressing his contrition; he received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 15.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1980.
THOMAS DAVENPORT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 2 watches, value 4l. 10s.; 6 seals, value 4l. 10s.; 1 watch-key, value 4s., and 2 shoes, value 6s., the goods of
Robert Turner
, his master .

ROBERT TURNER. I am a broker , and live in Friar-street, Blackfriars-road
- the prisoner was my shopman for three days. On the 18th of July I went to bed, and had two watches, one on a nail, and one in a bureau drawer, in the room I sleep in - the prisoner slept in the shop; I got up a little before seven o'clock in the morning - he had then absconded, and I missed these articles - the bed-room door had not been locked; I took him four or five days afterwards.

FRANCIS HENRY PARKER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a watch, pawned by the prisoner on the 19th of July.
Prisoner. Q. Can you swear that I pawned it? A. Yes.

JEREMIAH HENRY
JOYCE. I am a pawnbroker, and live in the New-road. I have a watch pawned by the prisoner to the best of my knowledge.

JOHN SHEPHERD
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found the duplicates on him.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1981.
CHARLES FITZPATRICK
and
JOHN FICKEN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 6 live tame pigeons, price 6s. , the property of
James Gabriel
.

JAMES GARRIEL. I live at Shadwell
, and keep pigeons in a shed adjoining the house; I missed six on the 25th of July; they had been safely locked in at half-past eleven o'clock the night before - I missed them at six in the morning; they had got in at the top, taken them out, and shut down the lid again; by the description of some boys, I suspected the prisoners; I saw Ficken on the evening of the 26th - I asked him where the pigeons were; he said he knew nothing about them - I gave him in charge.

PETER BUCKHEAD
. I am a weaver, and keep pigeons. I bought these three of the two prisoners on the 26th of July, at twelve o'clock - they are common pigeons; one of the prisoners had two, and the other had one: I paid the money to Ficken.

ERASMUS CHARLTON
(Police-constable K 135.) -Ficken was given to me by the prosecutor; he said they had sold them at a house in Spitalfields; I took Fitzpatrick the next morning.(Property produced and sworn to.)

FITZPATRICK -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

FICKEN -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged.
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 12.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1982.
GEORGE HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , at St. Matthew, Bethnal-green, 55 yards of silk, value 7l., the goods of
George Wyatt
, in the dwelling-house of
Benjamin Newley
.

GEORGE WYATT
. I am a silk weaver , and lodge on the ground floor at Benjamin Newley's, in South-street, Bethnal-green
- the prisoner lodged in the same house, and is a silk weaver; he lodged up stairs in the workshop, and slept there. On the 31st of August I got up the about halfpast six o'clock in the morning, and went up to the workshop, where I had a considerable quantity of silk in the loom- it was entrusted to me by my employer; I am answerable for it - it is worth 7l. at least: I missed it, and the prisoner had left the house without giving any notice; I suspected him, and looked about for him - this was on Tuesday, and on the Monday I found him; I said, "George, you have got me into a pretty mess - I am likely to lose my bread;" a person said, "What has he done?" I said he had robbed me of sixty yards of silk; the prisoner replied "There were not sixty yards, it was between fifty and sixty, for I measured it."

BENJAMIN NEWLEY
. I am a silk-weaver. I told the prisoner he had got me into a pretty mess, for our master suspected this was our own doing, and asked what he had done with it - he said he had pawned it; I went to the pawnbroker's by his direction, and found it.

HENRY JEROME
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Wood-street. I produce a piece of silk, which was pawned by the prisoner on the 31st of July.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Life .

1983.
ELIZA STEWART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 6 sovereigns, and 6 half-sovereigns, the monies of
John Martin
, in the dwelling-house of
Mary Martin
.

JOHN MARTIN
. I am shopman to my sister,
Mary Martin
, who keeps a clothes-shop in Robert-street, in the parish of St. George, Hanover-square
; she rents the house - I sleep in the kitchen; I got up on the 8th of August, about seven o'clock, and about eight I took this money from my coat pocket, and put it into my box in the kitchen, in a paper; there was 28l. in gold - I locked the box, and the kitchen door, and took both keys with me; the prisoner lived in the same house - she brought a man there as her husband; I missed my money about ten o'clock at night- the kitchen door had been opened by a key; the box was broken open - the paper was not taken, but six sovereigns, and six half-sovereigns were taken out of it; I gave the prisoner in charge next morning - I was in the shop, but did not go out; it might have been taken directly I got up stairs.

MARY PARSONS
. I live in this house. On the Wednesday morning in question, the prisoner came to me, between eleven and twelve o'clock, and said she had some work for me; I do needle-work - she opened a parcel and gave me a bombasin dress to make; she went out after dinner with her sister-in-law, and brought me a bonnet to trim - we had tea, and she asked me to go out with her; she bought various articles, paid some bills, and appeared flush of money - she came to me in the morning, and said, "What a fuss there is, the landlord of the house has been robbed, and I am suspected;" she told me not to mention what she had done, but I told the truth - after this she brought me down a basket full of things to conceal, and placed them under my bed with her own hands.

THOMAS HOBBS
. I am a Policeman. The prosecutor gave the prisoner into custody for stealing nine sovereigns; she denied the charge - the prosecutor's sister went down and brought up these articles, and no sooner did the prisoner see them, than she said, "Well I bought them, I took but two sovereigns and a half, and laid them out in these articles;" she said she took the two sovereigns and a half off the table.

THOMAS FARRANT
, I am a Policeman. I received the prisoner in charge; on the way to the station-house, she told me she had unlocked the door with her own key, and took two sovereigns and a half off the table; I found her key fitted the lock.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Life .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

1984.
WILLIAM OLIVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of June , at St. Leonard, Shoreditch, 5 sovereigns 1 half-sovereign, 2 half-corwns, and 5 shillings, the monies of
Joseph Harding
, in his dwelling-house .

JOSEPH HARDING. I am a milkman , and live in New North-road, St. Leonard, Shoreditch
. The prisoner lodged with me for five months.

HANNAH HARDING
. I am the prosecutor's wife. I received five soverereigns and a half, two half-crowns, and five shillings, which I put into a small box, and placed on the kitchen mantel-piece, in the prisoner's presence; he wrote a receipt for it for me, and I left him in the kitchen, writing a letter for himself; I returned in about ten minutes - he was gone; the box was in its place, but the money gone from it; we could hear nothing of the prisoner.

GEORGE DEHANE
. I am a Policeman. On the 9th of August I was in New North-road; the prisoner came to me - he said he had committed a robbery, and wished to be taken into custody, for he had been at Bristol, and he could get nothing to do, and would rather be transported than remain in England - he said he was sorry for what he had done; that he had robbed Mr. Harding - he told me the amount, and when he had done it.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Life .
Second London Jury, before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1985.
PHOEBE JAMES, alias MARY POWEL
, was indicted for
that she, on the 13th of March , feloniously did utter, dispose of, and put off a certain forged will and testament of one
Benjamin Norrington
, well knowing it to be forged, with intent to defraud
Jemima Norrington
and others .
TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating her intent to be to defraud other persons.

JEMIMA NORRINGTON
. I am step-mother to Benjamin Norrington, who went to sea on the 10th of February, 1831 - his father was not living when he went; he left a paper with me - I took it to Mr. Thackray (looking at it) this is it; I saw
Benjamin Norrington
write it; he went out in the Baretto, Junior, which returned on the 4th of March, and shortly after I heard of his death; I took the paper to Mr. Clarkson's, and tried to prove it as his will, but they would not let me; after the ship returned, two men brought me another paper; I did not go with them to Doctors'-commons.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What has become of the paper the two men brought? A. Mr. Thackray has it; they did not leave it with me, it was never in my possession; (produced) - this is Norrington's hand-writing; he had been a seaman for about seven years - he was twenty-four years old; he had no sweetheart to my knowlege, but he may have had one.

The documents being read, were as follows - the first was without a date."I, B. Norrington, leave my mother my will, wages, goods and chattels, provided death calls me. - B. Norrington." The second (brought by the two men) was a regular will, bequeathing all his goods and effects to
Sarah Norrington
,
Thomas Nevell
, and
Samuel Blake
, and his wages to his mother, residing at Low Layton, Essex.

SAMUEL MAYNARD
. I am a clerk to Mr. Scurlock, a proctor. The prisoner came to our office on the 18th of March, and brought this will (looking at it); he had a man with her; I cannot say whether the prisoner or the man gave it to me; the man paid me for the probate - he gave me the name of Tye; the prisoner gave the name of Mary Powell, and she administered to the will; the probate was afterwards granted to her as the sole executrix - there is no written affidavit; the oath is administered by the surrogate; it is, that she was the sole executrix named in the will, that the effects were under 20l., and that she believed the paper contained the last will and testament of the deceased.
The will was here put in and read; it was dated the 8th of February, 1831, signed B. Norrington, his mark; and bequeathing all his property to Mary Powell, his intended wife.

JOHN CLIFFORD PETRIE
. I am clerk to Mr. Read, ship-broker to the Baretto, Junior, which arrived on the 4th of March, having sailed about the 8th of February, 1831; the prisoner came about the 18th of March, and applied for the money of Benjamin Norrington; she did not produce a paper at that time; I told her to call after twenty-one days, when the ship would be paid off; she called two or three days after the twenty-one days, and produced a parchment, but I did not look at it; she was told to call again, which she did, and I then looked at the probate of the will which she produced, and seeing it purported to have the mark of Benjamin Norrington; I told her he could write his own name, and produced the ship's articles, which I had seen him sign; she said that was Benjamin Norrington's mark; she was told that we could not pay her on that account, and we did not pay her; she went away, and the next application was made by Mr. Howard, a solicitor of Mincing-lane - the application was from Mr. Styles, his clerk - he came alone; when the prisoner applied to me there was always a man with her - I do not know who he was.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you not know that sometimes seamen, when they can write, will make their mark? A. They do sometimes.
COURT. Q. Is that a frequent thing? A. Not very; it is generally the case with those who cannot write very well; I have seen it done once or twice - I do not call this good writing.

JOHN STYLES
. I am clerk to Mr. Howard, of Mincing-lane. The prisoner applied to me on or about the 3rd of April to make application to the owners of the Baretto, Jun. for the payment of 15l. odd - I applied at Mr. Read's office, where I saw two gentlemen; I did not get the money- the prisoner instructed me to apply for her as the executrix of Norrington, and brought with her the probate, which was returned to her.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not she appear anxious that you should proceed hostile for the recovery of the money? A. Yes; she insisted on it as her right; I saw no appearance of fear or guilt.

JAMES LEA
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on Thursday, the 12th of July, in Farringdon-street- I told her I took her on a charge of forging the will of Benjamin Norrington, and asked her name; she said
Phoebe James
- I said I had been looking for her for a length of time; she said she heard I had been looking for her, and she might as well be taken first as last; that she had just come from Newgate, where she had been to see Morgan and Dalton; I said Mrs. Norrington, the motherof the young man, had been to town several times about the will - she said she (the prisoner) had not had the money, and she might get it, she did not prevent her from getting it - I then said there was another charge against her where she had assumed the name of Phoebe James to a will; she said that was all right, and if she had known what she did now, she would not have given up any of the money which she got on the will; that she had given 10l. to a man - she then asked if the writers of the will had not a right to be taken as well as her; I said Yes, if I knew who they were; I told her I had found the probate of Norrington's will in Dalton's house, No. 11, Princes-street, Princes-square - she said he ought to be kicked for a fool; I searched her at the office, and found on her five letters, directed to Sarah James, and signed Andrew Morgan, and one
Andrew Dalton
- I found this probate of the will in Dalton's house about April; I also found there a will, four papers, and a number of wills, which I have not brought.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it your custom to hold conversations with prisoners, and afterwards give evidence of it? A. No - I told her what I took her for, and she talked to me; I do not think I had any motive in telling her I had found the probate - it was after she had told me all about it that I said so.

JOHN STYLES
. This is the probate she produced.

SAMUEL MAYNARD
. This is the probate, which I took out, on the oath of the prisoner.

MARY ANN PRINGLE
. I know the prisoner; about the beginning of March this year I went to the Cock, in Leadenhall-street, and saw Thomas Fallen, Andrew Morgan, and John Dalton there; I went out with Dalton, and when I came back the prisoner was in the tap-room -Dalton and Fallen said to me, "How did you get on?" and I told them what Norrington's clothes sold for; I said his clothes sold for 7l. odd, and that his wages were 7l. odd - I said nothing more in the prisoner's presence, and do not think she said any thing; we drank together, and I left them; nothing more was said while I was there- I did not stay two minutes; none of them made any answer when I stated what the clothes sold for; Morgan and Fallen lived in the same house as I did - the ycame to me one evening, but the prisoner was not there; next morning Dalton and she were at Fallen's house, where I lived - they worked there; all that was said before the prisoner was, that the will was made out, and they were to give me a sovereign, and 5s. for my trouble in going up; I was to have that if she got the money - this was said on Saturday night; it was for going to the owners about the money, which I had done - I was to do nothing more for the sovereign; the prisoner said she did not mind; they seemed all agreeable to it; a few days after that I asked her how she got on with Benjamin Norrington's will; she said she was obliged to take it to a lawyer, as she could not get it, for the ship was put into the Commons', and she did not think she should get it at all; but Morgan was to pay 1l. to fetch the will away from the lawyer who she had employed to try to get the money - I afterwards asked her how she got on; she said she did not think she should get the money, for there was another will made on board the ship - I do not recollect ever seeing this paper before (looking at one.)

Cross-examined. Q. Were you ever married? A. Yes; my husband's name was Thomas Pringle - I have not lived with him for several years - I do not know whether he is alive; my maiden name was Pettit - I have gone by the name of Francis, who I lived with; and by the name of Carnel, who I lived with nine years, and buried - I swore by the name of Mary Elliot, at Doctor'scommons, by Mrs. Dalton's request, as she had a will at Mr. Clarkson's, and could not go up herself; I was in the House of Correction for a month, for unlawfully pawning a cloak which I had borrowed - I forget whether I ever swore in this Court that I was single; I did not swear I could not read - I said I could not read writing well - I do not recollect mentioning I could not read at all; I said I could not write the alphabet - I can read a little - I do not recollect whether I swore I could not read; I can write the different names I have gone by, but nothing else.

JOHN CLIFFORD PETRIE
. The witness never came to my house with the prisoner - I never saw her there to my knowledge; I know her; Norrington's effects sold for 7l. 9s. 6d., and his wages were 7l. 7s.

WILLIAM THOMAS. I am master of the Baretto Junior. She sailed from Portsmouth on the 20th of February; she left London about a week before - she arrived again on the 4th of March, 1832 -
Benjamin Norrington
was a sailor on board, and died about the 14th or 15th of August.

Cross-examined. Q. How long before she sailed had you joined her? A. On the 7th of February, in the London-docks - she sailed from London about a week before the 20th; sailors who write a middling or bad hand, sometimes make their mark instead of their names- I have known that done two or three dozen times.
COURT. Q. Look at this; has that been the case with people who could write as well as this? A. Yes; men often say their hands are unsteady.

JOHN FRAZER
. I was Dalton's landlord. The prisoner called on me with a letter from Dalton, who was then a prisoner in Newgate; it was two or three days after he was committed, and about two months ago she wished to remove some clothes, but did not have them.
The five letters found in the prisoner's pocket were all directed to Mrs. James, or Phoebe James; four of them were signed Andrew Morgan, and one John Dalton.

Prisoner's Defence (written). I must confess that I have been too credulous in yielding to the false and impious persuasions of a young man named Pavel, whose name I have for some time assumed, and by whom I was, about six years ago, seduced from my parents and friends, and having brought me from my native city (Worcester) to London, was soon afterwards deserted by him, leaving me without any means of obtaining a livelihood otherwise than at the expence of chastity; on which I, in the first instance, am sorry to say, set too slight a value - in the course of these dissolute pursuits, it was my province to become acquainted with various seafaring men, one of whom was Norrington, the testator of the will in question, and who, in the course of a long intimacy, always gave me to understand that he had no relatives or friends to whom he was under any obligation, alleging, that although he had a step-mother, he did not consider her any relative - on the 8th of February, 1831, after informing me of his intention of going to sea, he left me the will, and told me, that in the course of a day or two the ship would be at Gravesend, from whence he would send me a monthly note;and on condition that I would mend my course of life, promised that we should get married on his return from sea; on the ship's arrival from India, I naturally made inquiry respecting him, and on discovering his decease, applied at Mr. Read's countinghouse, where I was instructed to administer to his wages and effects; I shall not further trespass on you with the details of intimate friendship that subsisted between the deceased and myself, but will suffice it to remark, that there could be no necessity for making a second will in favour of the step-mother, had the testator not revoked the first will to her by the will made in my favour. for which I am now prosecuted, and the date of which is evidently between the two wills in the step-mothers possession.
NOT GUILTY .
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Baron Gurney.

1986.
JOHN BOWERY
and
JOSEPH HARTLEY
were indicted for
feloniously killing and slaying
William Willis
.

ROBERT WILLIS
. I am the brother of William Willis; he was younger than me - he was seven years and seven months old. I was at Mr. Arnold's paper-manufactory with him some days before he died; I was there a week and two days - on a Thursday, about half-past one o'clock in the day, I saw the two prisoners there; Bowery leaned my brother over the valve of the steam-boiler, and Hartley let it off on him.

Q. Did they say why they did this? A. Because he took some grapes out of Mr. Arnold's garden the day before; he and some other boy s had got into the garden and taken them - I think the prisoners were laughing when they did this; I did not hear what either of them said - the steam went to my brother's face.

Q. Did it hurt him? A. No, only the fright; he became ill two or three minutes afterwards - he did not go home till about an hour after; when the steaming was going on he called out Murder! and tried to get away - he did not try to kick either of them; I think I have said he was trying to kick them - he died on the Sunday week afterwards.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. This happened on a Thursday? A. Yes; I had seen my brother eating the grapes on Wednesday night - I did not eat any, they were not very ripe; I think he had a bunch - he eat some of them; I am not sure that he did not eat the whole bunch - it was as large as my first; they were green grapes - I saw him on the Friday, laying on the cellar flap; he could not play about, he could walk about.
Q. Did he not walk about the place where the steamengine is, all day? A. Yes; he was taken to Mr. Wilson, the doctor.

MARY WILLIS
. I am the last witness' mother - he is twelve years old next February; my son, who is dead, was seven years and seven months old; he came home to me about an hour after the steaming, and looked very ill; he was playing about on Friday and Saturday, and was taken ill in the middle of Saturday night - I called in Mr. Wilson on Sunday morning; he voided a worm on the Thursday or Friday after he was steamed - he vomited it upwards, when I gave him a cup of beef tea; I gave the worm to one of the Coroner's Jury.

Q. In what way was he taken ill on Saturday night? -A. With violent purging and vomiting, and that continued till his death; he died on the Sunday following, the 2nd of September - I observed that his eyes never closed from the Sunday he was taken ill till he died.

MR. WILSON. I was first consulted about this child on Sunday; he was attacked with violent vomiting and purging - I administered medicine adapted to that complaint; I saw him but twice - the second time was on Thursday; the mother did not show me the worm, nor apprise me of it - I did not attend the opening of the body; the disease appeared likely to terminate in death.

Q. Could you judge of any other cause for death than the disease? A. My opinion is, there was something in the bowels and stomach causing continued irritation - a boy of his temperament and age eating unripe grapes I should think very likely to produce that; it was as likely to produce that complaint as any thing - it did not strike me at the time that he had worms; his mother did not inform me of his having been steamed till after the Thursday - as far as my opinion goes, I should think that could not have caused his death; I saw the worm before the inquest (looking at it) - there are generally a number of worms in the stomach where one is found; they are often produced by eating unripe fruit, that is the exciting cause, but they are produced by a morbid secretion of the canal.

Cross-examined. Q. Would not a severe complaint of the stomach produce some complaint on the brain? A. That is generally consecutive; the brain and stomach act on each other - there is great sympathy between them.
COURT. Q. We have heard of his eyes being continually open from the Friday till he died, does that indicate any thing the matter with the brain? A. It often does.

MR.
HUGH LEWIS
. I am a surgeon. I opened the head and body of the child after death; the approximate cause of death was inflammation of the surface of the brain; there was a predisposing cause in the system, which was a very firm adhesion of the membrane lining the chest - that must have proceeded from inflammation; it was a predisposing cause providing an existing cause applied - I think it extremely probable that the steam being let off in his face was the cause.

Q. Are you able to say that with any certainty? A. There was a great deal of probability to come to that conclusion - any powerful stimulant on the mind may produce inflammation of the brain; it might be caused by other means; we are very often unable to account for inflammation: of the brain; and this may have been produced by causes which I could not observe - I found no worms on opening the body,
Cross-examined. Q. You have heard he was playing about for two days after the steaming? A. Yes - I did not attend him till I was called in to open the body.

Q. Do you agree with the opinion of the gentleman who attended him? A. With regard to the irritation of the stomach, I consider that a symptom of inflammation of the brain: unripe grapes might disorder his stomach - there is a great sympathy between the stomach and brain.
COURT. Q. The boy had been vomiting and purging all the week - might not that be the consequence of eating unripe grapes? A. Very probably it might.

HENRY ALLEN
. I was at work at Mr. Arnold's manufactory, and saw the boy after he was steamed, but not before - he came down the steps, turned round, and said,"You may do it again, if you like, for I am not frightened"- he did not appear frightened in the least; the engine was going at the time - I saw him at play an hour afterwards, and did not see him after that - I was fifteen or twenty yards from the engine-house while the steaming was going on; I heard no cries of Murder! nor any call.

MR.
THOMAS FIRTH
. I am a surgeon. I attended the opening of the body - my opinion is that the child died from inflammation of the brain; from the representation given, I should naturally conclude that arose from a certain exciting cause - that is the steam which was let off while he was held over it - vomiting and purging for a week would undoubtedly cause death; there was no inflammation of the chest; but there was the result of a prior inflammation in the thorax on the left side - that was a previous inflammation, not within the last ten days.

Q. Inflammation there sometimes produces some disorder in the brain? A. It is not usual - I have not witnessed it; there is certainly a sympathy between the stomach and brain; when the surface of the brain is inflamed we cannot sometimes ascertain the cause; it is very often so.

Cross-examined. Q. When there is a disordered state of the stomach, would you not expect some consecutive disorder of the brain? A. Not permanent; I should certainly expect the brain would be affected by a disordered stomach - vomiting and purging would irritate the stomach- I should not think the quantity of unripe grapes he eat would disorder his stomach; there may be constitutions where eating a single unripe grape would cause vomiting and purging - a child eating a dozen might be likely to produce it.

ISABELLA WATSON
. I took the child to the doctor on Sunday morning, and again on Thursday; he had not voided the worm then - I took him again on Friday, and told the doctor of it.
Witnesses for the Defence.

CHARLES WEST
, JUN. I am seven years old. I remember Charles Willis being steamed; I saw him on the Wednesday before that, in Mr. Wade's yard, eating green grapes - he had a bunch; there was a good many on it - I saw him nearly finish the bunch: I eat some - they were sour; they were off a wall.

MARY SUTTON
. I am in the employ of Messrs. Arnold, and saw Willis come down from the steaming; I was fifteen or twenty yards from him - I saw him quite pleased- he went to the gate to the rest of the boys; they asked how he liked it; he seemed quite pleased, and not frightened in the least; I saw him playing about for some time.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1987.
JAMES GLEESON
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
David Fitzerald
, on the 14th of August , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, and 6 shillings, his property .
The prosecutor's name being Fitzgerald, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1988.
FREDERICK TALBOT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August
, 27 spoons, value 13l.; 12 forks, value 9l., and 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 12s., the goods of
Henry Baker
; and 1 watch, value 1l., the goods of
Mary Donovan
, in the dwelling-house of the said
Henry Baker
; and
JAMES CARMOZIE
and
JAMES BOLTON
were indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

MARY DONOVAN
. I live in Albany-street, Regent's-park
, with Mr. Henry Baker - the prisoner Talbot was my fellow- servant
there for about four months. He called on the 18th of August, about half-past seven o'clock - (he had left about two months;) I let him in - he followed me down stairs; I did what I was about in the kitchen, and returned up to the dining-room, leaving him in the kitchen alone - I went down again in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour, and he was gone: I was alarmed, and went to the plate-chest, which is in my bed-room in the pantry, and joins the kitchen, and the plate was gone - I had washed the plate up the night before, and gave it to the housemaid - I saw her take it away to the closet; I saw part of it in the closet, but did not count it - I missed the articles stated in the indictment; my silver watch was gone from the head of my bed - I had seen it hanging there at seven o'clock that morning; I gave 3l. for it - the plate must have been worth more than 5l.; none of it has been found.

WILLIAM AGGS
. I am an inspector of the Police. I apprehended Carmozie on the 28th of August, at No. 2, Saffron-hill; I found his door fastened inside, and threatened twice to break it open - it was then opened; I found him and two women there - I asked his name; he said Johnson; I said I did not believe that, and that I wanted him for a robbery, in Albany-street - I said, "What was done with the plate?" he said, "So help me God, I know nothing about it;" I searched him: he said if I would not handcuff him, he would go with me quietly; and when we got on the landing, I said, "Come, come, Carmozie it won't do;" he said, "Oh! then you know me, do you?" I said, "Yes, I know you very well," and took him to the station.

JOHN SMITH
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended Bolton on the 28th of August, in Field-lane; I knocked at the door; a person asked who was there - I said, "An officer, open the door;" it was not opened - I went in and found Bolton in bed; I told him to get up, and that I wanted him for a robbery in Albany-street - he asked if any body was taken into custody; I said Yes, Carmozie: I took him to the station, and next morning, as I took him to the Albany-street station, he asked me not to tell the Magistrate, that he was acquainted with Carmozie, and when I took him I asked why he had not gone home that night, as I did not find him at his own lodging - he said he heard they were after Carmozie, and had kept out of the way, but that he was at home about four o'clock, just before Carmozie was taken: when I took him to Albany-street, station-house - he wished particularly to be locked up with, or to go and speak to Carmozie, which was refused; but as I took them both to the office, Carmozie said to Bolton, "We shall be transported - Talbot is taken, and has told all;" Bolton answered, "Never mind, they cannot hang us, it is only transportation."
Carmozie. Q. Where was this said? A. Part of the conversaton was just by the New church.

FRANCIS COLCOMB
. I am a shoe maker, and live at No. 38, Saffron-hill. Carmozie lodged with me at No. 94, Great Saffron-hill; we began to lodge together about three months ago, and separated about a month ago - we lodged together in August; I left No. 94, about three weeks ago - we slept in the same bed together; Talbot came into our room three or four days before Camberwell fair, which was the 18th of August, and on the 18th of August; he came while Carmozie and I were in bed - he called Carmozie up; they spoke together and Carmozie went out - he returned with Bolton, and then they all went out together; Talbot had a small bundle - I did not see what it contained; Talbot stopped in the room while Carmozie went out with Bolton, and afterwards they all went out together - I asked if I might go with them; he said No, I was to stop till they came back, which would be about half an hour; I staid about an hour and a half, and then went out - I returned about twelve o'clock, and in a little time Carmozie came up to me, and asked me to go to Camberwell fair; I walked a little way, we met Bolton and Talbot on Saffron-hill: Carmozie and Bolton went away - Talbot and I went on to the fair; I saw Carmozie with a sovereign, and Talbot with 12s. 6d.

WILLIAM STREATFIELD
. I keep a public-house on Saffron-hill. On the 18th of August, Carmozie and Bolton came into my house, and called for something to drink - I do not know whether it was in the morning, or the middle of the day; I saw they were very flush of money - they each had silver; I cannot say how much - I thought it very strange, knowing they had not the means of getting an existence; after sitting some time, they said they were going to the fair.

TALBOT -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .

BOLTON -
NOT GUILTY .

CARMOZIE -
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Patteson.

1989.
MARY ANN DILLON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 2 rings, value 6s.; 4 boxes, value 12s.; 2 spoons, value 5s.; 1 case, value 1s.; 14 yards of silk, value 30s.; 11 yards of persian, value 16s.; 1 pair of ear-rings and drops, value 7s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; 2 necklaces, value 7s.; 11 yards of gingham, value 2s.; 3 towels, value 1s.; 2 dresses, value 5s.; 1 comb, value 5s.; 1 shawl, value 6d.; 1 Bible, value 17s.; 1 brooch, value 3s.; 1 breast-pin, value 2s.; half a yard of calico-velvet, value 3s.; 1 fan, value 4d.; 1 locket, value 3s.; 5 yards of calico, value 2s.; 1 piece of foreign gold coin, value 36s.; 1 half-guinea, 1 half-crown, one shilling, and 1 sixpence, the property of
Ann Stone
, in her dwelling-house .

GEORGE FOX. I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Upper Seymour-street
, in the dwelling-house of Miss Ann Stone, who is an invalid, and obliged to be carried up and down stairs; she cannot attend here. The prisoner was in her service - she left her on Saturday night, the 28th of July, without notice, and on Sunday morning this property was missed; I went about three o'clock that afternoon, with an officer, to the prisoner's mother's, in Featherstone-street, City-road; the prisoner saw me coming, ran up stairs, and got behind the bed; I went into the room, and said, **Mary, it is no use your running behind the bed" - she came out directly; I said,"Oh, Mary, what have you been doing?" I asked her where the things were which she had taken from Miss Stone - she made no answer; her mother said, "Here is something I have picked off the floor, and was just coming to Miss Stone's, to ask if these things were hers;" we searched the room, and found this property belonging to Miss Stone - I have seen them in her possession; here is a gold coin and gold chain - I should value all the things at about 9l.; no one article is worth 1l.

EDWARD LAMBERT
. I am a Police-officer. I went with Fox - his account is correct.

WILLIAM JONES
. I am shop-boy to Mr. Redpath, a pawnbroker. These two pieces of silk were pawned on Friday, the 27th of July, by the prisoner, in the name of Ann and Mary Fox; she said that was her mistress' name - that she pawned one for her mistress, and the other for her mother; I saw them pawned, and made out the duplicates.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY of stealing to the value of 99s. only . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1990.
JOHN COSTER ALESMORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 gelding, price 10l. , the property of
John East
.

JOHN EAST. I live at Hillingdon
; I am a labourer ; I have known the prisoner from a child. On Saturday, the 28th of July, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I saw my gelding safe in the field in which I kept it, and on Sunday morning, about seven, I found the gate lifted off the hinges, and the gelding gone; it was worth about 12l. - I saw it again next day at the One Tun, Old Brentford, in possession of the Police-man; I had seen the prisoner in the field the same afternoon - he lived about two miles off.

JOHN WARD
. I keep a cart and horse for hire. On Sunday, the 29th of July, about a quarter to seven o'clock in the morning, the prisoner, who I knew before, came, and asked if I would buy a horse - I said I would look at it; I went with him about twenty yards from my door, and saw the black gelding, which East afterwards claimed - I asked where he brought it from; he said from his brotherin-law's, Mr. Smith, at North Hyde, near Southall; he asked 9l. for it - I declined buying it; he then asked if I knew any body likely to buy it - I said a neighbour of mine, who hawked coals, wanted an old horse; I went with-him, but he did not buy it: I then said Cox, a horsedealer, was coming down with me at one o'clock, and he might buy it - he bought it of him for 7l.; I was present when Cox gave him 7l. all but 1s., about one o'clock on Sunday.

LUKE COX
. I am a dealer in horses, and live at Turnham-green. On the 29th of July I bought the horse of the prisoner, at Brentford, in Ward's presence, for 7l., all but 1s.; he said he had it from Smith, his brother-in-law, at North Hyde, and that Smith sent him to sell it; he asked 9l. for it - he turned it into Mr. Rodwell's field, which he had brought it out of - I found it there that afternoon; East claimed iton Monday; the prisoner was taken on Monday - I had paid for it.

JAMES SOUTH
. I am a Policeman. On Monday evening I received information that the horse was stolen, and saw it in a field at Brentford - I saw Ward, and from his information apprehended the prisoner on Monday, at Uxbridge, about three miles from East's; I asked if he had received any money from Cox for a horse on Sunday - he denied it; I took him to Ward, who gave the account he has now, in his hearing.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going by Botwell on Friday, and saw John Smith; he asked me to go to Moore's, the jobber, at Brentford, and ask him if he wanted to buy a horse - I went, and he was not at home; I returned to Smith, and he asked me to come at six o'clock on Sunday morning, and bring the horse to Ward's house; I did so, and told him Smith had a horse to sell - he gave me 5s. for my trouble.
JAMES COX. I did not see any John Smith about the house.

JAMES SOUTH. I found 10s. 7d. on the prisoner, and asked what he had done with the rest of the money he had received from Cox - he said, "Go to my wife, and ask her for what I gave her last night;" I went, and she gave me two sovereigns - I said, "Is this all you received from your husband last night?" she said No, and then brought me two sovereigns and a half.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Life .
First London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1991.
THOMAS MIST
was
charged on the Coroner's Inquisition only, with killing and slaying
Margaret Mist
.
Messrs. Pennington, Denby, and Doubleday, surgeons, having examined the body of the deceased, all agreed in opinion that her death was produced by natural causes, and not by violence.
NOT GUILTY .

1992.
JOHN BRIDLEY
was indicted for
stealing' on the 15th of August , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s., the goods of
George Clarke
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

GEORGE CLARKE. I am a shoemaker , on Ludgate-hill
. On the 15th of August, about half-past nine o'clock, while my back was turned, these shoes were taken.

WILLIAM BROWN
. I live in Whitmore-place, Hoxton, and am a shoemaker. I was in Mr. Clarke's shop on the 15th of August; he was busy - I saw the prisoner come in, and run off with a pair of shoes, which were two yards within the door; I pursued, and in Stationers'court secured him, and saw him throw them down - I held him, and brought them back.

SAMUEL COLLIER
. I live in Kirby-street, Hatton-garden, and am a professor of music. I was at the top of Stationers'-court; the prisoner ran up the court, and Brown after him - I saw him throw down the shoes, and picked them up; he was taken, and I followed him into the shop with them.

MICHAEL LYON
. The shoes were delivered to me, with the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

LEONARD COX
. I am a Policeman. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, and know him to be the man - I was present at the time - (read.)

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Life .

1993.
JAMES BURKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
Timothy Baly Roe
, from his person .

TIMOTHY BALY ROE
. I am clerk to Messrs. Helps and Co., of Cheapside. On the 12th of July, between ten and eleven o'clock in the morning, I was in Holborn
, opposite Brooke-street, and felt something at my pocket - I turned round immediately, and saw my handkerchief under the prisoner's jacket; I saw nobody with him - I attempted to seize him, but missed my hold, and he dropped the handkerchief - he got out of my sight, but the officer pursued him - I took up my handkerchief.

JAMES SLOGDEN
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner's hand in Mr. Roe's pocket - I had seen him attempt a gentleman's pocket before, and watched him; a person came in between us, and I did not see him take Mr. Roe's handkerchief out - Mr. Roe turned round to catch hold of him; he ran away; I pursued, and overtook him in Brooke-street; he said he was going to school, and not to pick pockets; but I had seen him attempt more than one pocket before - I found nothing on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not take it.
GUILTY. Aged 9.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Judgment Respited
.

1994.
THOMAS GOODMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William Aldridge
, from his person .

WILLIAM ALDRIDGE. I am a coachman , and live in Mount-street. On the 28th of August, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I was in Long-lane, Smithfield
; I did not feel my handkerchief taken till I received information - it was produced to me about two minutes afterwards, when the prisoner was secured.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I am a broker, and was in Longalley. I observed the prisoner and another following Mr. Aldridge, who had a female with him, and near the end of Long-lane I saw the other take the handkerchief out of Aldridge's pocket, and pass it behind to the prisoner, who went into a shop - I stopped Aldridge, and told him; Cadby went in, and took the prisoner; the other ran away - I took Aldridge to the shop where the prisoner was.

JOSEPH CADBY. I am a constable. I was in Longlane, with Colton; the prisoner, and another followed the prosecutor; they made several attempts; at last the other got the handkerchief out, and gave it to the prisoner, who went into a shop - I went, and took him; I found the handkerchief under his coat; I do not think I should know the other.(Property produced and sworn
Prisoner. I hope the prosecutor will recommend me to mercy.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Life .

1995.
THOMAS TURNER
was indicted for
uttering a forged request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
John Blanch
.

JOHN BLANCH. I am a gun-maker , and live in Gracechurch-street
. On the 14th of July the prisoner came to the shop with an order, purporting to come from Messrs. Lacy and Co. for two pairs of pistols, but as he was a stranger, and I was not satisfied with the hand-writing, I asked if he knew who wrote the order, he said he supposed Mr. Lacy; I then asked who gave it to him, he said a man in Camomile-street, who was to give him 1s., and he was to take the goods to him; I called in an officer, and detained him while I went to Mr. Lacy's, taking the order with me.

JOHN GEORGE LACY
. I am in partnership with Mr. Whitton. I know nothing of the prisoner, and never sent him to Mr. Blanch; this order was not written by me, or any body in our house.

JOHN KING
. I received the prisoner in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. A man in the street asked me to take the note, and he would pay me 1s.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Two Years .

1996.
HENRY DIMOND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 1 looking-glass and frame, value 30s., and 1 picture-frame, value 26s. , the goods of
James Reeves
.

JAMES REEVES. I keep a public-house in Upper Thames-street
. I cannot say that the prisoner was ever at my house; my wife who, is the principal witness, is confined to her bed; these things were missed from my parlour about four o'clock - I had seen them half an hour before.

DANIEL FORRESTER. I am an officer. On Saturday afternoon, the 14th of July, about half-past four o'clock, I was in Princes-street, Bank, and saw the prisoner with a black bag on his shoulder; another young man, who was close to him, said "Here is Forrester;" the prisoner knew me to be a constable; I let them walk into Coleman-street; the prisoner turned into White Rose-court - I turned in after him - the other then turned back and ran away; I asked the prisoner what he had got there - he said a looking-glass and painting; I asked where he got them - he said a man hired him at Shadwell to carry them to Armstrong, No. 7, Wellington-street, Old-street, and was to give him 1s. 6d.; I found a person named Armstrong in Wellington-street, Goswell-street; he was detained and I afterwards found the prosecutor.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was by Shadwell church; a person was resting there with this property, and asked me where there was a coach-stand - he asked me to carry them, and by the Mansion-house he said, "Do you know the nearest way?"
NOT GUILTY .

1997.
SARAH LANE
was
indicted for a misdemeanor . - To which she pleaded

GUILTY . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1998.
STEPHEN BROWN
was
indicted for a misdemeanour .
MR. BODKIN conducted the prosecution.

JOHN HOPKINS. I am vestry-clerk of St. Dunstan in the west
. Before April, this year, application was made by a woman calling herself Langford, for relief on behalf of two children; she said they were at Birmingham - the officers advanced her a trifle to go down and see them - it was afterwards reported that she was dead, and in June, application was made by a female, who I do not know, representing that Langford's two children were at Westminster; she summoned the parish-officers to show cause why they had not relieved the children - I attended the summons before Alderman Wilson, and the first person I saw at Guildhall, was Mrs. Langford, who had been represented as dead; I also saw the woman who had summoned me, and at Guildhall, the woman said her name was not Langford, but I am sure she is the woman who had applied by that name; the children not living in our parish, the Magistrate said they must be removed by the parish of Westminster - on the 3rd of July, they were removed into our parish from Westminster, by an order which I have; it describes them as Ann Langford, aged eight, and George Langford, aged four - another person came with them, as their relative; and on or about the 11th of July, the woman who had received the money to go to Birmingham, and who I knew as Langford, came, and Mr. Thomas, one of the overseers, offered to take them into the workhouse, as they were orphans; but she said their uncle, who was going to Edinburgh, or Glasgow, would take them, if the parish would give him money to enable him to take them, and they would be no further expence to the parish - she was desired to bring the uncle the next morning, when the overseers would very likely comply; she took the children away, and next morning the prisoner came, accompanied by Langford, and the prisoner stated to Mr. Thomas, that if the parish officers would give him 30s., he would take them to Scotland, and they should be no further expense - he described himself as their uncle, and in consequence of that, 30s. were given him; he was brought to Guildhall by the name of Brown - he would not acknowledge to that name at first, but did afterwards; he was asked if the receipt, which I had seen him sign for the 30s., in the name of Dixon, was his hand-writing, and denied it, but the following week, when he was under examination, he admitted that it was his writing.

ROBERT THOMAS
. In July last I was one of the overseers of St. Dunstan in the west. On the 11th of July the children were removed to our parish, by this order; we offered to take the children into the workhouse; the woman objected, as she said their uncle would take them to Edinburgh, if we advanced the money; that he was a linendraper, and was well off - she wished to have the money that evening - we told her to call next morning; I was in attendance next morning, and saw the prisoner - he said he was the uncle of the children, and a shoemaker, at Westminster; we put some questions to him, as to the propriety of their going, and asked what money was necessary; he said 30s. or 2l. - 30s. was advanced to him, and he signed this receipt; the woman, who had been the night before, and called herself Leech, said the children's parents were both dead, and died at Birmingham; that woman had before called herself Langford; when the prisoner was apprehended, he said the receipt was not his writing, but in the following week he said it was his writing, that his name was Brown and not Dixon; the woman who has pleaded guilty, by the name of Lane, is the woman I have been speaking of.

JOHN PONTIFEX
. I am a vestry-clerk of St. Andrew, Holborn. Lane, who has pleaded guilty, applied to our parish by the name of Elizabeth Palmer, for relief, on the27th of July, 1832, for two children, whom she represented as the children of Langford, deceased, and stated herself to be their aunt; one of them, Mary, was nine years old, and John four - she said the parents were dead, and she was their maternal aunt; from her statement, we believed the children were legally settled on our parish - she wanted 30s. to send them to Exeter, representing that they had an uncle there, who would take care of them, and free the parish from any further burthen; our parish made some inquiries before we advanced the money, and discovered a woman, named Catherine Lane; we got her to the office when Farmer came again - she had represented to me that the child's parents were married at Bermondsey; I had the certificate of the marriage with me, in the name of Lane, and not Langford, in consequence of what she had stated to our beadle - when she came, she represented herself as Elizabeth Farmer, and that Sarah Lane, mentioned in the certificate, was her sister - she had at first referred me to the church for the certificate, in the name of Langford; after she made this statement, I introduced her to Catherine Lane, who said,"Ah, Sarah, how do you do?" she said, "I am not Sarah, I am Sarah's twin sister;" Catherine Lane said,"You know, Sarah, you never had a sister;" she then admitted she was the Sarah Lane mentioned in the marriage certificate.
Q. When did the beadle take her into custody? A. It was on the 7th of August.
COURT. Q. Then this was after Brown's appearance at St. Dunstan's parish? A. Yes, but before his examination; he was not taken till Farmer had appeared once or twice.

JOHN BUCKMASTER
. In July last, I was an overseer of St. Andrew's, and remember on a Friday, the female coming for relief about three children, and on the following day, the prisoner came to my place with her; she represented herself as Elizabeth Farmer, and introduced him as her husband; he confirmed her intention of taking the two children to Exeter; he said he was her second husband, and that she was the sister of the children's mother - he said nothing about the parents being dead; they were spoken of generally as orphans.

Prisoner. Q. Did I represent myself as her husband? A. She introduced him as such, and he did not contradict it; she referred to him to know if he had a letter to his friends at Exeter - he felt in his pocket; and said No, he had not got it about him, but would go and get it from home.

CATHERINE LANE
. The prisoner Lane, who has pleaded guilty, married my brother, John Lane, and had four children by him, who are all dead; I saw them all in their coffins - they have been dead nine or ten years - she never had a sister; I never saw the prisoner, and never knew him as a relation.

THOMAS LIFFORD SMART
. I am vestry clerk of St. Botolph, Bishopsgate. The prisoner Lane came to our parish on the 4th of August, in the name of
Elizabeth Brown
, and brought three children, by order of removal; they are described as, Mary, aged nine years, John, four years, and William, one year, all lawful children of John and
Jane Farmer
, deceased - she said she was the mother's sister, and stated how the children were settled on our parish, and that she and her husband were going to Plymouth on the Wednesday following, and if we would give her 50s. to pay expenses, and clothing, we should hear nothing further of them - I promised to consider it, and she was to call again on the Tuesday; she did not come - on the 10th of August, in the morning, the prisoner called on me, and said he was the husband of the woman who came with the children, and gave his name as Brown; he brought this letter, which he said was from his wife, who had sprained her ancle, and could not get out - I told him to call in the evening; he said he had a deal to do, and could not he have the money then, as he was anxious to go hi journey - I gave him no reason to suppose I suspected him- I had made inquiry, and told him to call in the evening, which he did, and I read the letter openly before him and twenty gentlemen; I questioned him, and he was taken into custody - he said he got the letter from his wife - I asked where - he said she sent it to him, and he could not tell where from; I had found out that his wife, as he called her was in custody at the time - (the letter was as follows).
To - Smart, Esq., vestry clerk:-

SIR, - The bearer is my husband, and most proper to see the gentlemen, as he has protected the children since the death of the parents, and is going to take them with us on Sunday; I sprained my uncle, which prevents my attending - my husband will give you every satisfaction of taking the children off your hands, for the sum I proposed.
7, Oakley-street, Lambeth. E. BROWN.

MARY GEORGE
. I am the wife of Abel George, a serjeant in the Guards; I live in Smith's-rents, Westminster, and have two male children, one two years old, and the other five. The female prisoner Lane, came twice to my house, asked leave to take my children a walk; it was in July- she took them out between ten and eleven o'clock in the morning, and kept them till the evening; I only remember it being done twice.

ABEL GEORGE
. I remember Lane taking my children out three times; I am not positive of more - I was not always at home - she said she was going to see about some private property which was left her, and took the children while my wife washed; she said she had a boy in some school in the City, as his father was a citizen.

Prisoner's Defence. I must say several witnesses have been examined on my trial, who have nothing to do with the case; they are more against the female than against me - the acts I admit some of, but I am in other respects innocent; I was the bearer of the letter, but I expressed no anxiety to obtain the money.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 12.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1999.
WILLIAM STEELE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of July , 1 shovel, value 3s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. , the goods of
William Mears
. - To which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Two Months .

2000.
JAMES MURRAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 80 yards of canvas, value 4l.; 4 skeins of twine, value 2s. 4d., and 18 biscuits, value 6d., the goods of
William Henry Harton
, and others .
MR. GURNEY conducted the prosecution.

JOHN AYLOTT
. I am foreman to Messrs. Mc Culloch; Mr. William Henry Harton is one of the partner s. On the 8th of August, I left their premises at Limehouse
all secure at six o'clock, and every thing locked up; I went the next morning, found the warehouse broken open, and on examining, found several cases open - I missed some canvas, and some twine and biscuits; the prisoner had worked on the premises, but left two or three months before.
Prisoner. I never worked on the premises, nor saw this witness. Witness. I am quite sure he had been employed there by Mr. Wright, who takes the work by contract.

WILLIAM JAMES PEARCE
(Police-constable K 177). On the morning of the 9th of August, about 3 o'clock, I saw the prisoner by the side of Limehouse-cut, which is a branch of the river Lee - I observed a bundle under his arm; he walked rather quickly - I asked what his bundle contained; he said twine and biscuit, which he had brought from Gravesend; I called another Policeman, and the prisoner sprang into the water - the other Policeman found this quantity of canvas, about twelve yards from the spot, but the prisoner had not that when I saw him - in about two hours after I saw the prisoner again near the same spot, wholly immersed in the water, except his head - seeing he was discovered he endeavoured to escape, but I leaped into the water, swam across, and took him getting up the bank on the other side; when I saw him he was about two hundred yards from the prosecutors' warehouse.

JOHN ROBERTS
(Police-constable K 53). I was called to assist Pearce, and found this canvas twenty or thirty yards from the place; this twine was just by where he leaned into the water.

GEORGE CASTLEMAN
(Police-constable K 236). I found this other roll of canvas on the side of the water, near Limehouse church - I do not know where the prisoner jumped into the water.

MR. AYLOTT. This is our canvas - I know it by the number on it, No. 7, and here are two bolts of it, which are what we missed - this twine is the same description as what we lost; I suppose we lost four or six skeins.

WILLIAM HENRY
HARTON. I am one of the partners of the firm of Messrs. M'Culloch and Co. This is made by the same makers, Neilson and Co., and is the same No. 7 as the bolts of canvas which we lost - I am almost sure I have seen the prisoner on the premises; Mr. Wright, the rigger, has employed him.

Prisoner's Defence. I could not have rigged a ship by myself, and if I have been there to work let them bring forward a man to show it - I went down on the 8th of August to his Majesty's ship Dispatch to get employ, but she was full-handed - I stopped, and had dinner on board, at Gravesend - I got some biscuits, and came up by a Milton barge; I found that twine laying down - I took it up, put it under my arm, and walked on with my biscuits in my hand - I met a Policeman, who spoke to me, and let me walk on - I then came to another, and he asked me what I had got; I told him some biscuits - he drew out his staff; I, being in liquor, was alarmed, jumped into the water to make my escape; I got into the mud, and could hardly get out again - when I got out I gave myself up.

WILLIAM JAMES PEARCE
. He was quite sober, and I did not draw my staff at all.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2001.
JAMES FARLEY
and
JOHN HAY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
David Price
, from his person .

DAVID PRICE. I live in Tower Royal, and am a clerk . On the 27th of july I was on the Pavement, near Finsburysquare
- I missed my handkerchief, which was safe about ten minutes before, when I was in Coleman-street.

ANDREW GRIMES
. I am the son of
Martin Grimes
- he lives in Broad Arrow-court. On the 27th of July I was on the Pavement, near Finsbury - I saw Farley lift up the gentleman's coat, take out the handkerchief, and give it to Hay, who went down a street, across the road - Hay put it into his hat; the prisoners then met together again - Farley had been a school-fellow of mine; I had seen Hay in Milton-street.
Farley. He said at the office he could not see what was taken out. Witness. I could not see at the time, but when he got across the road I saw it was a handkerchief; he held it up in his hand.

ROBERT BARRELL
. I was with Grimes on Finsbury Pavement; I saw Farley take up the gentleman's pocket, and take something out, but I could not see what it was; he gave it to Hay; I had known Farley before.

Hay. He first said I took it, and when Farley was brought in, in two or three hours afterwards, he said it was him. Witness. Yes, I did; they were both there, but I was mistaken in the person who took it.

MATTHEW PEAK
(Police-constable G 198.) I took the prisoners at the corner of Whitecross-street; they denied knowing any thing about it.
Hay's Defence. I had left home, and was going towards Whitecross-street - I can prove I was at home at the time of the robbery, and did not go out till eight o'clock the next morning.
MR. PRICE re-examined. Q. What time was it you lost your handkerchief? A. At a quarter before nine o'clock on the evening of Friday, the 27th of July.

FRANCES HAY
. I am the prisoner's mother; I live at No. 1, Copthall-chambers, Throgmorton-street - I have the care of them; no one lives there but me and my family. On Friday night, to the best of my recollection, my son was at home from a little after eight o'clock, and not out till eight the next morning - he slept there, and the next morning he was taken; it was not nine when he came in; it was not much after eight - I looked at the clock when he came in; the clock is up stairs, on the first floor - I sit in the kitchen; I recollect going up to look at the clock; I held up the candle to look - I could not see without a candle.

FRANCES HAY
, JUN. I am Hay's sister - I went to the chambers in Copthall-court to live, on the 25th of July, and have lived there ever since. On last Friday five weeks the prisoner was at home at eight o'clock in the evening, and did not go out till the next morning - I recollect the time perfectly well, for I was going out myself, and I was at Mile-end by nine; I went out a little after eight, and was at home after nine o'clock - he had not been out, I am sure- I was in the kitchen, with my mother, when he came home; the candle was lighted about dusk, about seven -I had noticed the time, as I had an appointment at eight, and was waiting for my brother to come home, to stop with my youngest sister, and he came in at eight, or two orthree minutes after - I had gone up to see the time by a dial in one of the offices on the ground floor; there is no clock on the first floor; it is on the ground floor, in one of the offices.
MRS. HAY. The clock was on the first floor.

FARLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Months .

HAY -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2002.
WILLIAM DAVIS
and
WILLIAM AUSTIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July
, 2 coats, value 4l.; 1 handkerchief, value 5s., and 1 ring, value 10s., the goods of
Edward Harvey Maltby
, Esq .; and that Davis had been before convicted of felony .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

EDWARD HARVEY MALTBY. I am a barrister , and have chambers in Paper-buildings, in the Temple
. On the 2nd of July I went from town, to attend the Buckingham Quarter-sessions - I left Garton, my clerk, in my chambers; I had in my chambers some dress-coats, a mourning ring for Dr. Parr, a silk handkerchief, and some other things - I think I had seen these things safe about two days before I left town, which was about seven days before they were taken.

GEORGE KINGSTON GARTON
. I am clerk to the prosecutor - I remember his going out of town; I live in John-street. I went to dinner about half-past four o'clock on the 4th of July - I left the drawers and every thing in the chambers safe; I know these dress-coats, and other articles were safe; I had seen the coats that morning - I returned at six, and found the outer door shut, as I had left it, but the inner door was open - all the locks had been broken, the things taken out of the drawers, and one or two of the drawers were pulled completely out.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Were these articles under lock and key? A. Yes; I had left the key of the drawers in a little drawer.

MARIA KAMPTON
. I am now living with my friends; I have left the course of life I was in - I was an unfortunate girl; I was acquainted with the prisoner Austin - he was a clerk in the East India-house; I heard him say he had been a clerk before, but I do not know to what - he came to live with me at my lodging in York-square; he came there the beginning of June, a little before Greenwich fair - I afterwards lived with him at Harrison-street, Gray's Inn-lane, and at Easton-street, Clerkenwell; when we lived at Harrison-street, I pawned a coat for him with a velvet collar, at Mr. Loveday's in Gray's Inn-lane - I knew Davis while I lived in Harrison-street; I had never seen him before - he gave me a coat to pawn at the same time that Austin did; that had not a velvet collar - the prisoners were together when they gave me the coats; they took them out of the house, and gave them to me in the street - they had brought them into the house: one of the coats was tied up in a green silk handkerchief, but I do not know which - I received a mourning-ring about three weeks afterwards, at the Cheshire Cheese, publichouse, to pawn; I looked at the name on it, but could not tell what it was - it was after that that Davis and two other men went with me to the public-house, and the officer came and took us; when I went to Hatton-garden, I told what I have stated now.

Cross-examined. Q. But you never said any thing about it till the pawnbroker had identified you as the person? A. I did not know they had been stolen - I did not make the statement to save myself; Mr. Newton taxed me with it, and said I had better tell what I had done - I was frightened; I never was in trouble before, but I stated what was true - I have gone by the name of Jager, and Austin told me that his name was Copeland, and authorized me to go by that name; Mr. Jager has been transported - I have gone by the name of Bouverie and Knapp; I lived with a tradesman of that name - some people have called me James; I never went by the name of Briant - people have called me Sidworth, but I never gave my name as that; I went by that name when I lived in Lancaster-street - I never went by the name of Bland: my sister has gone by that name - I have not had another friend of mine transported; I was taken once for being out late, but I positively swear I never was taken on a charge of felony - I have worked at dress-making; I have been in town ten years - I was getting my living in the street when I lived in Lancaster-street; I was there four or six months - I had before that worked for my living, but when I had no work, I was obliged to go in the street: when I went to Easton-street, Austin told me to take a lodging, and he would pay for it - I went by the name of Bouverie when I lived in York-square; I used then to work when I had it to do, but I had not been there long before Austin spoke to me; when I first came to London I lived with my aunt, who was a dressmaker: I did not live with her long - Hollman, Smith, and Davis were with me when I was taken; I was not at home when the coats were brought to Harrison-street; I did not see them brought; Smith and a female he lived with lived in that house, and I believe no one else but the landlady - I know it was in July that the prisoner took the coats from the house, but I cannot say what time, only I know I was not there in June, and these coats were brought about a week before I left, but I cannot say when I left; the coats were wrapped up when I received them, and it was candle-light - Austin told me that the coat he gave me had a velvet collar, and I was to ask 30s. for that; I did not see them till they were opened at the pawnbroker's- I had never pawned any coats before.
COURT. Q. Neither of the coats had been in wear to your knowledge, in Harrison-street? A. No.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. How long had you been out before they were given to you? A. Two or three hours -Austin came to me, and asked if I would go and pawn his coat for him, as he wanted some money, and Davis said,"Perhaps you will take mine at the same time;" I do not recollect when it was, but I was only there a fortnight altogether - I never lived but with three men; I sometimes took their names - Mr. Jager was a boot and shoemaker, a respectable tradesman; I believe he was transported because a parcel was taken from a cart, and found on him - I was not taken up for that.

JOHN ABETHEL
. I am in the employ of Mr. Loveday, a pawnbroker, in Gray's Inn-road. Kampton pawned these two coats with me on the 7th of July; one of them is in a green silk handkerchief, and has a velvet collar - she asked30s., I think, for that, and I lent 1l. 6s., and on the other 13s. - she told me her name was
Maria Jager
, and she brought them for Thomas Williams.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen her before? A. Yes, she had pawned a coat about a week before, in the name of Copeland, I think.

JOHN DAVIES
. I am in the employ of Mr. Corwell, a pawnbroker, of Exmouth-street. Kampton pawned this mourning-ring with me for 8s. on the 10th of July, in the name of Ann Cook.(Property produced and sworn to.)

ANN COPE
. I live at No. 14, York-street. Maria Bouverie (Kampton) lived with me three months; Austin used to call on her - I do not know Davis: I believe Austin has staid all night - Maria used to pay the rent; she told me Austin gave her the money to pay - she left the latter end of June, but I was not at home then.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you used to see a great many gentlemen there? A. No, she never had many persons there - my husband has been a gentleman's servant -Maria came to me as a young person who took in needle-work; I know one young man used to come to see her - I never knew her out late: there were two other young men used to call, but no one staid all night but Austin, and I cannot swear that he did.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did you know him go away at night, or in the morning? A. I have seen him go away at night.

ELIZA MILLER
. I live in Harrison-street, Gray's Inn-lane. Maria lodged with me a fortnight; she came on the 29th of June, and left on the 13th of July; Austin has been there to her, but not Davis; I never saw either of the prisoners bring any thing there - Maria and another woman took my apartments for themselves and their husbands; I only know the names of Austin and Copeland -I never was paid at all: Austin staid there all night.

MARY SMITH
. I live at No. 7, Easton-street. Maria lived a fortnight at my house, up to the time she was taken; Austin lived with her - she took the lodging in the name of Copeland; Austin was there five days, and used to sleep there.

WILLIAM SPRINGATE
(Police-constable E 123). I apprehended Austin on the 19th of July - he, Smith, and Davis, were all standing together at the corner of Verulam-buildings; I went up to them - they separated; I thought their manner was very suspicious, and in the course of the same night I took Austin, and on the 23rd I took Davis, in company with Hollman, Smith, and Maria; I told Davis I took him for lurking about Gray's Inn - we went and found some duplicates at Maria's lodging; I know nothing of the duplicates of the coats and ring, but we inquired, and found them.

JOHN NEWTON
(Police-constable E 32). I apprehended Austin on the 17th of August, in Shire-lane, near the Temple, and he was let out on bail - I took him in a common brothel; I did not say any thing to him about what had happened at the Temple, but he knew what I took him for, and asked who had told me where he was -I said I should decline telling him; I have known him two years - I knew Davis; I had seen them together very often in July, and for eighteen months before; they frequented Sion-terrace, near Judd-street.

Cross-examined. Q. Upon your oath, do not you know that Austin has not left his ship fifteen months? A. When I first knew him he lived in Cromer-street, it must be nearly two years ago - I have not the exact date, but I have known him a long time.

JOHN CORRAN
. I am warden of the Inner Temple. I have seen the two prisoners go through at various times; I saw them together about June and July, and sometimes apart - I remember Mr. Maltby's chambers being robbed; I had seen them lately before that.

ISAAC SPREADBOROUGH
(Police-constable D 10.) I produce a certificate of the former conviction of Davis, which I got from Mr. Clark's office - I was present at the trial, and know he is the person.

DAVIS -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

AUSTIN -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

2003.
WILLIAM AUSTIN
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June
, 1 watch, value 20s. , the goods of
Philip James Chabot
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

MARY WHEELER
. I am laundress to Mr. Chabot, of New-square, Lincoln's Inn
. On the 12th of June I left the chambers safely locked up, and in the morning when I came I missed the different articles of plate in common use - I also missed a watch, which used to hang over the mantel-piece in Mr. Chabot's sitting room.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Had any one the care of those chambers but you? A. No. and I left them safe on Whit-Tuesday.

MARIA KAMPTON
. Austin brought a watch to me about the middle of June, while I was living at Mr. Cope's - it hung over the mantel-piece for three or four days; he then had it himself - when I lived in Easton-street he gave it to me to pawn, and told me to ask 1l. on it; they offered me 10s. - I went back to him at the Cheshire Cheese, and he told me to go to the corner of Wilson-street with it; they there lent 14s. on it, which I gave to him.

Cross-examined by MR LEE. Q. When did you begin to live with him? A. The beginning of June, about Whitsuntide; I did not live with him more than ten weeks altogether - he had but very few things there; he said he lodged over the water; I pawned the watch after the coats and the ring - I had no suspicion that these articles were stolen; I pawned them in different names, but they were the names he told me - I had seen Austin's brother and sisters, and they and he all appeared very respectable.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did Austin go out at the time that clerks do? A. Yes; I pawned the watch in the name of Copeland; I did not know him by the name of Austin.

JOHN SPENCER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have the watch, pawned by Maria, in the name of Copeland, for 14s., on the 14th of July.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you known her before? A. No, but I am certain she is the person.

ANN COPE
