. Maria lodged at my house for some time; she had no watch when she first came, but I afterwards saw a silver watch in her bed-room; Austin was in thehabit of coming there backwards and forwards - they left the latter end of June.

PHILIP JAMES
CHABOT. My chambers are in Lincoln's Inn New-square. This watch is mine - I missed that, and a quantity of plate.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2004.
JOHN HOLLMAN
and
JAMES SMITH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of July , 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 5 handkerchiefs, value 10s.; 2 shirts, value 2l., and 4 sovereigns, the property of
George Edward Baker
; 1 pair of boots, value 10s.; 2 watches, value 4l.; 2 coats, value 10l.; 2 rings, value 10s., and 2 waistcoats, value 1l., the goods of
Thomas William Flavell
, in the dwelling-house of the said
Thomas William Flavell
,
George Edward Baker
, and
George Pyke
; and that the said
John Hollman
had been before convicted of felony .

GEORGE OAKLEY. I am an inspector of Police division E. On the 23rd of July I apprehended the prisoners in the Cheshire Cheese, Mount-pleasant; I found on Hollman this waistcoat, and on Smith this pair of boots - Mr. Baker was with me, and claimed the waistcoat; the prisoners said it was theirs.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Who was there at the time? A. Davis and Maria.

WILLIAM SPRINGATE
(Police-constable E 123.) I went with the inspector, and took these boots from Smith's legs - I was in Gray's Inn on the 2nd of July, and saw Hollman against the door opposite No. 14, which are the prosecutors' chambers; I had seen him in the square three or four times before.

Cross-examined. Q. What enables you to fix on the 2nd of July? A. Because it is the day the robbery was committed - I saw him there about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, and I heard of the robbery about twenty minutes before nine; I am quite sure I saw him that evening, but I did not know that I had seen him till I took him up - I had seen him lurking about on the 19th; I recollect the date by the Hue and Cry, in which all robberies are inserted.

COURT. Q. Did you see him on the 2nd? A. Yes, and on the 19th he was lurking about the square; I saw the Hue and Cry after we had taken him, about the 23rd or 24th; I know the date by the Hue and Cry; I was called up into the chambers on the night of the robbery, about half-past eight o'clock, and I had seen Hollman that night.

GEORGE EDWARD BAKER. I have chambers at No. 14, Gray's Inn-square
- I have two friends, who reside there, Mr. Flavell and Mr.
George Pyke
- we jointly pay the rent, and reside there as a dwelling-house. I left the chambers at a quarter before eight o'clock on the 2nd of July, leaving Mr. Pyke there; when I returned, at nine o'clock, I found Mr. Flavell had returned - Springate and another Policeman were there; there was a complaint that the chambers had been robbed; the outer door seemed to have been opened by a key, and the inner door was broken - I missed a waistcoat, four sovereigns, five silk handkerchiefs, and two shirts; and three 5l. notes were left on the floor - Mr. Flavell lost two watches, some mourning-rings, and a pair of boots; I know the waistcoat to be mine, and these boots to be his.
Cross-examined. Q. Are these chambers held from the society of Gray's Inn? A. No, we hold them of Adlington and Co. - I was not the last person in before the robbery.

THOMAS PORTER
. I am in the service of a bootmaker in Covent-garden. These boots are Mr. Flavell's - I repaired them for him.

Cross-examined. Q. What do you know them by? A. By the letter C near the instep, which shows the currier the leather was bought of, and it is my own mark - I gave them out to be new footed by one of our men; I know they are the same.

THOMAS WILLIAM FLAVELL
. These are my boots - I lost them about the 2nd of July; I had worn them two or three times after they came home.

THOMAS GOODYEAR
(Police-constable E 39). I have a certificate of the conviction of Hollman in January, 1831- I got it at Mr. Clark's office; I was present at the trial, and know he is the man.

GEORGE PYKE
. Mr. Baker, Mr. Flavell, and myself jointly occupy the chamber in Gray's Inn-square; it is extra parochial, and pays no poor-rates.
Witnesses for the Defence.

EDWARD CURTIS
. I am a bricklayer, and live at Notting-dale, Kensington. I know Hollman's father; he has worked as a carpenter for me; on the 2nd of July, the prisoner Hollman came there with him, between 6 and 7 o'clock in the evening, as near as I can say - I am sure it was not later than seven; I know it was the 2nd of July, because I paid his father on the 3rd., 10s. for his labour, and here is his receipt - they stopped all night on the 2nd of July, and left me about ten o'clock on the 3rd.

COURT. Q. Where does Hollman's father live? A. I think about Kentish-town; I do not know exactly - I have a wife and four children; my wife is not here, she is ill -I have two rooms in my house; I went to bed, and the prisoner and his father slept in the next room; I have two beds in one room, and one in the other; two children slept with me - my eldest, who is a girl, and the next, which is a boy, slept with the prisoner and his father, in a turn-up bedstead about six feet long, and four feet six wide - the prisoner and his father did not go home, because I wanted my cart mended the next day; I cannot write - Hollman's father wrote this receipt - they began to work at my cart that night about seven o'clock, as soon as they came, and worked as long as they could see, and finished it the next morning.

RICHARD HOLLMAN
. I am the prisoner's father. I recollect going with him to Curtis' on the 2nd of July; I live at Camden town, but we did not start from there, but from the bottom of Oxford-street, about five o'clock, and got to Curtis' between six and seven o'clock; we went there to repair a cart, and returned the next day - we got to Oxford-road about eleven o'clock.

COURT. Q. What, were you an hour and a half walking to Kensington? A. No, we stopped and had something to drink; we started from No. 31, Crown-street -Hubic, my daughter, lived there, and I called there to say where I was going; I met my son there - he did not live with me; we stopped at a public-house when we got to Tyburn-gate; it was on the right-hand side - I do not know the sign; we then went on to Notting-dale,and got there about half-past six o'clock - I expected to finish the job by the time it was dark; we stopped there that night - there was plenty of room; I did not undress, nor my son either - the children slept at the bottom of the bed, with their feet to ours; we did not go to bed till eleven o'clock, or a little after, and got up at three - we had bread and cheese, and beer; the cart wanted a new tail-board, a new bottom and sides - the shafts were very good; the cart was about three feet six inches wide', and four feet in length - the timber was there, and we took our tools; we finished about ten o'clock the next day - I do not know where my son lodged at that time; it was on a Monday we went.

JOSHUA EVERETT
. I am a carpenter, and live in Bath-court, Cold Bath-square. I have known Smith from a child; I had occasion to go to Mile-end, to get some stuff, about the 10th of July, and as I came back I met Smith in Whitechapel - I had not seen him before for two or three months; he asked me if I could tell him where to get a pair of boots - I told him in Petticoat-lane; I went there with him, and saw him purchase a pair of one of those Jews who sell them; I then left him, and went up to Hampstead, where I work; I cannot tell whether these are the boots or not.

WILLIAM SPRINGATE
re-examined. Q. You have heard the evidence - now are you sure it was on the 2nd of July, that you saw Hollman in Gray's Inn-square? A. I am quite sure it was the night the robbery was committed; I had seen him three or four times before, but not again till the 19th.

HOLLMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Life .

2005.
LEWIS TREBOUT
the younger, was
indicted for stealing, on the 12th of August , 50 pieces of brass gas fittings, value 10s.; 50 brass tops, value 10s.; 50 plumbing blocks, value 10s.; 50 pieces of brass pipe, value 10s., and 50 pieces of copper pipe, value 10s., the goods of
Henry Houldsworth
and another .

TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating them to belong to
Lewis Trebout
, the elder, and other persons.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

EDWARD WARNER FIDLER
. I was agent to Mr. Lewis Trebout, and was taking care of his premises at Tottenham
; there were a number of brass fittings there - the greater part of them were loose on the floor, the others were, I believe, fixed to the shaft; the prisoner is Mr. Trebout's son; the building was not used at all in August; in that month I missed a number of these things - the prisoner lived at Scotland-green, Tottenham; he had no authority, that I know of, to take any of this property - I do not know how much has been taken away.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is the signature to this letter Mr. Trebout's writing? A. Yes; I have been dismissed from the service since this transaction, by Mr. Brett, who has been on bad terms with me.

NATHANIEL CHURCHILL
. I have been a gentleman's servant, but am now out of place - I live at Tottenham. I applied to the prisoner for employ, and he employed me to work in the garden adjoining the factory - on the 26th of July I was working there; he came to me in the evening, and told me to meet him at the gate, at half-past eight o'clock - I met him; he had a sack under his arm - he unlocked the back part of the factory, took me up stairs into the factory, and he put one end of some gas-pipe into the sack, and told me to put the other end in - I do not remember any being put into a basket; he came to me again on the 7th of August, about half-past nine o'clock at night, and told me to take a sack to Mr. Glover, the horsekeeper at the Red Lion, and to tell him that he should be there in half an hour - he told me the horse-keeper was to empty the sack, and I was to bring the sack back; I do not know what was in it - it was some sort of metal, and not very light; I saw the horse-keeper turn it out - it was some brass pipe and some gas-pipe; when I went back he sent me with another parcel, and when I got there with that, he came and ordered the horse-keeper to pack it up in a sack - the prisoner wrote a direction, and gave it to the horse-keeper, who gave it to me to tie on the sack - I cannot read, and do not know what it was; I tied it on the sack - the horse-keeper told me to wait till the errandcart came, and when it came I brought the sack out, and put it on the shafts of the cart; the prisoner was not there then, but he ordered the horse-keeper to put it on the errand-cart.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you known him long? A. No, not till I went to work in his garden - I never saw his father; the pipes were not fixed, but laying loose about on his floor.

BENJAMIN ROCHESTER
. I drive a cart from Enfield to London. I received a sack, with some metal in it, at the Red Lion, on the 8th of August, between ten and eleven o'clock - it was directed to Mr. King, No. 13, Mark-street, Paul-street, Finsbury - I carried it there; Mr. King took it in; Churchill and the horse-keeper gave it to me.

JOHN FOWLER
. I am a constable of Tottenham. I went with Forster to Mr. King's, No. 13, Mark-street, Finsbury, on the 13th of August - I saw a hamper in the front room, but it was empty; I went into the back room, and King's wife followed me; I there found some brass, which I produce - the prisoner was in the front room, at tea, with King and his family.

NATHANIEL CHURCHILL
re-examined. Q. Are these such things as were put into the sack on the 7th of August? A. No, they are not.
JOSEPH FORSTER. I am a constable of Tottenham. I found, up stairs at King's house, a number of brass tops belonging to gas-fittings, and other brass articles.
NATHANIEL CHURCHILL. Some of these are a great deal like the ends of the pipes that were taken.

JOSEPH FORSTER
. I found some pipes in the factory - I have fitted some of these ends to them, and they fit exactly.
MR. ADOLPHUS to NATHANIEL CHURCHILL. Q. Were all the things you put into the sack, pipes with ends, or some ends without pipes? A. Some ends without pipes.

Cross-examined. Q. Could the ends, which this gentleman says he fitted to other pipes, have belonged to the pipes you took away? A. I do not know; the chief of the things I took were pipes with ends to them; I cannot swear that these are any of the ends I took away.

JOSEPH FORSTER. I took the prisoner on the 13th ofAugust, at King's house; I read the warrant to him - he said he did not expect that; and on the 18th, when I was bringing him to Newgate he said he did it on purpose to be transported, as he wished to get out of the country; and if this did not do, he would commit forgery to a great amount, for he could do it as well as any man in England.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you tell whether these are what were taken on the 7th of August? A. No; many of these ends fitted to pipes remaining on the building - the pipes to which these fitted, were not taken away.
MR. FIDLER. The manufactory and the property in it belonged to Mr. Trebout, Sen.

COURT. Q. How came the prisoner to take charge of the garden? A. By consent of his father; he applied to me for part, and I would not let him have it - his father has had the premises for twenty years; these gas-fittings were not used in his business - they were in the lacemaking business about three years ago, and since then they have become useless - I live close by, and had a power of attorney to take care of the premises; there are some fields at the back of the premises to which persons may have access, but not to these premises - I supplied the prisoner with 10s. a week by his father's order, but I deducted 4s. a week out of it for the garden, which was worth a great deal more; he could get a good living by the garden - it was full of fruit; his father ordered me to give him 4l. more - I did not give it him at one time.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know of any gates being taken away? A. No; that I swear.
NOT GUILTY .

2006.
NATHANIEL GRIFFITHS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 1 pair of trousers, value 10s., the goods of
Thomas Griffiths
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

THOMAS GRIFFITHS. I am a carpenter
, and live in Whitmore-road, Hoxton
. The prisoner is my son; he has been employed a little at my business, but not much- he lodged in my house; I missed a pair of trousers on the 21st of July, from the room he and his brother slept in - these are them.

Prisoner. I did not steal them - he lent them me to wear; he murdered my mother; when I came out of the House of Correction, I wanted a little money to go to a place, and he told me to go and steal. Witness. No, I never did - I never lent him the trousers; he might have taken them unknown to me.

JAMES LEVICK
. I live at Hoxton, and am a pawnbroker. I have the trousers, which were pawned by the prisoner on the 21st of July, and on the 28th he came and had another shilling on them; he gave his own name and address.

WILLIAM EPPS
(Police-constable N 63). The prosecutor called me to his house on the 1st of August - I found the prisoner and his brother there; I took charge of them; in going along, I said to the prisoner, that it was a pity - he said he knew he had robbed his father, and he would do so again, for he ought to keep him.

GEORGE DUNCAN
(Police-constable N 59). I was called in; I found five duplicates on the brother, but none on the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I came home from work, and there was nobody at home; I went by Mr. Barrows' beershop, and saw my father in the bar - I then went past again, and Mrs. Barrows said to me, "Nathaniel, your father is asleep in our room;" I then went and took a walk, and when I came back, he was asleep on the step of the door; I shook him, but he did not awake; I went and took a walk again till eleven o'clock - my father had just then gone in doors - I went to go in, but he shoved me out, and shut the door in my face; he is not worthy the name of a father.

THOMAS GRIFFITHS
. It is false; I provided him with clothes as well as I could; I work as a carpenter; he was employed at the saw-mills, but was discharged for getting drunk and keeping bad company; he got all my things almost.

GEORGE KEMP
(Police-constable N 82). I have a certificate of the former conviction of the prisoner, which I got from Mr. Clark's office; I attended the trial, and know he is the man - he was imprisoned three months.

GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2007.
JOHN DUIG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 13 shirts, value 2l.; 6 waistcoats, value 1l.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 1l.; 9 cravats, value 1l., and 1 trunk, value 8s. , the goods of
Frederick Davey Cooper
.

FREDERICK DAVEY COOPER
. I live in Guildford-street, and am a medical student ; I send my linen to my father, at Bury St. Edmond's, to be washed. On the 3rd of August I employed a man to fetch my box of linen from the Golden Cross, Charing-cross
; he did not return with it, but I met him in Guildford-street the same night, and gave him into custody - it was not the prisoner; he said he had lost the box; it contained all the articles stated, and a letter containing some money.

THOMAS MOORE
. (Police-constable E 16.). I produce some articles, which I got at a pawnbroker's shop - the prisoner took them in, but did not pawn them; I took them from his hat, and one shirt was on his back - this was on the 4th of August - I asked him if the two shirts on the counter were his; he said Yes - I asked if they were marked; he said Yes - I asked him his name, and he said Edward Connelly; as I was taking him, he threw a duplicate behind him, and I found 5s. on him.

WILLIAM HOW
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shirt, pawned by the prisoner on the 4th of August, in the name of David Conner, for 4s.; it is marked F. D. C.

JOHN MURPHY
(Police-constable C 135). On the 3rd of August, Holmes, who had been sent for the box, came to me, and said he had lost it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had been out of work some time - I was told to go to London-bridge, where I should get work: on my way home I picked up these things in Holborn, near Southampton-street - I took them home, and the next morning I pawned one of these shirts, and was going to pawn two more when the officer was sent for.
NOT GUILTY .

2008.
MARGARET HAYES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 pair of stays, value 3s., and 3 handkerchiefs, value 5s., the goods of
Matthew Hart
; and that she had been before convicted of felony .

JOHN CHARLES HART
. I live with my father in Vauxhall-bridge-road
. On the 30th of July, in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner inside his shop in the act of secreting a pair of stays under her petticoats - she had not offered to buy any thing; I asked her what she was going to do with them - she denied having them, and dropped them at the same time: I am sure she was trying to conceal them, for I came into the shop about two minutes before, and watched her putting them under her petticoats; the handkerchiefs were not found till she was going to the station; when she had got three or four yards from our house they were found under her things - this shawl was found in her bosom at the station; they are all my father's - his name is Matthew.

Prisoner. It is quite false that I went to put them under my clothes - I went to look at a pair of stays; there were two young women in the shop when I went in; and when he came to me, he said if I would give him 4s. for them, he would not take me. Witness. No I did not.

JOHN BASS
(Police-constable B 4). At half-past two o'clock, on the 30th of July, I went to the shop, and took the prisoner - when we had got a few yards from the shop, I saw what I thought was a handkerchief about the lower part of her legs; I looked, and found these two handkerchiefs; I took hold of them, and pulled them down - I took this blue shawl from her at the station, and this large knife was taken from her bosom.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. As I was turning from the door these two handkerchiefs were outside, they were not in the shop.

JOHN CHARLES HART
. I missed them from the side of the door.

Prisoner's Defence. His sister came into the shop, and desired him not to take me - I offered 2s. 6d. for the stays, and he said he would have 4s., or he would prosecute me if it were only for his expences.

THOMAS GREENIN
. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, on the 31st of March, 1831, which I got from the clerk of the Westminster Session - I was present when she was convicted; she was imprisoned four months.

GUILTY . Aged 18 -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2009.
HENRY JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 coat, value 1l.; 3 pair of boots, value 20s.; 2 shawls, value 12s., and 1 pair of shoes, value 6s. , the goods of
William Hayward
.

WILLIAM HAYWARD
. I am a shoe-maker , and live at Old-ford
. On Saturday, the 27th of July, a young woman came to me; she said she came from Norwich, and she could not get a lodging - I accommodated her that night, and on the Sunday the prisoner came; he had come from Norwich as a recruit - on the Monday morning he came again, at five o'clock, and tapped at my window for the young woman; they went together - all the other recruits were passed; but the prisoner was refused, and they returned on the Tuesday morning, about five o'clock - in the course of that day, the prisoner said he was not on good terms with his mother, but he should write to her for some money to take him down to Norwich, and he asked my wife to let them remain a few days in our house; I objected to it, but at last I consented - on the Friday, he got up, and went away, without my knowledge, and I missed the property stated from my room; the young woman remained with us till he was taken - I traced the prisoner by the nails in his shoes to the Coburg-road, and there lost the track; I gave information, and on Sunday he was taken.

JOHN JOHNSTON
(Police-constable K 227). The prosecutor gave me notice of this on the 27th of July; and on the Sunday, the prosecutor's wife came and said the prisoner had sent a man for the girl to go and join him near Charing-cross; I followed that man and the girl, in private clothes, up to Field-lane, and on Saffron-hill I saw the prisoner join them, with this great coat on - I followed them some distance further; the prisoner then saw me, and ran into a public-house - I ran in, and took him with the coat on, and the shoes on his feet.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I sent a letter to the prosecutor saying I was very sorry, but if he would send a person, I would return his property; I sent the man for the young woman to tell her to take the things - I had been in the Philanthropic Institution.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2010.
JAMES JAMES
was indicted for
stealing, on 31st of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d.; 1 pair of trousers, value 7s., and 1 shirt, value 3s. 6d. , the goods of
John Constantine
.

JOHN CONSTANTINE
. I live in Colchester street
, and am a boot-closer . I lost this property on the 31st of July, from my lodgings, while I was out; I had left the things in my box - the prisoner was then gone; my handkerchief was taken from Red Lion-street, out of my hat - I had known the prisoner nine weeks; he had lodged in the same house two or three days.

THOMAS HARDING
. I had been out with the prosecutor on the 31st of July, and when I came home, about ten o'clock at night; I found my box broken open, and the property spoken of belonging to the witness, was gone; in about ten minutes the prisoner came home, and said he knew nothing about it; I then said I would go and tell my friend John - as we were going along, I saw him take something, and put it into his hat, and I went to friend John, and told him of it - the prisoner again called God to witness that he had seen nothing of it; John said, "Give him into custody," and the duplicates were found in his hat.

WILLIAM BUTLAND
. I have a handkerchief, which was pawned on the 31st of July, by the prisoner.

JOHN AARON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shirt, pawned, I believe, by the prisoner.

WILLIAM PERRY
. I live with a pawnbroker. I have a pair of trousers, pawned, I believe, by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating, that the prosecutor having to find bail for an assault, had sent him to get his clothes and pledge them; but that he had not given him all the money advanced on them.

JOHN CONSTANTINE
. I gave him the key of my box when I was taken, to get my things, as I had no money, but I did not allow him to pawn any thing.
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Weeks .

2011.
SAMUEL MAJOR
was indicted for
stealing,on the 22nd of August , 2 watches, value 2l., the goods of
Thomas Freebody
; and that he had before been convicted of felony .

THOMAS LOWNDES
(Police-constable I 51). On the 24th of August I was at Ealing, at half-past one o'clock in the afternoon - I saw the prisoner and Harvey quarrelling about some watches; the other said to the prisoner,"You stole a watch from Hammersmith" - the prisoner said, "Yes, and you stole one from Isleworth the other week;" I then took them into custody - I found nothing on Harvey, but on the prisoner I found this watch.
Prisoner. I bought it of Harvey.

THOMAS FREEBODY
. I live at Hounslow
, and am a watch and clock maker , this is my watch; I lost it out of my shop on the 22nd of August, between ten and three o'clock, but I was not in the shop - I know nothing of the prisoner; the other watch was lost the same day.

WILLIAM HOILEY
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned this watch with me on the 22nd of August.

JOHN PASCOE
(Police-constable T 19). I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office - I was at the trial and know he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Life .

2012.
FRANCIS MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , one half-crown, the money of
William Robert Syer
, from the person of
Harriet Jones
.

HARRIET JONES
. I lived at Mr. Syer's, in Tavistock-street. On the 20th of July I was sent out to buy some brandy at Mr. Watson's; I went up to the prisoner, who keeps a fruit-stall in Drury-lane
, to buy a half-penny worth of cherries; I had a half-crown in my hand - he snatched it out of my hand, put it into his trousers pocket, and ran over the way to Mr. Watson's to get change, and left a strange boy to mind his stall - I went to the public-house, and said to the publican; "If you please, that is my money" - the prisoner then drank a glass of gin, and the publican gave him 2s. 4 1/2d.; I asked the prisoner again for my money, and he said he had not got it - I then lost sight of him for six or seven minutes, and then he came back to his stall; I asked him for it again - he said he had not got it, and if I did not go away, he would knock my head off; I then told the Policeman - I have never had the half-crown since; I had the halfpenny in my hand, which I gave him.

MARY CHURCH
. I live with Mr. Wilson. I was passing at the time; I saw the prosecutrix go to the prisoner's basket about half-past nine o'clock: she asked how he sold his cherries - he said a half-penny a bunch; she took one bunch, and when she opened her hand, the prisoner snatched the half-crown out of her hand, put it into his trousers pocket and went to the public-house; she followed him, and said, "If you please, that is my money" - the prisoner said if she did not go away he would knock her down.
Prisoner. Q. Did she not go to a man who sold baked potatoes, and say she must have given it to one or other of us? A. No.

GEORGE CAREY
(Police-constable F 45). I saw a mob round the prisoner's stall; I went up and asked the prisoner how he could account for his conduct - he said he thought it was a bad one, as he had been taken in the night before - I found 2s. 4 1/2d. on him.

GUILTY . Aged 51. -
Confined Six Months .

2013.
CHARLES BOLTON
&
JAMES THOMAS BENN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 4 bottles of ginger-beer, value 8d.; 1 pottle of nuts, value 8d.; 2 ozs. weight of sweet-meats, value 4d.; 1 shutter, value 5s.; 1 plate, value 1d., and 1 tray, value 4d. , the goods of
William Cole
.

WILLIAM COLE
. I live at Hammersmith
, and am a boot and shoemaker ; my wife keeps a little shop. On the 9th of July one of my shutters was taken down and the window broken; I came down, found the glass out and the property stated gone; there was a blue-edged plate and a small tray: I went out with the officer, who called me up, and we met another officer, who advised me to go home again - I went home and found my shutter in a neighbour's garden, under some pales; I then went to bed, and was afterwards called up by Salmon, who had these two bottles, which are mine.

NICHOLAS SALMON
(Police-constable T 96). I was on duty at half-past twelve o'clock that night, and saw the two prisoners drinking ginger-beer within a few yards of the prosecutor's house - Benn then went and hid one bottle behind a post; I then went on, and met Wood, who told me of the robbery - I went back and found the bottle which I saw Benn put by the post, and one more; the other articles have not been found - the prisoners had been cracking nuts.

AGNES COLE
. I am the prosecutor's wife. We lost four bottles of ginger-beer - I know this one by a particular mark.

BOLTON -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

BENN -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

2014.
ROBERT AVERY
was
indicted for embezzlement ; and
WILLIAM CONNELL
was indicted for
feloniously harbouring, &c., the said Robert Avery .
SECOND COUNT, charging Connell with receiving part of the said property.

GEORGE LUDBROOK MAPLESTON
. I am a publican -Avery was in my employ for five weeks, as pot-boy . On the 18th of August I sent him to Mr. Rolls, in Broad-street
, with a 5l. note; he was to bring me back 25l. in silver - he never returned, and the money is all lost.

WILLIAM ROLLS
. I am a wine-merchant. On the 18th of August Avery came to me, brought a 5l. Bank note, and a note for 20l. more - I gave him 20l. in sovereigns and silver, and the 5l. note back again, for Mr. Maplestone.

JAMES CLAPSON
(Police-constable D 153.) I was on duty on the 18th of August - I heard of this, and went in pursuit of Avery for two or three days; I heard of him, but could not get him; on the Tuesday morning I heard he was taken, and on the following day I apprehended Connell - I said to him, "Poulterer, is that you?" he said,"That is not my name;" I said, "It is the name you go by - when did you see Bob?" he said, "What Bob?" I said,"Bob at the corner" - he said he had not seen him; I took him to the prosecutor, who said he did not know him; I then took him to the station - I found on these stockings, shoes, and other things; he said the next day that hehad had 4l. in gold, and 4l. in silver of Bob, and that he had bought these things; that they had been that night to Astley's, and then to the New-cut; that then they took a cab, and drove to Camberwell fair, where he went in a onehorse fly, and got robbed of the rest of the money - he did not say that he knew where Bob got the money.

JAMES ELLIS
. On the 21st of August Avery was given into my charge; I asked what he had done with his master's money - he said he had given part of it to the other lad.
Avery delivered in a petition, expressing his contrition for the offence; he received a good character.

AVERY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

CONNELL -
NOT GUILTY .

2015.
JOHN GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 24 lbs. of coffee, value 1l. 10s. , the goods of
John Ferris
.

JOHN BISHOP
. I am an officer. On the 10th of August I was in the West India-docks
- there was a waggon at the back of No. 5 warehouse; I received information, and went to it; I saw the prisoner drive it off just before I came up to it - I desired him to stop the horses, and asked if he was the carman; he said he was - I said I was come to examine it; he then said he was not the carman, but the carman was gone down the dock: I got into the waggon, and found in it a bag, containing 24 lbs. of coffee, concealed under the tilt - the prisoner then said he had picked it up, seeing it run out of a cask; I asked how he came by the bag; he said he had worn it as an apron - I was about to go up the dock with the waggon and horses, when the carman came, met me, and took charge of it; I asked if he knew the prisoner; he said No; I then took him up to the entrance, and reported it to Mr. Foy - he had this coffee weighed; the cask of coffee was taken out and reweighed, and the quantity in the bag just corresponded with that missed from the cask.

JOHN FOY
. I am superintendent of Police at the West-India-docks. On the 10th of August the prisoner was brought to me by Bishop; I examined the casks in the waggon, and one had been plundered - I had it weighed, and it wanted 24 lbs. of the original weight; this found in the bag is the same quantity and quality - I examined the carman and the prisoner, as to whether they knew one another; they said they did not, but it was proved they had loaded the waggon together - the carman went off after they had been to the office.

JOHN FERRIS
. I am the carman . It was my waggon, and I am responsible for it.

GEORGE JONES
. On the 10th of August I was at the West India-docks to receive some tierces - I saw this waggon drawn into a nook in the west wing; the waggoner went up for his pass, and the prisoner was left in care of the waggon.

JOHN ROGERS
. I am foreman in the docks. The property loaded in the waggon was what has been stated.

GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

2016.
WILLIAM HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 1 pair of boots, value 3s. , the goods of
John Andrew Belsham
.

JOHN HAYWOOD. I live with
John Andrew Belsham
, a shoemaker , in Clare-market
. On the 21st of July the prisoner came, and said he wanted a pair of shoes - I told him to take a seat; I went to call Sheppard; as I came back I saw him take a pair of half-boots, and put them under his coat - Mr. Sheppard came up; the prisoner showed him a bit of string, and said he wanted a pair of shoes of that length; he said he had not any; he went out - I told what I had seen; I was sent after him - I found him one hundred yards off - I told him to come back; he did so, and was given in charge.

WARD SHEPPARD
. This witness called me, and the prisoner wanted a pair of shoes, which I had not got - he went out; the lad gave me the information; I sent him after him, and he brought him back - these are the shoes.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2017.
JAMES JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 8 yards of Valentia, value 40s. , the goods of
John Bedward
.

THOMAS FARRANT
(Police-constable C 42.) On the afternoon of the 10th of August I saw the prisoner in company with another; I went up, and followed them to Vine-street
; the prisoner came back, stepped into the prosecutor's shop, and almost touched me as he came out; he stepped in again, and said, "Very well, Sir, I will tell him;" I thought I might be wrong in my suspicion - I looked into the shop, and there was no one there - I called to Stone, my brother officer, who took him with this valentia.

WILLIAM NOAKES
. I am in the employ of Mr.
John Bedward
, a woollen-draper . I did not know of this being taken till the officer brought the prisoner back; I know this is my master's.
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Six Months .

2018.
ANN KEEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of July , 6 spoons, value 25s., and 1 pair of sugartongs, value 5s. , the goods of
Francis Hart
.

MARY ANN HART
. I am the wife of
Francis Hart
- we lodge on a first floor in Claremont-place
; the prisoner occupied the kitchen, and so did I, for cooking and other purposes. I lost my silver spoons out of the kitchen - I taxed her with them; she denied it - she was a servant out of place.

REBECCA WARREN
. On the 16th or 17th July the prisoner came and asked my permission to leave a small box in my place - she left it there; I gave it to the prosecutor's mother.

WILLIAM ALDRIDGE
. The prisoner, on the 17th of July, pawned these sugar-tongs with me.

JOHN NESBITT
(Police-serjeant E 6). The prisoner was given to me on the 22nd of July; I gave her in charge of one of our men - she was taken before the Magistrate next day; I met Mrs. Hart's mother, and this property was given up to me.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. Between six and seven o'clock in the morning I got out of bed, and found the six spoons in my room, the duplicates, and 5s. 6d., and a half-pint bottle with some rum in it - I told the witness, and I said the owner should have them in time, but I should keep the money till she had it.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2019.
WILLIAM SMITH
and
JOSEPH PLUMMER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 57 live tame ducks, price 4l., and 44 live tame fowls, price 3l. , the property of
William Murphy
.

WILLIAM MURPHY. I deal in poultry , and live in Caroline-place, Saffron-hill
; I have a yard and stable fenced in, a few yards from my place - it has a wooden fence eight or nine feet high. On the 30th of July I had fifty-seven ducks and forty-four fowls there, in baskets, and between three and four o'clock in the morning they were all gone - it was all my stock except eleven geese; I gave notice at Newgate-market, and between eleven and twelve I was sent for, and saw some of them in possession of Bates.

JOSEPH BATES
. I am a patrol of the ward of Farringdon Within. I saw the prisoners selling chickens about the market for half their value; they sold six to a lad, and told him they had more at home - there was another person with them.

JAMES COOPER
. I go to the market for my father, and on that morning I saw the two prisoners and another person with them - they had eight fowls; they sold two to a woman for 1s. 3d., and then I bought the six at 8d. a piece; they said if I went to No. 8, Paradise-place, they would sell me thirteen more - I went there by order of the officer, and paid 4s. for six more, the officer took the prisoners.

JOSEPH SWAINSON
. Bates told me he knew where to find the prisoners; I went with him, and we sent Cooper in to bargain for the fowls, but he was not to pay for them till he brought the prisoners to a public-house where I was waiting - I then took them.

WILLIAM MURPHY
. I saw the fowls - they were mine; I got nineteen back; it has been the ruin of me and my family.
The prisoners put in a written Defence, stating that they were employed by the other person to assist in selling the poultry, which they did not know was stolen.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

PLUMMER -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

2012.
THOMAS BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Robert Cuff
, from his person .

ROBERT CUFF
. I live in Pall Mall East, and am a saddler . I was in Piccadilly
on the 3rd of September, about twelve o'clock - I did not feel any thing, but received information; I turned, and saw the prisoner about two yards from me - I missed my handkerchief, and the officer produced it immediately.

GEORGE STAPLETON
. I am a public informer. On Monday, the 3rd of September, I was passing Half Moon-street, in a gig, and saw a female in a fit; I saw the prosecutor go towards a crowd of about twelve people - the prisoner went up to him, and appeared to hustle him; I saw the prisoner take the handkerchief out of the prosecutor's pocket - I took and held him by the collar till the Policeman came and took him; he took it from his near side pocket.

ROBERT CULLY
(Police-constable C 95). I took the prisoner, and took the handkerchief, which the prisoner had dropped down; I had been there assisting the person in the fit - I took him to the station, and found a crape shawl on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was returning home about twelve o'clock on Monday night - I saw a crowd: I stood a few minutes, and the witness laid hold of me, and said I had taken the handkerchief - I denied it: another person said,"Here it is," and he said, "I suppose he has dropped it."

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2021.
GEORGE CLAYTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Daniel Bamfield
.

WILLIAM HARRIS
. I am in the employ of Daniel Bamfield, a bootmaker . On the 20th of August the prisoner was with me the whole day, employed as errand-boy - he had been employed four days; I missed him out of the shop for some time - I went out to inquire of a man selling fruit, and in consequence of what he said, I went and looked at the stock, and missed four pairs of boys' shoes; I went after him, and found him coming home - I taxed him with it, and he denied it; I called in a Policeman who found 1s. 6d. on him, and then he owned he had pawned them.

WILLIAM BROWN
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of shoes, which were pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. He was asking me all day long to buy some beer, and then I took the shoes.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Whipped and Discharged.

2062.
WILLIAM DARBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 hat, value 3s., the goods of
Edward Morris
, from his person .

EDWARD MORRIS
. I am a cooper . On the 10th of July I was passing through Bloomsbury-square
, about three o'clock in the afternoon; I had walked a great way, and being hot, I sat down at a door, and fell asleep - I was not drunk; I had my hat on when I fell asleep - a gentleman touched me on the shoulder, and said, "Where is your hat?" I felt my head, and said, "I have lost it;" he took me to the station, and there I found it.

THOMAS BATUTE
. I am a gas-lamp lighter; I was opposite where the prosecutor was sitting - I saw the prisoner take the hat off his head, and walk to the corner of King-street, where he offered it to a Jew for sale - I followed him some distance, and when I saw an officer I gave him into custody.

JAMES HAMILTON
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner in the Bull and Gate-yard; he said this hat was his own.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 57. -
Confined Three Months .

2023.
WILLIAM FOWLER
and
GEORGE GLUE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 pair of sheets, value 3s. , the goods of
Cornelius Hogan
.

MARGARET SULLIVAN
. I am in the service of Cornelius Hogan, of Queen-street, Seven-dials
; he takes in nightly lodgers . On the 20th of August the two prisoners came there about eleven o'clock at night; I showed them to a lodging - these sheets were then on the bed; between nine and ten o'clock in the morning, I went up stairs, and found all safe - I locked the passage door, and went up to the prisoner's bed, as they were strangers; I missed the sheets - I came down, and said to one of them, "Have youa pair of sheets on you?" he said, "No, you may search me" Mrs. Sheekey said, "You have no occasion to search, the sheets are on the kitchen stairs" - they had brought them down, and could not get out, as I had locked the door; there were four beds, but the other lodgers had all gone before I went up - I told the prisoners to get up, and all the beds were right then, but I locked the door, that they should not go out, as they were strangers.

MATILDA SHEEKEY
. I was in the yard at the time the prisoners came down - they tried the doors, and could not get out; they then tried the water-closet, and that was fast- I then heard one of them say, "What shall I do?" and the other said, "Put them down the kitchen stairs;" the witness then came down, and I told her what I had heard.

JOSEPH KENDRICK
(Police-constable F 126). I took the prisoners.

CORNELIUS HOGAN
. To the best of my knowledge these are my sheets.

FOWLER -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

GLUE -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Months .

2024.
WILLIAM HUDSON
and
GEORGE SAUNDERS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 mahogany tea-chest, value 20s., the goods of
John Graham
and others .

JOSEPH KENDRICK
(Police-constable F 126). I was on duty in Brook-street, Holborn, on the 26th of July, about seven o'clock in the evening, and saw Hudson coming into a public-house, with this tea-chest in a bag, and Saunders with him; Hudson wished to leave the bag, but the landlord would not let him; I asked what it was, and Hudson said it was no business of mine - I took them to the watch-house, and then Hudson said, it was a tea-chest which he bought in Tottenham court-road, for 12s.; they were about three hundred yards from the prosecutors'.
Saunders. Q. Where was I? A. You were coming in just behind him.

ROBERT LYON
. I am in the employ of Mr. John Graham and others - they are upholsterer s. This is their property; I saw it safe in the afternoon of the 26th of July - I know nothing of the prisoners.

JOSEPH HIGGINS
(Police-constable F 35). On the 26th of July, between one and two o'clock, I saw the prisoners in Holborn - I watched them; they went into an optician's; they then went to the prosecutors', and from there to the public-house where they were taken; they had changed coats after I saw them.

Hudson's Defence. I saw a man with this and some others, and he wanted 16s. for one - I offered him 12s.; he would not take it - I walked away; he ran after me and let me have it - I then went to the Three Tuns with it, and was taken.
Saunders' Defence. I was in the tap-room when Hudson came in - I had not seen him before.

HUDSON -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

SAUNDERS -
GUILTY Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

2025.
JOHN JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 time-piece, value 3l. , the goods of
James Wood
.

JAMES WOOD
. I live in Great Russell-street, Bloomsbury
, and am a silversmith and jeweller . On the 15th of August I was sitting in my shop, and saw the prisoner turn out with this time-piece in his hand; I pursued, and took him with it three doors from my house - there was another with the prisoner; he put a pocket handkerchief over it, and the moment he saw me he threw it down.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined One Month .

2026.
THOMAS MALONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 2 deal boards, value 4s. , the goods of
Joseph Ford
.

JOSEPH FORD
. I am a bedstead-maker . I lost these two boards from outside my door, in High-street, St. Giles'
, between six and seven o'clock in the evening; a man told me that a man had gone off with two boards - I went and took the prisoner about three hundred yards off, with the boards on his shoulder; I asked what he was going to do with them - he said, "To make a box;" I took him to the station.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he found the boards on the curb-stone, and being intoxicated had taken them.

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2021.
EDWARD POYSER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 4 pieces of merino, value 8l.; 16 pieces of printed cotton, value 9l., and 1 wrapper, value 6d. , the goods of
Edward Bright
.

WILLIAM WARE
. I am an officer of the Tower. On the 4th of September I was at the corner of Plough-street, in Whitechapel, a quarter before eight o'clock in the evening; I saw a man come round the corner with a hat in his hand - as soon as he saw me he made a stop, and soon after the prisoner came round with this package on his shoulder; I looked in his face, and said, "Ah, Teddy! is it you?" he said he had been employed by a man in the Commercial-road to carry the package, and he was going to take it to the Kent and Essex tavern - I took him to the watch-house, and opened the package, in which I found the bill of parcels.

EDWARD BRIGHT
. I am a carrier . I took this bale of goods on my waggon at the Kent and Essex yard
; it is directed for Mr. Bell - I did not miss it till I got below Epping.

GEORGE BUCKLAND
. I packed the truss, and took it to the Kent and Essex tavern, from Messrs. Hadland and Co.'s, Cheapside.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that a gentleman met him in the street, and employed him to carry the hale to Kent and Essex yard.

EDWARD BRIGHT
re-examined. Q. Was your waggon tilted? A. Yes, and this was in the middle of it - I was driving it.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .
OLD COURT. THURSDAY, JULY 13.
Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2028.
THOMAS NEWMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August
, 1 pelerine, value 2s.; 2 night-caps, value 3s.; 4 pairs of drawers, value 10s.; 5 pairs of stockings, value 5s.; 5 shifts, value 5s.; 2 slips, value 5s.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 6 napkins, value 7s., and 2 handkerchiefs,value 2s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Ramsay
; and
WILLIAM LANGLEY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen . - To which they both pleaded

GUILTY . -
Transported for Seven Years .

2029.
WILLIAM EMMERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of July , 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 waistcoat, value 5s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 7s.; 1 pair of gloves, value 1s., and 5 sovereigns, the property of
Alexander Hirons
; and 1 coat, value 5s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 3s.; 1 pair of boots, value 2s.; 1 sheet, value 4s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 3s.; 1 waistcoat, value 1s., and 1 pair of gloves, value 6d., the goods of
David Hirons
, in the dwelling-house of
Alexander Hirons
.

ALEXANDER HIRONS
. I live in Foundry-place, Shoreditch
- the prisoner is a tailor , and lodged on my first floor since Easter. On the 23rd of July some property was missing, and he absconded without notice - I had seen him in the house after two o'clock that afternoon.

ANN HIRONS
. I am the wife of Alexander Hirons. On the 23rd of July I missed five sovereigns from a box up stairs; it was locked, and I found it still locked, but the key was in the room; I had not seen the money for ten days - my husband's clothes were all right in the morning - I went out at two o'clock, returned at four, and the things were gone - the prisoner, whom I had left in the house, was also gone.

WILLIAM ATTFIELD
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner in Langston-place, Hampstead-road, on the 23rd, about nine or ten o'clock, and charged him with this robbery - he strongly denied it at first, but I found a pair of gloves, which the prosecutor claimed, and 1l. in silver; and in a box, which he said was his, I found all the property belonging to the prosecutor's son; he then said he was guilty, and that he had sold a coat at Benjamin's shop - we went, and took Benjamin that night, and found the coat and other things hanging in his shop.

JOHN BENJAMIN
. I bought the coat and things of the prisoner, between five and six o'clock that afternoon, for 28s.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. She said, at the office, it was a 5l. note she lost - I can prove I had no money for a week before.
MRS. HIRONS. I never said any thing about a 5l. note; this handkerchief was in the same box as the sovereigns.
GUILTY of stealing to the value of 99s. only . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

2030.
WILLIAM PUTNAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 ewe sheep, price 18s. , the property of
Thomas Goddard
.

THOMAS GODDARD
. I am a farmer , and live at Ealing. On the 27th of August I had ninety-three ewes in a field, at Harrow
, and next day, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I found the prisoner dragging one of them along the field by its legs; he drew it to the hedge, threw it into the ditch, then turned, saw me, and ran away; the field was enclosed - he had no right there; he ran very fast, but I ran round another way, and secured him.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. What condition was the sheep in? A. It was healthy; they were there to graze - there is a footpath through the field; it was a fine day - he was not near the footpath; I do not think it was shady under the hedge - when I took him I asked what he was going to do with the sheep; he said, "What do you think?" I said, "I think you were going to kill it;" he said, "No, I had nothing to kill it with, if I had wanted;" the ditch was dry, and about three feet deep.

JOHN PASCALL
. I am an officer. I received him in charge, and found a knife in his pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. The sheep was laying down, and not well; I took it up, and put it under the hedge; seeing Goddard (having heard his character) I ran away.

WILLIAM COOMBS
. I am a farmer, and have known the prisoner all his life; he bore a good character. I was passing through this field a few days before, and a sheep laid exactly in the footpath - I have no doubt it would have died if I had not taken it up; all the sheep there were ill.
- MILLER. I am a farmer. I have been obliged to move the prosecutor's sheep; they were so rotten that they were ready to drop as I moved them, and several have died since.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Baron Gurney.

2031.
JOHN DILLON
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Cain Carrol
, on the 4th of August , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 cap, value 6d.; 1 half-crown, and 2 shilling, his property .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1032.
WILLIAM DIGNUM
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Henry Andrews
, and with a certain sharp instrument, cutting and wounding him in and upon his neck and throat, with intent to kill and murder him .
TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating his intent to be to disable him - or do him some grievous bodily harm.

HENRY ANDREWS
. I am a clerk to the London United Copper Mine Company . On the 24th of August, at half-past eight o'clock, I was going over Haggerstone-fields
, alone, and was stopped by two men; one inquired the way to Shoreditch, while the other knocked me down and robbed me - one knelt on me, while the other robbed me; I was going to cry out, when they swore they would throw me into the canal, if I made any noise - I was going to call out Police! when the man who knelt on me, drew a knife from his pocket, cut my throat, and then they ran away; they had taken 2l. 10s. from my pocket, and my watch - it was not very dark; the sun had set, I should think, two or three hours, but I did not take particular notice; it was not very dark - I saw the face of the man who used the knife to me - it was the prisoner; I had a good opportunity of seeing his face - I had never seen him before; I got up, and went to the man at the lock, and he went home with me; I had three cuts on one side of my throat, and one on the other; they bled, and I was attended by a surgeon - I saw the prisoner at the Crown, Church-street, Bethnal-green, a fortnight after; I was taken there by two Policeman; he was in company with others, and was not pointed out to me; I pointed him out; I should not like to swear positively that he is one of the persons, in consequence of an alibi set up by three witnesses - I am fully convinced he is the person, but do not swear positively to him.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Which of the men came up to you first? A. Both came together; I am not able to identify the other - I have not the least idea of his person; I was a good deal alarmed and agitated - I am not quite so positive as I was before the Magistrate; one had a fustian jacket on, and the other a fustian frock coat, the one not taken had the jacket.

JAMES SENOLS
. I am lock-keeper at the Regent's canal. On the evening in question, between twenty minutes to nine, and nine o'clock, the prosecutor came to my lock; he was very much agitated - I put my hand to his face, and found it wet; it was too dark to distinguish whether it was blood or water - I took him home, and found his throat was cut; it was light enough to see a man's face - he was robbed about one hundred yards from my lock.

WILLIAM HUXTABLE
. I am a surgeon. I was called to the prosecutor's house; he had received two incisions on the right side of the throat, and another on the left; the one on the right was full half an inch deep, and of a very serious character; the others, though very extensive, were not so deep - he was under my care for ten or twelve days; the wounds healed favourably.

THOMAS SILCOX CARTER
. I am a Policeman. On the 24th of August, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, our inspector came to me to go into a field, adjoining where I was on duty, to see if I could find any sharp instrument or bludgeon; and about four o'clock in the morning, I went and found a watch, laying on its face, exactly at the entrance of the gateway - there appeared to have been a scuffle about two yards from where it lay.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Was not this spot between two hedges? A. The watch laid on the gateway, nearly on the east side of the post - it was not hedges; there is a small fence, and the scuffle appeared to have been near the fence; it would be darker at night on one side the fence than in an open place - the fence is about four feet high; I do not think that would make it darker on the ground, because it is about midway between two gas-lamps, which throw a reflection nearly on the spot.

PHILIP JONES
. I am a Policeman. I went with the prosecutor to the Crown, public-house, and saw the prisoner in company with several persons; the prisoner was not pointed out to the prosecutor - I believe he pointed him out himself.

WILLIAM KING
. I am a Policeman. I was with Jones; the prosecutor and I went into the tap-room near where the prisoner was sitting; the prosecutor's eye appeared to be fixed, and he pointed out the prisoner; I cautioned him to be particular - he said he was quite positive; the prisoner said he could prove an alibi.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. He said so at the time, I believe? A. Yes, and produced his witnesses before the Magistrate.
COURT. Q. And they were bound over to appear? A. Yes; they did not go before the Grand Jury, because they were not called.

RICHARD WACE
. I am secretary to the London United Mine Company; the prosecutor was in their employ; he had 10l. given to him on the 9th of August, but nothing on the day of the robbery.

THOMAS BOLTON
. I am a chair-maker, and live in Three Harts-lane, Bethnal-green, at the corner of South-street. I was called before the Magistrate on the prisoner's behalf; I know where he was on the 24th of August - I know the date because we were so very busy at work, and very much tied to time to finish it - it was on a Friday - I worked with him all that day; we parted at meal times; eight o'clock is the time to leave off work, but we worked till half-past eleven o'clock - I work for the prisoner, and his employer - he lived at the same place; I was in his company from a quarter to five o'clock till half-past eleven at night; Morgan was at work from four o'clock till half-past nine - he worked at home till four o'clock, and then brought his work there to finish - I was never in custody myself.

MR. BODKIN. Q. Have you known the prisoner some time? A. I served my time to him - he never had a fustian jacket since I have known him; he bore a very good character indeed; our lodgings is about three quarters of a mile from where the robbery was committed.

JAMES MORGAN
. I am a chair-carver, and work for the prisoner. On the 24th of August I went to his house about four o'clock in the afternoon, and remained there till after nine at work for him - he and Bolton were there; I was called before the Magistrate to give the evidence.
NOT GUILTY .
The prisoner was again indicted for the robbery, but no evidence offered.

2033.
JOHN BURTON
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Cook
, on the 26th of August , and stealing 1 watch, value 10s.; 1 shilling, and 5 sixpences, his property .

JAMES COOK
. I live in the parish of Finchley
. On Sunday, the 26th of August, a little before four o'clock, I left my house fastened up, and left nobody in it; I returned a little before seven, and found the window broken, just where the hasp catches; the window was open - I had left it fast; I saw two foot-marks by the window, and missed my money from the mantel-piece, and my metal watch, which hung at the bed-head; the prisoner has been in my cottage several times for his beer - he pitched hay for my master.

JOHN STAMP
. Last Sunday fortnight, between four and five o'clock, I was going with Mr. Harris' two sons, and saw the prisoner peeping round the haystack, against Cook's barn, which joins his house - he was about twenty yards from the house; when he saw me, he came out, and said,"Master has not taken all the hay up;" I said No, he had only taken two loads - he stopped a bit, and then said, "It is fine, and I shall go on to Finchley;" he went by Cook's, within two yards of it - the window was shut then.
Prisoner. I was never near the place at all. Witness. I am quite sure of him.

CHARLES WILLIAMS
. I am in the employ of Mr. Cassel, a pawnbroker, of Camden-town. Last Monday fortnight an old metal watch was pawned, and redeemed the same day; I cannot say whether the prisoner is the person who pawned it.

JOHN RATCLIFFE
. I am a Policeman. I apprehendedthe prisoner on the Tuesday after the robbery - I found 3s. 4d. on him.

ALFRED JOHN LIST
. I am a Police-inspector. The prisoner was brought to the station-house; I told him he was charged with felony, having received information that this house was broken into, and that Stamp had seen him near the house - he said he was no farther than Hampstead-heath, near the Castle, on the Sunday of the robbery - I repeated that; he still denied having been further than the Castle; I asked him to account for the money he had; he said he had been at work at Kilburn the preceding day, and received 2s. 6d.
NOT GUILTY .

2034.
RICHARD COLLINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , at St. Martin in the Fields, 3 coats, value 4l.; 2 1/4 yards of cloth, value 1l.; 4 pairs of trousers, value 3l., and 1 bag, value 1s., the goods of
John Walter
, in his dwelling house .

THOMAS MOORE. I am in the employ of John Walter, a tailor , at No. 415, Strand, in the parish of St. Martin in the Fields
. On Wednesday, the 25th of July, about ten minutes to eight o'clock, I was opening his shop, and as I took the shutters round into the court - I did not see the prisoner go into our shop, but he came out with four pairs of trousers, three coats, and two yards and a quarter of blue cloth under his right arm; he walked out; but when he saw me running after him he ran up New Exchange-court, and threw them down - I still followed him, laid hold of his coat, and kept him till a gentleman came; he lifted his hand, and attempted to strike me, but never got away - the things are worth more than 8l.

Prisoner. Q. Did I throw the things down before you came up to me? A. Yes; he dropped them, and ran up the court - I caught him in Heathcock-court, about a dozen yards from the Strand - it is a throughfare.

FRANCIS LITTLE
. I am a Policeman. I was called in when the prisoner was taken - I took him into custody in New Exchange-court, at a public-house door, and found the clothes.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down the court, and met the young man; he charged me with the robbery - I said he could go and fetch a Policeman; I stopped there five minutes while he went, and if guilty of a robbery I should not have stopped.

THOMAS MOORE
. A man held him while I went.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Life .

2035.
CHARLES AITKEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August
, 36 knives, value 2l. 18s. 6d.; 3 pencil-cases, value 24s.; 1 opera-glass and case, value 27s., and 1 ivory tablet, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
Charles Essex
, his master, in his dwelling-house ; and
WILLIAM DAYTON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

CHARLES ESSEX
. I am a dealer in cutlery , and live in Well-street, Gray's Inn-lane, in the parish of St. Pancras
- the prisoner Aitkin was my errand-boy . On Saturday, the 11th of August, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I told him to put up the shutters of the warehouse and fasten all the doors; I had a Policeman up stairs, and when the prisoner got on the step of my door I gave him in charge; he was brought back and searched - there were found on him nine two bladed horn handled knives, two with buck-born handles, and one with an ivory handle; they were mine, and worth 18s. 7 1/2d.; no threat or promise was made to him - when he was searched, he said, "Oh, Sir! I hope you will have mercy on me;" I said, "Policeman, do your duty;" he cried a great deal and begged for mercy - the Policeman said,"You young rascal, is this the way you rob your master, what were you going to do with the property?" he said he was going to take it to
John Neale
and Lipman, who were to be in the first box in the Union gardens, on the right-hand side out of the Bagnigge-wells-road.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. The property must have been taken at different times? A. Certainly; I have every reason to believe he had been robbing me for eighteen months; he told me what he had done with my property - I had information from a Policeman named Baylis, letter D 63.
Q. Have you not reason to believe the prisoner has been led away by other persons? A. No, I think he is naturally depraved.
COURT. Q. Has he given you information by which you have found your property? A. A small portion of it.

NATHANIEL BROWN
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a tablet and pencil-case, which were pawned by Dayton - he told me he pawned them for his father.

LUIS WHITE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pencilcase - I do not know who pawned it - it was a boy.

RICHARD HOWARD
. I have a silver pencil-case, pawned by a boy - I cannot say who.

JOHN EDWARD
NEALE. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I have an opera-glass pawned for 7s. 6d. in the name of Lewis - I have no recollection who it was.
MR. ESSEX. The prisoner sent me a letter giving information, by which I recovered about 4l. 10s. 2d. worth of property - my loss is upwards of 80l.

ROBERT BAILEY
. I had known th prisoner about three weeks previous to this.

Cross-examined. Q. You gave the officer information, I believe? A. Yes, I have not had a great deal of property from him; I was never tried - I am errand-boy to Mr. Wilton, of Pearle-street, Bagnigge-wells; I became acquainted with the prisoner through
Joseph Neale
, who was taken up - I was in custody about four years ago, at Hatton-garden, for pulling down some haycocks at Highbury; that is the only time I was ever in custody.
COURT. Q. Did you receive any thing from the prisoner? A. Yes, a dozen knives, which I gave up to Baylis, and gave information.

ROBERT BAYLIS
. I am a Policeman. I received a dozen knives from Bailey, who gave me information - I took Aitken into custody, and found this property on him.

AITKEN -
GUILTY of stealing to the value of 99s. only . Aged 16. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

DAYTON -
NOT GUILTY .

2036.
JAMES DANKS DUNN
was indicted
for stealing, on the 29th of February , at St. Matthew, Bethnal-green, 40 gold rings, value 10l., the goat of
Dickenson Sowerby
, in his dwelling-house .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM EDWARDS
. I am foreman to Dickenson Sowerby, pawnbroker , Brick-lane, in the parish of St. Matthew, Bethnal-green
. On the 29th of February, about seven o'clock in the evening, I was at tea in the parlour; our lad came in, and said a man wanted to look at a weddingring; I went and saw the prisoner, who said he wanted a wedding-ring to fit his little finger - I got some from the parlour, and showed him some in a paper; there were about forty - I took one out, and put the paper of rings by my arm; I said, "That is about the size you want;" it rolled along the counter, and I went to prevent its going off - he immediately snatched up the paper containing the rest from under my arm, and ran out instantly; I pursued, and caught him in the middle of the road, as he stumbled; we had a tussle two or three times - he was up and down; he screwed part of his coat up, and left part of it in my hand - two of his companions came up and knocked me down - he escaped; on the 17th of July I went with the officer to Kingsland-road, and saw the prisoner walking a match - I am quite certain he is the man; I had seen him about a week previous to the robbery, at the Crown and Shuttle, Shoreditch; the officer took him, and said, "I have caught you at last, Jemmy;" and took him to the station; I identified him immediately - I went to Worship-street with him in a coach, and a person who was with him said, "When this is all over, we will walk this match again;" he said, "I shan't walk it again, I suppose this will send me across the herring-pond."

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. When had you seen him before? A. On the 29th of February; I did not seen him again till he was apprehended - I do not know that it was publicly announced, that he was going to walk a wager, but a man came to my shop, and said Danks was going to walk a wager; I knew his name, as when I saw him at the Crown and Shuttle, the week before, he came to my shop and bought a belt, he was talking about it being a good thing to walk with, and somebody said he was Jem Danks, the walking man; and he said,"I'll run you for 100l."

GEORGE LEE
. I was in the shop when the prisoner came in and run out with the rings; I am certain he is the man - I was standing by, writing a ticket at the time.

FRANCIS FARQUES
. I am a dyer, and live in Phoenix-street, Spitalfields. I had seen the prisoner two or three times before the 29th of February; I heard a noise at our gate that day, went out, and heard a cry of Stop thief! I opened the gate, saw the prisoner running, and pursued him; Edwards and several more were running after him - I saw a piece out of the shoulder of his coat; I caught him myself, but was knocked down by two or three, and he escaped - I am quite sure he is the man.

Prisoner's Defence. I have been placed here a second time on a capital charge; the first was on the 6th of April, when I was charged with robbing Mr. Wood, and had his Majesty's free pardon - he is brother-in-law to Sowerby, and he must know me; after receiving my pardon, I went into the employ of Mr. Bailey; and after this I was told if I walked for a wager, I should be taken into custody for robbing Sowerby, but knowing nothing of it, I went to walk the match - I knew Edwards, and saw him at his door on the 6th of July, and bid him good night; he said good night in reply - Lee said at Worship-street, that he did not believe I was the man.
MR. EDWARDS. These rings were worth 10l.; they were not all stolen.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Life .

2037.
SUSANNAH EMMERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 1 bag, value 1d.; 24 half-crowns; 38 shillings, and 4 sixpences, the property of
Leah Hunt
, her mistress .
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

LEAH HUNT
. I am a widow and live in Petticoat-lane
; I am in the coal and potatoe trade - the prisoner was in my service. On Friday, the 27th of July, I placed exactly 5l. in sixpences, shillings, and half-crowns in a bag, and when I closed shop just before my Sabbath commenced, I put the bag into a drawer with 19l., which was in a piece of patchwork - it was in the middle of the drawer, in my bed-room; the drawer was locked, but whether I left the key there I cannot tell: I put it away to pay my coal bill - I did not go to look for it till the Monday morning; I found the patchwork tied up as I had left it - I brought it down, untied it, but found the bag of silver was not there; I called the servants, and said, "I am robbed! I am robbed!" I have another servant: the prisoner was near enough to hear me - I said,"I will go and send for a Policeman, and have every one of your boxes searched," meaning all the servants: the other servant said I was very welcome to go over her box, and that it was not locked, but the prisoner said nothing - I sent for Lealter, and told him, in the prisoner's presence, what had happened; he went up stairs, the prisoner went first, and he followed her - they were not up stairs long Lealter; brought down my purse and the 5l. in silver (the prisoner slept in the same room as I did); I said, "Oh, here is my little coarse purse with my 5l. in it," and asked her how she could be so cruel as to rob a widow with a family of children, as she had robbed me - she prayed forgiveness and I let her go; and on the same day, in about two hours, I received a summons from her, and went before the Justice, but she did not attend, and the case was dismissed - I told the Justice what had happened; he granted a warrant for her, and she was taken the same day.
The summons being read, was for unlawfully taking 5l. out of the prisoner's box.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. How long had she been in your employ? A. Two years altogether; she lived with me twice - I gave her 1s. 6d. a week: she had told me about a fortnight before, that she was going to give me warning, but not till I suited myself; we were to part friendly; I am sure when I put the money into the drawer I locked it, and had the key in my pocket, but whether I left the key in the drawers when I took the money out I cannot tell - the bag was made of coarse cloth; I never made another bag of the same stuff; none of stuff was remaining.

ISAAC LEALTER
. I am a neighbour of Mrs. Hunt's. -On Monday, the 30th of July, I was sent for, and went to her house; the prisoner and the other servant was present - she told me she missed the bag of silver from a drawer in her bed-room, and that nobody but her servants had access to the room; I said the best thing was to search their boxes - the other said she was willing: the prisoner beganto cry - I said, "Come, I will go up and search your box"- she went up, and the other servant also; the prisoner opened her box, gave me 15s., and siad it belonged to a boy- I said, "You have more, have not you? it is of no use, I must see what you have;" she then put her hand to the bottom of the box, and pulled out a bag; I said, "What is that?" she said, "The bag is mistress', but the money is mine;" I asked how much there was - she said 4l.; I counted it, and there were 5l. - I took her down to her mistress, and asked her what was in it; she said 5l., and said, "How could you rob a widwo like me;" she cried, and begged forgiveness - I said, "You had better pay her wages, and let her go;" I attended to the summons with Mrs. Hunt - I saw the prisoner close to the office as I went there, and when she saw us she went away: Mrs. Hunt waited two hours, but she did not appear - Hunt stated the circumstance, and the Magistrate issued a warrant.

COURT. Q. Did Mrs. Hunt say any thing to her about more money? A. Yes, she said, "Have you not got more money belonging to me?" she said, "No, I have only got 16s.; you have got all belonging to you, (meaning the 5l.) and this is mine."

JAMES BROWN
. I am an officer of Worship-street. -When the summons was heard the Magistrate directed me to take the prisoner - I received the bag and money from Lealter.

LEAH HUNT
. This is my bag - the 5l. is in it.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2038.
SAMUEL HOLMES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 25 pairs of gloves, value 5l. , the goods of
Joseph Gladman
.

JOSEPH GLADMAN
. I am a hosier and glover , and live in Quadrant, Regent-street
. On the 14th of August, about six o'clock in the evening, two persons came into my shop, and asked to see some silk handkerchiefs, which I showed them; they said there was none of the sort they wanted, would I show them more - I did so; they wanted some with a border, and while I was looking for some, I saw the prisoner put his hand over the shop window, and take something; my wife came out of the parlour, and said,"There is a man running out with some gloves;" he was running out - I pursued him down Vine-street, and cried,"Stop him!" and when I got up to him, a Policeman ran across the road, and stopped him; I had seen him let the gloves fall - there are twenty-five pairs; he was never out of my sight.

ROBERT KENDAL
. I was a Policeman. I heard a cry of Stop him! I immediately ran up, and saw the prisoner throw the gloves down in Vine-street - I secured him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2039.
WILLIAM HASTINGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 hat, value 3s. , the goods of
Robert Stewart
.

JAMES ENGLEHART
. I am shopman to Robert Stewart, a hatter , of Shoreditch
. On the 17th of August, between twelve and one o'clock, this hat was on a stand in the shop- I was present when the Policeman brought the prisoner in with it in his hand; I had not seen it taken.

JOHN WILLIAM
DENNIS. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner take the hat off a stand inside the shop; I took him immediately with it - he said he did not care any thing about it, for he wished to go and see his old palls in Clerkenwell - that Moore was transported, and he should not mind going to see him.(Property produced and sworn to)

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2040.
JOSEPH HART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 1 iron wheel, value 1s. 6d.; 1 iron bed for a smoke-jack, value 2s.; 1 iron standard, value 2s.; 1 collar for a lathe, value 4l., and 1 file, value 4d. , the goods of
John Prosser
.

WILLIAM PROSSER
. I conduct the business for my brother John, a smoke-jack maker , on Back-hill, Hattongarden
- the prisoner was in his employ for a month. On Saturday, the 11th of August, as he was going to dinner, I met him, and suspecting him, I called Lloyd, who searched him, and found on him the bed of a smoking-jack and a standard, both new - we went to his lodging, and found the collar of a mandril, some files, and a great many other things, all of which are my brother's.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you in partnership with your brother? A. No - I saw some of the things the night before, concealed with other property - nobody else makes these things; we have a patent for them; these are unfinished, and are never sold in this state.

ANDREW LLOYD
. I met the prisoner on the spot, and took two things out of his pocket - he said, "Here they are - I ought to be transported."
Cross-examined. Q. Did you go to his lodging? A. Yes, and found his wife and two children there.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 24.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .

2041.
DAVID FIELD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 33 yards of silk, value 3l., the goods of
William Brown
, his master .

WILLIAM BROWN
. I am a silk weaver , and live in Fashion-street, Bethnal-green
. The prisoner has been about ten months in my employ, and worked in the house, making gros de Naples - he absented himself on the 23rd of July, and I found thirty-three yards of his work cut out of his loom, and gone - he was taken on the 8th of August.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had he just got married? A. He had - he was paid 4 1/2d. or 5d. a yard, and could make six or seven yards in a day; he served four years with me as an apprentice.

LAWRENCE JAMES HALES
