I went to Frost's house; when the door was open I saw Frost, but not Sheldrick - the mob was collected outside, who told me there was a wine-merchant's man who could not get his money, and they were afraid he would be ill-used; Frost said to me, "I want you to clear the mob away, and then you can go about your business;" I said, "I want to know what brought them together?" the carman then said, "I want you - he will neither let me take my wine away, nor yet give me my money;" I asked Frost the reason, and he said his master had got a bill of his for 30l.; the carman said he had not got a bill for thirty pence - the place was dark till I sent for a light; the man then missed two bottles of wine and one of brandy - I searched to find them, but could not; the carman then said, "I will give him into custody;" I took Frost, and on the day following I found Sheldrick in Hoxton; I asked him if he knew one Mr. Frost - he said, "What makes you ask the question?" I said, "It is a fair question;" he gave me no answer - I then asked if he knew any thing about wine or brandy - he said he had ordered some.

GEORGE KEMP
(Police-constable N 82). Frost was in the lock-up place; a female, who represented herself as his wife, came and saw him - he handed her this paper, which I took - it is the invoice of the wine.
WILLIAM NEIGHBOUR. I had a receipt with me, but it was not signed - I should have signed it if I had received the money.

Sheldrick's Defence. Mr. Frost gave me the bill to take to a gentleman in 'Change-alley, to get discounted - they wanted me to leave it, but Frost told me not; I brought it back, and gave it to him, in the presence of the carman; I have a large family, and what I have done for Mr. Frost he paid me for.

FROST -
GUILTY . Aged 28.

SHELDRICK -
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .

2060.
JOHN SHARPE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 1 knife, value 4d.; 1 key, value 6d.; 1 tobacco-stopper, value 1d.; 1 sixpence, 4 pennies, and 6 halfpence, the property of
Francis Roper
, from his person .

FRANCIS ROPER
. I live in Holborn. On Sunday, the 12th of August, I was returning home from Notting-hill, about four o'clock in the morning - I was taken is a fainting fit, and fell down about half a mile from Hyde-park corner; when I recovered I felt for my money, and missed the articles stated - Peter Hussey came to me, and I told him.

PETER HUSSEY
. I live in Ivory's-buildings, and am a coach painter. I was in the road, and saw the prosecutor in the kennel - I saw the prisoner and another man come up to him - one of them went up to him and the other stood in the centre of the road - I saw the prosecutor's pocket turned inside out; the prisoner and his companion ran off; I pursued them to the Edgware-road, and the officer took the prisoner.

DAVID DAVIS
(Police-constable T 132). I stopped the prisoner, and found on him a silver sixpence, 1d., a knife, key, and a tobacco-stopper; the other was not detained.

Prisoner's Defence. I had no place to go to; I had been into the park, and laid down till four o'clock - I got over the wall, and saw this man asleep in a kennel - I went to awake him; I did not disturb him - I sang out Halloo! I saw his pocket turned out, and these things by the side of it, and I took them up.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2061.
RICHARD SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 trowel, value 3s. , the goods of
Samuel Battershill
.

SAMUEL BATTERSHILL
. I am a plasterer , and live in Stamford-street, Blackfriars - I do not know the prisoner I had left my trowel safe in Gray's Inn-lane
, where I had been at work on the 15th, and when I came to work at half-past six o'clock the next morning it was gone - I went to buy another, and saw the prisoner with my trowel and another in his hand, in Drury-lane.

Prisoner. He stopped me, and said it was his - I said if it was he must have it; I had it of a man who had it to dispose of, and I would have taken him to the man in St. Giles', but he would not go. Witness. He was remanded from Friday till Monday, and I believe the Policeman went and made inquiries.

GUILTY . Aged 38*. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2062.
JOHN SMITH
was
indicted for embezzlement .

CHARLES HODGSON
. I live in Bedford-street, Covent-garden
, and sell soda water - the prisoner was in my employ, and he was to account every night to me for the money he received for goods; some soda-water was sent by him to the Swan with Two Necks, Lad-lane on the 14th, and on the 18th of June, but he neveraccounted to me for any money received there, on either of those days.

JOHN MARKS URBAIN
. I am a waiter at the Swan with Two Necks. I paid the prisoner 10s. 6d. on the 14th of June, and 9s. on the 18th for soda-water.
The prisoner received a good character, and a witness engaged to employ him.
GUILTY. Aged 25.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

2063.
ANN WESTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 2 shawls, value 5s., the goods of
Harriet Mason
; and a necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Isabella Mason
.

HARRIET MASON
. I am a widow , and occupy the upper floor in Mr. Munday's house, Penton-street, Pentonville
. On the 11th of August; I missed a necklace from the top of a box, in one of my rooms; the prisoner was pursued and taken; I said "You wicked woman, you have robbed me of a coral necklace - if you will return it, I will let you go;" she gave me the necklace, but we thought she had something more, and asked her for it; she paused some time, and then gave up this shawl, which is mine - the necklace is my daughter Isabella's; we found on her another shawl.

MATILDA MUNDAY
. I live at the house with my parents; we sell milk, and the door stands open. On the 11th of August I saw the prisoner in the passage; she asked for a person who did not live there; I said there was no such person there; she went up stairs came down again, and appeared fuller about the bosom than before.

JOHN MUNDAY
. I ran after the prisoner, and stopped her; she produced the necklace in my presence.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. Distress drove me to it.

GUILTY . Aged 53. -
Confined Six Months .

2064.
MARY ANN WHITE
was indicted for
indicted for stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 purse, value 1d; 1 sovereign, and 2 half-crowns, the property of
George Robert Galloway
, from his person .

GEORGE ROBERT GALLOWAY
. I am a traveller , and live in Marylebone-street. On the morning of the 14th of August I was coming home by the New-road
, a little after one o'clock, the prisoner met me, laid hold of me, and said, "My dear, will you come home with me;" she then put her hand into my pocket, and took out my purse, which had a sovereign and two half-crowns in it; I charged her with it, and she denied it; I was looking on the ground, and she threw the purse on a wall, intending, I suppose, to throw it over - I took it down; the two half-crowns were gone from it, and the two slide-rings off it - the sovereign was safe in the other end; there was another girl came, and spoke to her; I had felt the money safe a quarter of an hour before.

THOMAS BARNETT (Police-constable S 108). On the morning of the 14th of August I was in the New-road on duty, about half-past one o'clock; the prosecutor was holding the prisoner - he gave her in charge for taking his purse from him, and two half-crowns out of it - I found 1s, on her.
Prisoner. He said he had been drinking with two friends in the course of the day, and he had been talking to two women coming down the road.

GEORGE ROBERT
GALLOWAY. I had not said a word to any woman - I was quite sober.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2065.
MARY ANN WHITEHEAD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of September , 4 spoons, value 3l.; 3 shirts, value 15s.; 1 gown, value 10s.; 1 brooch, value 14s., and 1 necklace, value 7s., the goods of
Isaac Hewitt
, her master .

ISAAC HEWITT. I lived at No. 1, Savoy-street, Strand
, at the time of this robbery - it was my dwelling-house, and in the precinct of the Savoy; I am a wine and spirit merchant . The prisoner came into my service on Friday, the 24th of September, 1831, and she left me on the Monday, taking with her these things - we did not know she was gone till a ring came at the bell, and she did not answer; I never saw her again till the 6th of September, in this year, when I saw her in Chandos-street - when I spoke to her she said she did not know me, but in less than a minute she said she did; she said at the station that she had sold the things the next day to a Jew, for 3l., and she should not know him again - they were worth at the lowest rate 5l. 6s.

HENRY HUBBERSTY
(Police-constable A 52.) I took the prisoner - she said she took the property, and sold it to a jew for 3l.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2066
ANN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 gown, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Nicholls
.

GEORGE CHAPMAN
. I am shopman to Mr.
Thomas Nicholls
, a pawnbroker , of Gray's Inn-lane
. I had a gown hanging up for sale, and was told by a person who was passing that it was gone - I went after the prisoner, and found it in her apron; it was between four and five o'clock in the afternoon.
Prisoner. It was another man took the gown from me, and two girls had given it to me. Witness. There were two girls with her - she did not say they gave it her.(Property produced and sworn to.)

RICHARD BAYLIS
(Police-constable G 67.) I took the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2067.
THOMAS KIRBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 bed, value 1l.; 1 pillow, value 2s.; 1 pair of sheets, value 8s.; 1 pair of blankets, value 8s., and 1 quilt, value 2s. , the goods of
William Perren
.

ELIZABETH MATILDA PERREN
. I am the wife of
William Perren
- we live in Featherstone-buildings, City-road
. On the 16th of August the prisoner was at our house, and asked for a lodging; I had a bed, a pair of sheets, and blankets there; he came about nine o'clock at night, and I missed the articles stated at six in the morning.

WILLIAM BRUFF
(Police-constable G 162.) In Cousequence of the witness' description I was passing Drurylane, and saw the prisoner - I apprehended him; he had the bed and things on the ground near him; I asked him what made him take them, and he said he wanted to go into the country.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2068.
THOMAS LITTLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 1 hat, value 6s. , the goods of
John Cook
.

ELIZABETH DIVEIS
. I am the wife of
John Diveis
, of George-garden, Bethnal-green-road. On the 10th of August I was in Brick-lane
, passing Mr. Cook's shop - I saw the prisoner take this hat off the shutters, and walk away with it; I gave information, and he was followed; I am sure this is the man.

JOHN COOK
. I keep a hatter's shop , in Brick-lane - the prisoner was taken by Mr. Mannock.

THOMAS FREDERICK MANNOCK
. I am a silk-weaver. I took the prisoner, in Phoenix-street, with this hat under his arm, about two hundred yards from the prosecutor's - I gave the hat to the officer.(Property produced and sworn to.)

SAMUEL MILTON
(Police-constable H 27.) I took the prisoner, and have the hat.
Prisoner. It was nine o'clock at night when I took it, and I had no victuals for two days.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

2069.
CHARLES MITCHELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 8lbs. weight of soap, value 3s.; 1 Bath brick, value 3d., and 1 box, value 3d. , the goods of
Robert Wing
.

ROBERT WING. I am a grocer , and live in Leigh-street, Burton-crescent
. I lost these things from the threshold of the door.

HENRY BOYD
. I live in Lancaster-street. On the morning of the 10th of August I was in Mr. Wilcox's shop - I saw the prisoner with two others near the prosecutor's shop; he said something to them, but I do not know what - the prisoner stood at the bottom of the steps and held up his apron, while one of the others took the soap and brick, and put them into his apron; he walked off; I gave an alarm, and Mr. Wilcox ran after him - he dropped the articles; I am sure he is the person - he was stopped by Wiliam Parish.

WILLIAM PARISH
. I live in Joseph-street. I was coming home from my milkwalk, and put down my cans; I ran after the prisoner, and stopped him.
- WESTBURY (Police-constable E 154). I heard a cry of Stop thief! between eight and nine o'clock - I went and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1270.
ROBERT PLUMMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 1 coat, value 7s. , the goods of
John Sewry
.

JOHN SEWRY. I live in Industry-row, Battersea, and am a carter . On the 24th of July I lost a coat from my waggon - I saw the prisoner had hold of it and he ran off; I followed him - he threw it down, and ran out of my sight before he was stopped - I picked up the coat in Nortonfalgate; my cart had been in Lamb-street, Spitalfields
.

JOHN BURNESS
. I am a private watchman. On the morning of the 24th of July I heard the cry of Stop thief! I saw the prisoner running - I stopped him, and the Policeman came and took him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up under a baker's window; I saw it was a coat, and put it down again - I went on, and saw two men running up Norton-falgate; I pursued, and called Stop thief! I never took it away from where it lay down.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Two Months .

2071.
JAMES STILES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 1 jacket, value 2s. , the goods of
Robert Sneath
.

ROBERT SNEATH
. I live in White's-square. On the 19th of July I was at a lady's house in Tavistock-street
; I put my jacket in the passage - I heard an alarm, looked out, and saw the prisoner running about twenty yards off, with my jacket under his arm; I pursued, and hallooed Stop thief! I stopped him, and took it from him.

EDWIN YOUNG
. I was a Police-constable. I saw the prisoner run across Southampton-street, and took him; I received this jacket from the prosecutor, which I saw him take from under the prisoner's arm.(Property produced and sworn to.

Prisoner's Defence. I am not the person who took it; I was going by the Strand, a man in his shirt sleeves ran past me; the prosecutor was looking about - I took up the jacket which the man had dropped, and gave it to him; I stood ten minutes, and the officer came up and took me.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . - Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

2072.
JAMES RADFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Richard Griffin Edwards
, from his person .

JOHN CHILDS
. On the 31st of August, about noon, I was near St. Giles' church; I saw the prisoner and another lad - I cannot tell which of them took the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket, but I saw the prisoner putting it into his apron; he was near enough to have taken it, and was in company with the other lad - I gave an alarm; the prisoner was taken, and the handkerchief found on him.

RICHARD GRIFFIN EDWARDS. This is my handkerchief - I lost it from my pocket in Broad-street, St. Giles'
, on the 31st of August.

GEORGE PALMER
(Police-constable E 5). I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I only picked it up from the ground.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2073.
JAMES WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 silver spoon, value 5s., the goods of
William Davis Pritchard
; 3 silver spoons, value 5s., the goods of
George Hedge
; and 2 silver spoons, value 2s., the goods of
Dorothy Hedge
.

EDWARD HAINES
. I am shopman to Mr.
William Davis Pritchard
, of Davies-street, Marylebone
. On the morning of the 20th of August I went down into the area; I looked through the window into the kitchen, and saw the prisoner endeavouring to make his escape by a door thatleads to the kitchen stairs - I set a boy to watch, and in about a quarter of an hour I saw the prisoner running up the area steps; I pursued, and stopped him - I asked him if he had any property; he said he had not - he was searched, and a spoon of Mr. Pritchard's found on him.

WILLIAM FLAXMAN
(Police-constable D 29). I went to Mr. Pritchard's shop, and found all these spoons on the prisoner, round his waist, between his shirt and his skin, in a leather strap.
GEORGE HEDGE. I lodge at Mr. Pritchard's. This table-spoon is mine; these other two are my mother's, and here are two others, which I cannot swear to, as they have no mark on them.

GUILTY . Aged 22.* -
Transported for Seven Years .

2074.
SOPHIA WALTERS
&
ELIZABETH GRIFFITHS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 pocket-book, value 1s.; one 5l. Bank note, and 1 order for payment of 26l. , the property of
Henry Mee
.

HENRY MEE
. I am a seaman , and lodge in Union-street, Lambeth. On the 30th of August I fell in with the two prisoners at Woolwich; I came to London in a passage-boat with them, and then got into a waterman's boat, and went on shore with Adams; I then missed my pocketbook, containing a 5l. Bank note, and my discharge and remittance-ticket for 26l., which I had when I left the Seringapatam - I was in liquor.
Walters. I saw the book in the vessel, but I gave it to him, and did not see it afterwards. Witness. I was so much intoxicated that I cannot say.

JOHN ADAMS
. I am a waterman. On the 30th of August I put the prosecutor on shore - he had been in my boat with the two prisoners; when the prosecutor got to the public-house, he put his hand about his pocket, when he called for for a pot of half and half, and charged Walters with having his book; she denied it - she said she had it on board the vessel, and gave it him there; she pulled out a shilling and a few halfpence, and declared to God that was all the money she had about her - she then said she wanted to go to Woolwich, and I said I could take her to the coach; while we were talking I saw Griffiths go to the door - I went to her for my fare, and saw through the window Walters giving a 5l. note to the landlord at the bar; I went up to her, and desired to have it - they were then both going out at the door; I put them back, and asked her again for the note - Griffiths said to her, "Let the bl - y rogue have it - he wants to keep it;" I then said, "I shall take you both into custody - I think you are both in it together."

FRANCIS GRIMMER
. I am a waterman. I was at the public-house after these people had been in my boat; I heard Mee charge Walters with having his pocket-book; she said she had but one shilling and two or three halfpence - I was cleaning out my boat afterwards, and found under the water-board this pocket-book, which has the remittance-bill and the discharge in it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Griffiths' Defence. A young man I was with gave me half a crown and 2s., and the waterman said, "You are a d - d fool if you don't take the other half-crown out of his hand."

JOHN ADAMS
. They were talking about it, but I told them to be cautious, for I was an officer, and I would have nothing of the kind done.
Walters' Defence. I had the 5l. note of a young man I was with, but I had 2l. 10s. to pay for liquor which he had had.

WALTERS -
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

GRIFFITHS -
NOT GUILTY .

2075.
HENRY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 candlestick, value 10s. , the goods of
John Matthew Bulkley
.

WILLIAM JOHN HERDMAN
. I am footman to
John Matthew Bulkley
, Esq ., who lives in Connaught-square
. On the 14th of August I was in the kitchen, and saw the prisoner leave the passage; I ran after him - I took hold of his coat, tore the flap of it off, and the candlestick fell from him; I followed him to the Edgware-road - I there stumbled and fell, but I got up, and still pursued; he was taken in my sight.

Prisoner. Q. When I came out of the kitchen, did you follow me? A. You took it from the front-room; I came up to you while you were running - I followed you into a mews, where you was taken; I never lost sight of you.

JONATHAN POLLARD
(Police-constable D 125). I took the prisoner at the Hop Pole, public-house; his coat had the skirt torn, as it has now.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2076.
LEWIS THOMAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 coat, value 3l. , the goods of
George Edward Rees
.

The
prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

2077.
TIMOTHY CALVERT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 hammer, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of the
overseers of the poor of the parish of St. Luke.

JAMES FLIGHT. I am a labourer, and live in Radnor-street, St. Luke's. I work for Mr. West, the superintendent of St. Luke's; the prisoner was employed to break stones in the yard - I had three hammers under my care, and missed one from the window-ledge, about twenty yards from where the prisoner was at work, on the 4th of August; I saw him leaving the yard in the evening, and called to him - he refused to come back; I asked what he had got wrapped up in his jacket - he said only a piece of wood, which was of on use to me; I went after him, and he was brought from a public-house - I saw the handle of the hammer projecting from his jacket; I took it from him, and found this hammer, which is the property of the overseers and guardians of St. Luke's - he afterwards said he merely meant to take it home to break up a piece of wood; but he had denied twenty times that he had any thing of the kind.

ROBERT DALE WEST
. I am superintendent of the stone yard. I left out two or three hammers, and I saw this taken from the prisoner's person.
Prisoner. He said that I was a very old man, and he would get rid of me if he could; he has been saying how much he got of the parish since I have been in prison. Witness. It is not true.

GUILTY . Aged 71. -
Confined Ten Days .

2080.
HELEN GALE
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 11th of August , 1 necklace, value 3s., the goods of
Cornelius Willey
, from the person of
Maria Mary Willey
.

MARTHA GANDY. I am servant to Mr. Cornelius Willey, Store-street, Tottenham-court-road
. I had
Maria Mary Willey
to take care of; she is five years old - I dressed her on the 11th of August, and she and her brother went out - she had a coral necklace on; she came back crying, and said somebody had taken her necklace off her neck.

THOMAS PHILIP PAYNE
. I am servant to a pawnpawnbroker in Hampstead-road. The prisoner pawned this necklace at our shop on the 11th of August, about five o'clock.(Property produced and sworn to.)

DAVID LAING
(Police-constable E 58). I heard of this loss from Gandy; I went into a public-house, and the child identified the prisoner as the person who took it - I took her to No. 18, Store-street, but she denied it; Mr. Willey then said the child's brother would be at home presently, and he could describe her person - the prisoner then put down her head, and began to cry, and then said she had left the duplicate at the public-house; I went there, and found two, one of a gown, and one of the necklace.
Prisoner. I did not take it off the neck; I picked it up. Witness. She at first said she took them, and pawned them to get her a loaf of bread, and then said she picked them up.

CORNELIUS WILLEY
. The prisoner was brought to my house; she denied it, and then told Mrs. Willey she would tell where it was, if we would not prosecute her.

GUILTY of stealing only . Aged 19. -
Confined 1 Month .

2079.
ELIZA HARVEY
and
MARY JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 1 watch, value 2l., the goods of
Thomas Tipper
, from his person .

THOMAS TIPPER
(Police-constable F 152). I was standing at the corner of Bow-street
, on Saturday, the 11th of August, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night - I saw some men quarrelling; the prisoners came up in front of me, and several more persons - there was a bit of a crowd at the corner; Harvey drew the watch out of my pocket - I felt a snatch, and saw the watch in her hand; she passed it to Jones - I took them both into custody, and took the watch from Jones; I was surrounded by a body of persons, and among them, a body of thieves - they made several attempts to rescue the prisoners, but I kept them right; Jones bit me, scratched me, and kicked me - this is my watch; I delivered it to Smith.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. There were a great many people? A. A number passing; I gave an alarm - after I had the prisoners in custody, I was knocked down several times, but I still kept hold of them; they fell with me - Smith took one of the prisoners out of my hand- it was near the Police-office, but that was shut up; I put the watch in my fob again, after I took it from Jones, and buttoned it up out of sight - I had Jones in my hand at the time; it took but a second to put it into my pocket with one hand - there might be thirty or forty persons round me.

COURT. Q. You say there were some men collected, who were quarrelling? A. Yes; I do not know what about - I was at a distance, watching them, and before I could ascertain what it was, I was drawn of my watch; there was not a chance for Harvey to get away.

Jones. We were both going down Bow-street; he caught hold of us, and would not let us go; he was quite intoxicated - he wanted us to go to a house to treat us with liquor; when he was at the station, he said he took the watch from Harvey, and at Bow-street he said he took it from me. Witness. I did not; I was in plain clothes, as I had been ordered.

JOHN SMITH
(Police-constable F 69.) On the night of the 11th of August, I was on duty in Great Russell-street. I saw a crowd at the corner of Bow-street; when I got up, I saw Tipper surrounded with people; the prisoners were endeavouring to get from him - there were some men about who were trying to hustle the witness, and get the prisoners from him; I secured Harvey, and they were taken to the station-house; the witness said Harvey took the watch, passed it to Jones, and he took it from her hand.

Cross-examined. Q. How far is this from your station? A. From three to four hundred yards, and about fifty yards from the office; there were people about, and the corner shop was open - there were a number of persons there; it was a fair night - there was no rain; I believe the witness had a brown coat on - I observed nothing particular about his clothes or face; he told me he had been hustled and thrown down twice by the crowd - I did not see any dirt or mark on his clothes; when I got up, he seemed quite fatigued and harrassed; when I went up the crowd dispersed - we were not in hail of our station; he certainly did tell me that he had been knocked down- I heard him swear to that at Bow-street, and I was told of it by a gentleman I know, but who is not here; his name is Barns; he is a chemist in Great Russell-street - he came across the street, and told me a gentleman had been hustled, and I went over.
JONES' Defence. I am innocent.

Jury to JOHN SMITH. Q. Was the dress of the prosecutor soiled or disordered? A. I did not observe that it was; when I got up he had hold of the two prisoners, and they were struggling to get from him.

HARVEY -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

2080.
ELIZA JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing on the 30th of August , 1 half-crown, the money of
Edward Gainsby
, from his person .

EDWARD GAINSBY
. I am a seaman belonging to the Amphitrite collier. Between eleven and twelve o'clock at night on the 30th of August, I met the prisoner near the Old Rose, in Ratcliff-highway
; she took hold of me, began fumbling about me, whipped her hand into my pocket, and took half-a-crown out - she attempted to put it into her bosom, and dropped it.

THOMAS BAILEY SMITH
. (Police-constable K 4). On the night of the 30th of August, I was standing on Chigwell-hill; I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner standing talking - I heard him say he had a great mind to give her into custody; I went up, and he gave charge of her.

Prisoner. I was going home, and he stopped meand said, might he go with me; I said I did not mind- he said he would give me half-a-crown to sleep with me; I said I would not for that - he then felt what more money he had, and dropped the half-crown; he gave the half-crown to the officer from his pocket.
THOMAS BAILEY SMITH. He gave it me from his hand; he was sober - she said he wanted to go home with her, and he denied that.

GUILTY . Aged 21.* -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2081.
ELIZABETH TYLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of May , 1 spoon, value 1l. , the goods of
John Peirse Wennard
.

ANN BOYKER
. I am in the service of Mr.
John Peirse Wennard
, at Hackney
. The prisoner was sent to the house to see my fellow-servant - this spoon was taken from the table in the kitchen on the day she came to our house; I knew nothing of her before - I have seen a spoon, but I do not know that it is the same.

MARGARET FOWLER
. I know the spoons were right that morning, and in the evening I missed one. The prisoner came for some money, and I paid her.

WILLIAM GREEN
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in this spoon from the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

2082.
JOHN WRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
William Cumming
, from his person .

WILLIAM CUMMING
. I am a carpet-manufacturer . On the 20th of August, after twelve o'clock at night, I was in Picket-street
; I felt a pull at my pocket; I turned, and saw the prisoner throw my handkerchief to another young man - I seized it, and secured the prisoner.

WILLIAM SMITH
(Police-constable F 129). I took the prisoner.
Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. What did he say? A. He said he had done it for a meal.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. There were several persons before and behind me; this gentleman said I had picked his pocket, but I had not done it.
GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2083.
WILLIAM LOMAX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 hat, value 7s. , the goods of
Daniel Lunn
.

DANIEL LUNN
. I am a hatter , and live in Camden-town
; I saw the prisoner take this hat from my shop on the 17th of August - I pursued; he dropped it, and I took him.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Whipped and Discharged.

2084.
EMMA MERRETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August
, 1 frock, value 2s.; 2 petticoats, value 1s. 6d., and 1 pinafore, value 6d., the goods of
Joshua Jordan
, from the person of
Sarah Jordan
.

SARAH JORDAN
. I am the wife of
Joshua Jordan
- we live in Parker-street, Belgrave-square
. I missed my daughter Sarah for four hours on the 3rd of August; I then found her running home from the brick-fields, stripped of every thing but her shift; she is four years and a quarter old - I know nothing of the prisoner; but I found the clothes stated, at the pawnbroker's; they are what she had on.

GEORGE GEVERS
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in this frock and two petticoats from the prisoner, on the 3rd of August, for 2s,; she said they were for her aunt.

ANTHONY RUTT
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 12.

2085. EMMA MERRETT was again indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August
, 1 pair of boots, value 2s.; 1 frock, value 1s., and 1 petticoat, value 1s., the goods of
James Knight
, from the person of
Emma Knight
.

MARTHA KNIGHT
. I am the daughter of James Knight; I have a little sister named Emma five years old; I was out with her near my father's door, on the 4th of August; the prisoner came and asked us to go to play with her -I had never seen her before; she took my sister into the Five-fields with her; my sister had her boots and all her clothes on; I went with them as far as the end of Sloane-square
- I then wanted to go back, and take my sister, but the prisoner prevented me; I had my little brother nursing; I went back and the prisoner took my sister on; it was then about five o'clock; I did not see my sister again till near seven - she then came home with her flannel petticoat on and her pinafore, but all the rest of her clothes were gone.

JOHN ROLLS
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Chelsea. I have a frock, a pair of boots, and a child's petticoat pawned by the prisoner, I believe - the boots on the 4th of August, and the others on the 6th.

JAMES KNIGHT
. These are my child's things.

GUILTY . Aged 12. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2086.
MARY ANN STEVENSON
&
MARY ANN MORGAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 14 shillings, the monies of
John Arthur
, from his person .

JOHN ARTHUR
. I am a porter . On the 15th of July, I had been to a friend's house, and was returning between twelve and one o'clock; I met the two prisoners in Milk-alley
- I was quite sober; they were together; one of them asked me to go a little way, but I declined it - Morgan then put her hand into my breeches pocket, and took out my money; I caught her hand coming out of my pocket; Stevenson then laid hold of my collar, and took me away from her - I called for assistance; the watchman came up - I took 6s. and a medal from Morgan's hand.
Morgan. There was another female in company whom he charged first, and when I came up, he said as he could not get her, he would give charge of me. Witness. No, it is quite false.

JOSHUA FREDERICK CLEMENTS
. I am a superintendant of the Police. I received the prisoner in charge.

ROBERT QUADLING. I am a private-watchman. I heard the noise, and on getting up to Milk-alley, I heard the prosecutor call out - I went to him; he had hold of Morgan's hand, and took 6s. out of it - there was a third person taken, but she was let go.
Morgan. Q. Did you see him take the money out of my hand? A. Yes, and a young man picked up 2s.;

JOHN ARTHUR
. I swear that Morgan took the money out of my pocket.

Stevenson put in a written Defence, stating that she was passing, and seeing the prosecutor who was intoxicated strike Morgan; she went up and advised him not to do so, and immediately some silver fell on the ground - that the prosecutor then charged her with preventing him, from calling for assistance.

STEVENSON -
GUILTY . Aged 31.

MORGAN -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2087.
DAVID WATERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Brown
.

THOMAS BROWN
. I am a shoemaker . On the 16th of August the prisoner came, took these boots, and walked out of my shop with them; he got about twenty yards - I took him with them; I did not know him before.
Prisoner's Defence. I was coming through Somers'-town with a young man; we were both drunk, and I did not know where I was.

GUILTY . Aged 18 -
Transported for Seven Years .

2088.
JOHN BURNELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July
, 9 lamps, value 4l.; 2 oil-cups, value 3s.; 1 glass-holder, value 18d.; 2 lamp-glasses, value 1s.; 6 lamp-values, 18d.; 3 pairs of scissors, value 4s.; 4 wick-holders, value 16d.; 6 knobs, value 6d., and 4 lamp-buttons, value 1s., the goods of
William Brookes
, his master ; and
ZALICK WORMS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute.
MESSERS. PHILLIPS and CHURCHILL conducted the prosecution.

MATTHEW BAYFIELD
. I am in the service of Mr.
William Brookes
, a lamp-manufacturer ; Burnell was in his employ. On the 24th of July I was informed some of our lamps were exposed for sale on Saffron-hill; I went and bought at the shop of Mr. Ince, this chamber-lamp; it was on the evening of the 24th of July - I afterwards purchased another at the shop of Worms; and in consequence of that, I took the number of the lamps contained in the drawers, and in our counting-house - on the morning of the 25th a chamber-lamp was taken away; I then gave information to Waddington, at Hatton-garden - next morning there was nothing missed; on the morning of the 27th of July I had Burnell apprehended - I went to Worms' with Waddington and Cooper; we found on the mantel-piece, a pocket-book containing some duplicates, and amongst them several for lamps, and concealed in a child's crib, under the bed, we found these new bronze pieces of a lamp, and some other pieces in the shop; they are my master's.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you give instructions for apprehending Burnell on the 25th? A. Yes; he was taken on the 27th - this globe-vase and some other things were found on him; he had been nearly two years in Mr. Brookes' employ - Worms keeps a small broker's-shop on Saffron-hill; I saw some articles belonging to my master exposed for sale in Worms' window; when I bought the lamp, but not when we made the search.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I am a Police-officer. I watched Burnell from Mr. Brookes', on the 27th of July-I stopped him on Saffron-hill; I found in his hat a globevase, this chamber-lamp in one pocket, and these other articles in another pocket - I asked what he was going to do with them; he said to make money of them, and he was sorry for what he had done.

JOSEPH COOPER
. I went to search Worm's house; I found in the fire-place these two chimney-glasses, and this part of a lamp; Waddington handed to me this pocketbook, in which I found some duplicates which led to other lamps - on the fire-place I found a pair of scissors, and another pair in some drawers in the shop - I told Worms we came to look for some lamps; he denied having any thing of the kind, but said we might search his place, but we had no right without a warrant; we then searched; he was very turbulent, and said he would not go with us -Waddington's time was taken up in taking care of him; he said he could produce a catalogue of a sale at which he had bought some lamps - when we got him into custody I took him to Burnell; I asked if he knew that man; he said he did, and it was useless to deny it - I said, "Did you let him have this property?" he said, "Yes, all but these chimney-glasses and the scissors."

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did not Burnell tell you that he had taken these things to Worms' at different times? A. No; he said he had sold him the property, but he did not say when - I was not with Waddington when he took Burnell, but I joined him before he locked him up, about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's, and about three minutes walk from Worms' - he was passing by a turning which led to Worms', but not coming from there - it was about nine o'clock in the morning.

JOSEPH INCE
. I am a broker, and live on Great Saffronhill. I bought a duplicate of a lamp of Worms, on the 17th of July, which the officers afterwards took away, but I was not at home - I believe this is it.

WILLIAM MURDOCH
. I am in the service of a pawnbroker. I have a lamp, pawned at our shop by a woman, on the 2nd of July.

MARY BAYLE
. I live in Worms' house - his wife is in a bad state of health. I was often called down to go on errands for him; I took one lamp to pawn for him, in Baldwin's-gardens, but I do not know the day of the month- I pawned two at Mr. Nicholls', in Gray's Inn-lane, and one at the corner of Liquorpond-street - they were all in my own name; the one I pawned with Murdoch was in Mr. Worms' name as well; I should not know any of them again.

HENRY LONG
. I am in the service of Mr. Nicholls. I have a lamp, and part of another, pawned by Bayle on the 3rd of April and the 24th of March.

GEORGE BUCKLAND
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I have one lamp, pawned on the 22nd of June - it was taken in by a young man, who has now left us.

BURNELL -
GUILTY . Aged 44.
Transported for Seven Years .

WORMS -
NOT GUILTY .

2089.
ELIZA BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 table-cloth, value 20s.; 12 handkerchiefs, value 1l.; 21 napkins, value 3l.; 2 shifts, value5s., and 2 aprons, value 3s. , the goods of
William Willshen
.

FRANCES WILLSHEN
. I am the wife of
William Willshen
- we live in Middlesex-street
. The prisoner was living in our house as servant ; she lived there five days - she went away without notice, and then I missed these articles.

SIMON TAMPION
. I am a shoemaker; I lodge in the house of the prosecutor. I saw the prisoner go out at ten minutes past seven o'clock, on the 26th of July - she had a bundle with her, and never returned.

JOSEPH TURWEN
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a tablecloth pawned by the prisoner on the 1st of August.

CHARLES MAYHEW
(Police-constable E 152.) I have some other articles, which I got from different pawnbrokers.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2090.
THOMAS CHARLES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 book, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Larkin
.

MARY LARKIN
. I am the wife of
Thomas Larkin
, of Old-street-road
- he is a bookseller . On the 6th of August I was told this book was taken; I went out, and found the prisoner twenty doors off with it - he was quite a stranger; he was running.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . - Aged 35. -
Judgment Respited .

2091.
ELIZA WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of July , 18 pincushions, value 7s.; 84 combs, value 14s., and 4 fans, value 10s. , the goods of
David Hicks
.

DAVID HICKS
. I live in the City-road
. I am a turner and toy-dealer . These articles were packed up, and directed to go to Portsmouth; they were taken from my shop, and some time afterwards a man in my employ was going up Hackney-road and saw these pincushions - I saw the prisoner eight or nine days afterwards in custody; I have lost property to a great amount, but I only swear to the pincushions, though I have no doubt they are all mine.

MARY ANN MILLER
. I live in Hackney-road. I bought these pincushions of the prisoner in exchange for a petticoat and a shilling, in the early part of July - she said they were her uncles; she had been at my shop for second-hand clothes, which I sell.

ALLEN CAMERON
(Police-constable N 91). I took the prisoner by Miller's direction on the 1st of August; she was then there with these other cushions and four fans, which she said were given to her by a girl.

LOUISA BUTLER
. I am the prisoner's sister. She asked me to wash her a cap, and I found these combs in it.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Three Months .

2092.
ELIZABETH TUCKWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of July , 1 pair of sheets, value 1s. 6d.; 1 dish, value 1s.; 2 pillows, value 2s.; 1 blanket, value 6d.; 1 saucepan, value 2s.; 1 tea-kettle, value 2s.; 1 iron pot value 2s., and 1 candlestick, value 6d. , the goods of
Edward Maddle
.

ANN MADDLE
. I am the wife of
Edward Maddle
- we live at No. 14, Upper Charlton-street, Fitzroy-square
. On the 13th of July the prisoner took a lodging of us as a married woman, but no man came there - she staid in our back kitchen till the 22nd, and then left without notice, and we missed the articles stated; my husband found her in Oxford-street, quite accidentally.
Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Was she there when you missed the articles? A. No; a young man had fetched her away.

MARIA MADDEN
. I bought of the prisoner this iron pot, these sheets, and some other articles - she said they were her own.
Cross-examined. Q. How long was she in your shop? A. A quarter of an hour.

SAMUEL APPLEBY
(Police-constable E 28). I took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Three Months .

2093.
THOMAS BROOKERY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of June , 1 coat, value 4l.; 1 waistcoat, value 16s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 2l., the goods of
Joshua Lloyd
, from the person of
Thomas Anderson
.

THOMAS ANDERSON
. I am errand-boy to Mr. Joshua Lloyd - he is a tailor
, and lives in Conduit-street. On the 16th of June I had a parcel, which contained a coat, waistcoat, and a pair of trousers, to take to Mr. Pontifex, at Holloway; there was Mr. Pontifex's direction on it - two different men came up to me; they spoke to me on the way, and looked at the direction on the parcel; when I got near to Holloway
, the prisoner, whom I had not seen before, came up, and asked if I came from Mr. Lloyd, in Conduit-street - I said I did; he then asked me if these things were for Mr. Pontifex, of Holloway - I said they were; the other two men were not there then - the prisoner said Mr. Pontifex was waiting for the things to go out; I gave him the things, and he gave me 1d. - when he got a few yards from me, he said he would give me 6d. when he saw me again, and that Mr. Pontifex was to be measured for some more things on the Monday following; the other two men were afterwards tried here, and convicted.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. What day of the week was this? A. Saturday evening; I had had tea at five o'clock; I went out after tea - I heard the clock strike nine when I got to Camden-town, before the prisoner came up to me; I had not seen him before; he did not stay long talking with me, but I am sure he is the person - I knew him by his face; it was not quite dark - I did not see him with any other person.
- ROBERTS. I am in the employ of Mr. Lloyd. I sent the parcel by this witness on the 16th of June; I packed it and directed it - I have not seen it since.
Cross-examined. Q. What night was it? A. On Saturday night, the 16th of June - I know nothing of the prisoner.

JOHN STACEY
(Police-constable F 12.) I took the prisoner in consequence of information - I had been looking for him for some time.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you not seen him once beforeyou took him? A. Yes, but I was ill, and he was on the top of an omnibus - I did not hail it.
Witnesses for the Defence.

GEORGE HIGHFIELD
. I am a hatter, and live at No. 22, Cumberland-street, Middlesex-hospital. I know the prisoner - on the 16th of June I was in his company from seven o'clock till twelve; I took a hat home to his brother and stopped there till about nine - Mr. Hagan came in about eight, and we went to the Mogul, where we stopped till twelve.

COURT. Q. What day was this? A. On Saturday night, the 16th of June - I know very little of the prisoner, but his brother I am intimate with; he is a fishmonger, and the prisoner assisted him - he was at his brother's when I took the hat home; Mr. Hagan then came in, and we went to the Mogul - his brother mentioned the circumstance to me, and then I recollected it; I cannot tell where I was on the 26th, 27th, or 28th - I suppose I was in my business, but on the 16th I know I took the hat home to the prisoner's brother; I gave him a bill and receipt, and got an order from Mr. Hagan the same night - it was about seven o'clock when I got there, and we did not part till twelve at night; I took the hat home to Mr. Hagan the next Saturday night - we had some half and half at the Mogul; I do not recollect having any spirits, and we had no wine.

- HAGAN. I am a tailor, and live at No. 22, Rupert-street, Haymarket. I know the prisoner perfectly well; on the evening of the 16th of June I went to his brother's, in Lumber-court, to give an order to Mr. Highfield for a hat - he had brought a hat home that night for the prisoner's brother; the prisoner was there; I went there about a quarter before nine o'clock, and the prisoner, Mr. Highfield, and I went to a concert at the Great Mogul, in Drury-lane, and remained there till twelve o'clock.

COURT. Q. What time did you leave his brother's? A. It might be ten minutes or a quarter past nine o'clock- I had gone there about nine, or a little before; I had been to the Mogul once before; the prisoner was at his brother's when I went there - he was serving in the shop part of the time; Mr. Highfield was there when I got there- I do not know Mr. Lloyd, nor Mr. Pontifex; I never heard of Holloway - I have seen the prisoner since the 16th of June, driving a cab and an omnibus.

COURT to
JOHN STACEY
. Q. When did you receive the information? A. Two or three days after the robbery, and I looked night and day for him; I took him on the last day of August - he was sitting alongside the driver of an omnibus; he drove a cab before the 16th of June, but I never saw him drive one afterwards.

- HAGAN re-examined. Q. Who did he drive for? A. I do not know - I really never noticed what sort of a cab it was, nor what number; I did not know any one was looking for him - I saw him twice in Holborn, and once in Oxford-street; I had drank with him repeatedly before the 16th of June - I cannot tell the date; when I saw him driving a cab - I did not take notice of it; I cannot say when I saw him in Holborn - it might be five weeks ago; I cannot tell the month - it must have been in July - I cannot tell what coloured cab it was; I think it was a bay horse - I nodded to him; he had a fare at the time - I believe he never had a cab of his own.
PETER BROOKERY
. I am the prisoner's brother. On the 16th of June my brother was sitting with me till near nine o'clock; he lived with me at the time - he was not out in the evening; Mr. Highfield brought me home this hat, which I have now in my hand - Mr. Hagan came there at the time; they and my brother went out together - I live in Lumber-court; I was born in the house, and my father kept it for thirty years before - my brother has been driving an omnibus latterly; before that he was driving a cab, and before that he lived with me.

COURT. Q. What time did he come home that evening? A. About five or six o'clock; he might have been out for five or ten minutes; I do not think he was out half an hour- he was not driving a cab that day - he went out about nine o'clock with these two witnesses; I heard of the charge the night he was taken, and then I recollected this; he had driven an omnibus since the latter end of June, I think - I believe he has driven a cab during that period; he left me about the latter end of June - I did not hear of this robbery till he was taken; I never heard he was being looked after - I do not know what omnibus he drove; he drove one twelve months ago - I cannot tell what time he left me - he had driven cabs and omnibusses before he came to me; I think he had driven a cab since - I cannot tell what coloured horse he drove; one cab may have different coloured horses.
THOMAS ANDERSON. I described to the officer the person who robbed me; I am sure the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Life .
OLD COURT. FRIDAY, JULY 14.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2094.
DANIEL NEWHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 cap, value 3s.; 1 waistcoat, value 5s.; 4 sheets, value 5s.; 3 razors, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Roberts
. - To which he pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2095.
JAMES GRAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September, 10 sacks, value 6s. , the goods of
Isaac Martin
.

ISAAC MARTIN. I keep a coal-shed in Princes-street, Westminster. I lost ten sacks out of my cart, which stood in my yard in Dean-street
.

ROBERT GOOSE
, I am an officer. I found these ten sacks at McGrath's.

JOHN McGRATH
. I am a carman. The prisoner came to me on the Tuesday before this happened, and asked if master would lend him his cart to draw some coals; my master consented; he told me to meet him at Westminsterbridge, and he would have the sacks there ready to fetch the coals from Davey and Co.'s - I received these sacks from him.
Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. You were taken for this? A. Yes - the sacks were in my possession from seven o'clock in the evening till nine in the morning.

ISAAC MARTIN
. I cannot saw how they were taken - my gate was not broken open.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner deals in coals? A.Yes - many people have carts in the same yard, and they all have a key; I have lent sacks to the prisoner - I was out that day, so that he could not see me to ask my leave.
NOT GUILTY .

2096.
ROBERT HORN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 veil, value 10s. , the goods of
James Thyer
.

OLIVIA THYER
. I am the wife of James Thyer; he is a saddler . On the 30th of August, between half-past three and four o'clock, I was in King-street, Covent-garden, returning from the City; I had been to see some friends from the country - my husband was not with me; I saw the prisoner in King-street, in company with another - the prisoner came, and asked me to go and have some gin; I refused - they followed me to Berwick-street
, and asked me several times to have gin - the prisoner came, and again asked me to have gin - I refused, and he snatched my veil off my bonnet and ran through a court; I called Stop thief! and followed - when I got into Wardour-street the Policeman had got him.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where had you been? A. To No. 21, Shoe-lane - I cannot tell at what time I left; I walked as fast as I could - I was not tipsy; I had only taken part of a pot of half-and-half - I should have left at twelve o'clock, but it rained; I had been in Farringdon-street with my friends to see the illuminations; the prisoner did not insult me, further than asking me to have gin - they followed me sometimes behind and sometimes at my side.

SAMUEL GODDARD
. I am a Policeman. I was in Wardour-street, and heard a cry of Stop thief! the prisoner and another ran out of Tyler's-court - I laid hold of them; the prosecutrix came up, and charged them with stealing her veil; I could not find it.

SARAH SKELTON
. I picked up the veil in Tyler's-court, about five o'clock in the morning, and gave it to the constable.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the prosecutrix under the Piazza, quite intoxicated - she could hardly stand; I walked with her to Berwick-street, and as we parted she was going to fall; I went to take hold of her, and her veil came off - she accused me of stealing it, and not wishing to get into trouble I ran off.

SAMUEL GODDARD
. The prosecutrix was not intoxicated; she had been drinking, but told her story as she has now.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Three Months .
Before Mr. Recorder.

2097.
JAMES BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 2 half-crowns, 12 shillings, and 12 sixpences , the monies of
John Johnson
.

LUCY JOHNSON
. I am the wife of John Johnson, a cheesemonger . On the 30th of August, about eight o'clock in evening, I was in the parlour, and heard somebody in the shop - I got up to wait on them, and as I opened the parlour door I saw a lad come from behind the counter; I was alarmed, but as soon as I recovered I said, "Here is a thief in the shop;" my daughter said, "It is Brown's boy;" the prisoner's father lives near me; I went to the till, and all the money but one shilling was gone - I had seen it safe ten minutes before.

ELIZA JOHNSON
. I was in the parlour, and saw my mother go into the shop - I saw the prisoner go out on his hands and knees; I am certain of him - I have known him a long while, and cannot be mistaken; when he got to the door he stood up, and looked down the street - I told my mother, and he was taken next morning.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not say it was my brother? A. I said it was Brown's eldest son, but did not then know there was one older than the prisoner - I am sure it was him; I know there were two bright shillings in the till, and one black one, which I had taken from a sweep.

JOHN PANNEL
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner going towards London-fields - he was counting money in his hand; he kept it in his hand till he got to the watch-house; he asked me several times what I wanted him for, and I did not satisfy him - when I got to the watchhouse I told him the charge; he had 7s. in his hand, and pulled out 10s. more from his pocket - before
Eliza Johnson
saw the money she said there were two bright shillings and one black one among them - there is a very dark shilling and two bright ones; the prisoner said his brother had lent him the money, and he was going to buy a pair of shoes and trousers with it.
Prisoner's Defence. My brother lent me 18s. at the Woolpack.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2098.
HENRY HUGHES
was
indicted for embezzlement .

EDWARD MILLARD
. I am a farmer , and live at Cranfield in Bedfordshire. I had some beasts at Smithfield; the prisoner was keeping them for me, as a drover . On the 3rd of August I sold a cow and calf; he was to drive them to Mr. Palmer, in Marylebone
, to whom I sold them, and bring back 16l. - he was to meet me at the Pied Bull, public-house, Holloway; he was not in my service, but merely the drover - he was employed by me at different times; he never brought me the money; I saw him again on the 28th of August - I was looking for him for two nights without success.

JOHN HEIGHT
. I am servant to Mr. Palmer. The prisoner brought the cow and calf to my master, on Friday, the 3d of August, with a note; I paid him 16l., myself, in gold; Millard came the next morning to inquire about it - I told him I had paid the prisoner.

Prisoner. He did not pay me. Witness. I am sure I did, and on the 28th, I saw him at Hatton-garden, but the prosecutor not having come from the country, he was discharged, he had not left the office twenty yards before the prosecutor came and he was taken again; when he was discharged, he asked me how it was Millard did not appear against him - I said I did not know, and said,"Harry, did you think of keeping this money, and spending it before you received it;" he said Yes, I did; I concluded what I would do with it as I came along; I thought Millard could afford to lose it, and I stuck to it like a cock, and spent every farthing."

HENRY SWAIN
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner, and told him it was for absconding with 16l.; he said, "Blood into me, I don't think I shall go."

Prisoner's Defence. I received 16l. 2s. from the gentleman, at the Yorkshire Stingo; he gave me threeglasses of ale, and told me to go home; I met a young man at Battle-bridge, and got intoxicated, and when I came to myself, found all the money was gone.

GUILTY. Aged 20. -
Judgment Respited
.

2099.
DANIEL LAMBERT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 coat, value 3l.; 3 waistcoats, value 16s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 18s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; 1 shaving-box, value 2s., and 1 rule, value 1s. , the goods of
William Thompson
.

WILLIAM THOMPSON. I live in Hartshorn-court, Golden-lane
; the prisoner lodged in the same room with me. I missed these things from different drawers, on the 31st of July - I had not seen them after that; I saw the prisoner in about six hours, and told him I suspected him; he said he had pawned them, and told me where, but I have not found the clothes - the things altogether were worth 5l.; I never authorized him to pawn them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you never authorize him to pledge any thing? A. Never; I never agreed not to prosecute if he would pay me 6s. a week - I am porter to Messrs. Hale and Co., oilmen.

HENRY PRINCE
. I am foreman to Mr. Galloway at times. On the 31st of July, about two o'clock in the afternoon, the prosecutor, having missed his things, told me to search for the prisoner, and about half-past four o'clock, I saw him in the room, and asked what he had done with Bill's things - he cried, and said he had taken and pawned them at the corner of Worship-street; I went there next day, but the pawnbroker had left; the prisoner gave me the duplicate, which I gave the Policeman.

Cross-examined. Q. You asked where he pawned them? A. Yes; he said the house was shut up, but the goods were to be delivered in Newgate-street; but there was a board on the house referring to Mr. Joyce of the New-road; I have known the prisoner fourteen years; I never said the prosecutor had agreed to take 6s. a week not to prosecute.

SAMUEL KNAPP
. My father is a pawnbroker in Golden-lane. I have a shaving-box and rule, pawned on the 31st of July, for 8d., in the name of
Thomas Smith
- I cannot say who by.

RICHARD COTTER
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner; he cried, and said he had given the duplicates to Prince, who gave them to me; one of them has the name of Pickford on it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner delivered in a petition, expressing his contrition.

EDWARD HANDS
. I am an officer of St. Luke's. Prince told me the prosecutor had agreed that the prisoner should pay down 9s., and 5s. a week, and he would not prosecute him; this was about four o'clock in the afternoon - the prisoner was taken that night.
GUILTY. Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Fourteen Days .

2100.
JOHN WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 watch, value 5l.; 1 seal, value 10s., and 1 key, value 5s., the goods of
William Scott
, from his person .

WILLIAM SCOTT
. I am a lighterman , and live at Rotherhithe. On the 20th of August, about nine o'clock in the evening, I was coming out of the Minories, down by St. Katharine's-dock wall
- I was sober; the prisoner and three more were coming towards me; they separated, two on each side of me; the prisoner was close to me - he caught hold of my ribbon, and snatched my watch with great violence - he dragged the ribbon right through the loop-hole; the two on the left went into the road - the other, who was with him, went on the right side; I ran after the prisoner, calling Stop him! he was taken in my sight, with my watch in his hand.
Prisoner. It was done in a very dark place. Witness. Quite the reverse, it is lighted with gas all the way.

JOHN DEMPSEY
. I am a Policeman. I was opposite the Mint, and heard a cry - I stopped the prisoner, and found the watch in his hand; Scott came up and charged him with the robbery.
Prisoner's Defence. I heard a cry of Stop thief! and saw a man throw something down; I took up the watch, and gave it to the Policeman.

WILLIAM SCOTT
. I remarked his face, and am certain he is the man who took it.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Life .

2101.
ALFRED COOK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 spoon, value 12s. , the goods of
Thomas Rugless
.

ELIZA RUGLESS
. I am the daughter of
Thomas Rugless
, who keeps a confectioner's-shop in Picadilly
. On Friday, the 24th of August, the prisoner came into the shop for a basin of mock-turtle soup; I took it into the soup-room with a spoon, and in a very few minutes he called me into the room, and gave me half a crown - I gave him 1s. 6d.; he had only eat half the soup; he left in a very short time, and as he went out, I went into the room, and missed the spoon - my father went after him, and he was taken in a pawnbroker's shop; I saw the spoon at the office the same evening, and am quite sure it is my father's - I have cleaned it for many years; there are no initials on it.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How do you know it? A. By the pattern; nobody came in or went out of the room before I missed it - we had no other customer.

NATHANIEL BARNES
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 24th of July, between four and five o'clock, the prisoner came to pawn this table-spoon; Mr. Rugless came in and took him before I advanced the money.
Prisoner. Q. If you wanted a quantity of these spoons, could you not obtain them very readily? A. Certainly.

CHARLES BAKER
. I am a serjeant of the Police. Mr. Rugless brought the prisoner to the station-house, charged with stealing the spoon, which Barnes delivered to me; the prisoner gave no account of it.
ELIZA RUGLESS. I am quite certain of this spoon; the prisoner never claimed it as his own - I know it from a mark on it; a flaw - my father followed him immediately.
Prisoner's Defence. I purchased it of a dealer, which is customary in the trade I followed.
CHARLES BAKER. He told the Magistrate he purchaseda pair of spectacles at the same time, which I found the duplicate of in his pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2102.
LYDIA ANDERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 4 gowns, value 24s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3d.; 2 gowns, value 4s., and 4 caps, value 4s. , the goods of
Hannah Parsons
.

HANNAH PARSONS
. I live in North-street, Chelsea
. The prisoner lodged in the same room with me for a week; I missed these things from my drawer on the 14th of August, at half-past eleven o'clock - they were safe the night before; the prisoner was absent, and did not return that night - I saw her next morning, and charged her with stealing them; she said, "Pray, don't hurt me, I was going to bring them back" - I found two of my gowns at her mother's; she had one of them on, with a cap and petticoat.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned a gown with me, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, on the 15th of August.

THOMAS BRANSTON
. I am a Policeman. I took her in charge; she had one gown on - I found two gowns at her mother's, in Great Peter-street.(Gowns produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had been compelled to resort to prostitution; that she had been on terms of intimacy with the prosecutrix, and that they were constantly in the habit of wearing each other's clothes.

HANNAH PARSONS
. I did not give her leave to pawn my clothes; I did not give her leave to wear any of these things - I lent her a shawl; I have not gone by different names.

WILLIAM DAVIS
. I am a jeweller, and live in Crown-street. The prosecutrix lodges in a house of mine; she was brought home tipsy last Saturday night by a Policeman, in a coach, and said she was robbed of half a sovereign, and accused five or six people of it; I think her word ought not to be taken - she told me last Sunday that she was in the habit of lending the prisoner clothes, and gave her leave to pawn them; I have told her to leave my house- she has been there three weeks, and brought home a stranger every night.

HANNAH PARSONS
. I never told him I gave her leave to pawn my clothes; he was always asking me to come and live at his house - he keeps a bad house.

WILLIAM DAVIS
. I let my rooms to men and women, single as well as married; the prosecutrix answers to three different names.

SARAH KIERNEY
. I live at No. 11, Crown-street; the prosecutrix and prisoner formerly lodged there, and were intimate - Parsons used to dress her in the greatest style, and said she need not want clothes while she lived there, she would always lend her them to pledge; and the prisoner used to give her what money she got - they both absconded from my house, taking their clothes out of window.
NOT GUILTY .

2103.
MARY ANN AUSTIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., 6d. , the goods of
Asher Daniel Humphries
.

ELIZABETH HUMPHRIES. I am the wife of
Asher Daniel Humphries
, and have not seen him for five years; I live in Ironmonger-row, St. Luke's
- I take in washing. The prisoner kept a school in the front-parlour ; I saw this handkerchief laying with dirty linen at twelve o'clock, and missed it between three and four - the prisoner had looked at it that morning, and said it was a pretty one; when I told her I missed it, she said it was a very wicked thing to rob the widow and fatherless.

JAMES COOK
. I am a shopman to Mr. Russel, in Fore-street. This handkerchief was pawned on the 22nd of August, by the prisoner, in her own name and address.

THOMAS DOWLEY
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended her, and found eighteen duplicates on her - but none for the handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Three Months .

2104.
GEORGE ANSLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
John Stevens
, his master .

THOMAS KING
. I am servant to
John Stevens
, a butcher , at Harrow
; the prisoner and I were in his service together. The prisoner came in at seven o'clock in the evening, and said, "Go and get a truss of hay for the horses;" he returned and said he had got it, and wanted half a crown to pay for it - I was serving a customer in the shop at the time; he went into the parlour where the money was - there was 3s. 8 1/2d. in the bowl; I saw him at the cupboard; I went into the parlour, and caught him at the cupboard - I said, "You have been robbing your master;" he said he had not, and dropped some money: I sent for the officer, who found 1s. 7d. where he sat - I have not found the other 2s.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. He went to get the money for the hay? A. No - he said he would go and get something to eat; he must have thrown the two shillings out of window, for I did not find them.

JAMES ROWE
. I am a constable. I found 1s. 7d. by the prisoner's chair, and 2 1/2d. in his pocket; he said he did not take the money.
NOT GUILTY .

2105.
JOHN ATKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 poker, value 1s.; 1 shovel, value 2s., and 1 pair of tongs, value 5s., the goods of
Catherine Whitfield
and another .

CATHERINE WHITFIELD. I am a broker and live in Old-street
. These fire-irons were taken from outside my door; I did not see the prisoner near.

GEORGE BLACKMAN
. I am a tailor, and live two or three doors from the prosecutrix. The prisoner passed with these things in his hand; I followed and took him: he dropped them.

AUGUSTUS PENMAN
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner running, and secured him.(Property produced and sworn to)

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined One Month .

2106.
MARY ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 5 napkins, value 18d.; 1 bed-gown, value 9d., and 1 night-jacket, value 1s. , the goods of
Richard Silver
.

RICHARD SILVER. I am a silk-weaver , and live in Hare-street, Bethnal-green
; the prisoner was sent from Bethnal-green workhouse to nurse my wife in her confinement. On Sunday, the 12th of August, when I came home to dine, there was no dinner cooked, and she had left my wife in bed unable to help herself - I missed these things; she came again on Monday; I said, "Where are the things you have taken away, belonging to the Benevolent Society-box? tell me, or you will get me into disgrace;" she then told me, and I found them.

SARAH BAILEY
. I keep a clothes-shop near Bethnalgreen. The prisoner brought me a bed-gown, five napkins, and a jacket; I gave her 1s. 3d. for them - they are very old; I did not observe the society's stamp on them till it was shown to me.

JOHN CARPENTER
. I am a Policeman. I have the property; some of it is very old.

Prisoner's Defence. His wife asked me to go and pawn something belonging to the box - I refused; she sent her boy to pawn them - the following week she asked me again, and I pawned some for 3s.; I was taken ill, and asked this woman to lend me 1s. 3d. on these things - I was to return it again; I told his wife what I had done - she said I was welcome.

GUILTY . Aged 52. -
Confined Six Months .

2107.
ANN BRADY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 2 pairs of boots, value 10s. , the goods of
Joseph Hester
.

JOSEPH HESTER. I am a boot and shoemaker , and live in Crown-street, Finsbury
. On the 24th of August, about two o'clock, the prisoner and another came into my shop to buy a pair of shoes; several pairs fitted them, but they objected to them - the other went out, and just as the prisoner was going out, I stopped her, and asked what she was going to do with the boots she had got, as I missed two pairs off a rail; I found one pair under her arm, under her shawl - she said she was going to pay for them- she had before denied having them; I have not found the other pair.

WILLIAM DAMAN
. I am a Policeman. I received her in charge; she said she had money in her pocket to pay for them - I found 6d. in silver, and 6d. in copper, on her.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2108.
JOHN BROOKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Thomas Clark
.

THOMAS CLARK
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Upper Marylebone-street
. The prisoner was nearly eleven months in my employ; I gave him the materials to make four pairs of shoes, on a Saturday, and on the Monday he was taken in the act of selling a pair of shoes, which are mine, and have my mark on them - I cannot say whether they were what he had to make - I never knew any thing against him.

PETER CANE
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner on the 3rd of September, offering these boots to a Jew for sale - he folded them up in a handkerchief, and walked off, on seeing me; I followed him to Manchestersquare, and asked how he came by them - he said he made them for a tailor's wife; they did not fit, and he wanted to sell them; he said he lived in Clipstone-street; I found he did not live there - he begged me not to take him, and then said it was work his master gave him, and when finished, instead of taking it home, he wanted to sell it - when I got near the station, he ran off, but I never lost sight of him; he said at the office that he stole them from his employer in Tottenham-court-road, but did not know the name or number.(Property produced and sworn to).
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined One Month .

2109.
WILLIAM CASTLE
and
JOSEPH SKELTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , a skittle-ball, value 2s. , the goods of
John Willis
.

CHARLES HOLLAND
. I live with John Willis, a turner , in Kingsland-road
. I missed this skittle-ball out of a little carriage, in the shop.

RICHARD HAWKES
. I am a Policeman. On the 6th of September I saw the prisoners together; they went up Kingsland-road, and stopped at a public-house next door to Willis'; I afterwards stopped them, and found a skittle-ball on Skelton; he said he found it - I had seen him take it(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoners received a good characcer.

CASTLE -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

SKELTON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Fined 1s., and delivered to their former employer .

2010.
CORNELIUS DRISCOLL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 shawl, value 1l. , the goods of
William Henry Pearce
.

WILLIAM HENRY PEARCE
. I live in Rosamond-place, Limehouse. On the 21st of August, early in the morning, the shawl was on the neck of my child, which a friend was carrying - he is not here; I had occasion to stop behind, and as I came on I saw the prisoner take the shawl off the ground; I said, "My friend, this is my property;" he said, "I wish you may get it," and run across the road-I followed; he said, "You may run, and be d - d;" I cannot say that he saw it fall from the child, which had gone on about thirty yards.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Where is your friend? A. Not here; I have not seen him since - I told the prisoner it was mine, and he ran off with it; I do not believe he saw it dropped - I had asked him about a minute before what he stood there for; this was before he took the shawl.

JAMES PYE
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner in Penny's-fields, Poplar, running; the prosecutor was following, calling Stop thief! I took the shawl from under his jacket.

JOHN BENT
. I am a Police-constable. About two o'clock in the morning I was with Pye, and heard the alarm; I received the prisoner - he said he had picked the shawl up in the road; I asked if nobody claimed it - he said Yes, there was a man claimed it; I took him back, and met the prosecutor.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up in the road.

GUILTY . Aged 36. -
Confined One Month .

2011.
HENRY FLANDERS
was indicted for
stealing,on the 30th of August , 9 lbs. of ham, value 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Francis Dovey
.

JOSEPH HAYNES
. I am in the employ of
Thomas Francis Dovey
, a cheesemonger , of Shoreditch
. The ham was taken from the window, and the prisoner brought back with it - I saw it safe half an hour before; it was half a ham.

JAMES BLAKE
. I am a Policeman. Haynes took me to a public-house, where I saw the prisoner; we asked what he had got - he said a bit of ham, that he took it from a shop in Shoreditch; we took it back, and matched it with the other half.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty, and received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 41. -
Confined One Month .

2112.
ANN FORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s.; 2 shillings, and 1 sixpences , the property of
James King
.

ANN KING
. I am the wife of
James King
, a tailor - we live in Long-alley, Moorfields. I had got a little drop to drink, and got into the watch-house; the prisoner was there, and stripped these things off me - I saw the apron on her.

WILLIAM BARTLET
. I am a Policeman. I was at the watch-house; the prosecutrix was brought in drunk; I took the prisoner there about noon, for a riot, and breaking a window; she had been drinking - when I let the prosecutrix out she complained that the prisoner had her apron on, and she missed a handkerchief - the prisoner gave her the apron, and she took the handkerchief out of the prisoner's bosom.
Prisoner. I picked it up after the prosecutrix went out- four of my family have died since I have been here.
NOT GUILTY .

1930.
JOHN FRANCIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 2 pewter pots, value 18d., the goods of
Andrew Morris
; and I pewter pot, value 1s., the goods of
George Kerridge
.

RICHARD MORRIS
. I keep a public-house in Piccadilly
. I found two pots at the office, with my name and sign on them.

GEORGE KERRIDGE
. I keep a public-house in Belgrave-square
. I found the prisoner in custody with a pot of mine.

FRANCIS KEYS
. I am an officer of Marylebone. On the 8th of August, about seven o'clock in the morning, I received information, and watched by a cellar in Carey-street, St. Giles' - I saw the prisoner go to the cellar, pull the flap open, and go down; I went down after him - I could hardly, see it was so dark - I said, "What is your name?" I believe he said Francis - I said, "Come to the light" - he threw his hat off, and I found two pewter pots in it; I found a string tied round his waist, with another pot suspended to it, concealed; I proceeded to search the cellar, and he tried to escape - I pulled him back, and in the cellar found this frying-pan, with metal sticking to it.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2060.
FREDERICK FINLEY
and ANN, his wife , were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 2 pairs of shoes, value 2s., and 2 caps, value 1s. the goods of
John King
.

JOHN KING. I am a dealer in marine-stores , on Saffron-hill
. I missed these things from my shop, on the 18th of August - I had seen them two or three days before; the prisoners lodged in my house, and slept in a little parlour, and would pass through the shop to go out - they lodged about three weeks with me; I found the things at Loscombe's, No. 113, Saffron-hill, on the 20th, and knew them by the marks - they are children's caps; one pair of shoes is sown all roundthe other has a patch in the heel.

Frederick Finley
. Q. Did you ever go by any other name? A. I went by the name of Wilson, in the army, for twenty-five years; I am illegitimate, but that was my father's name - I receive a pension in that name, but I was Christened by the name of
John King
; I was bail for Mr. Pollock in the court of King'sbench, for 35l., - I can bail for 500l. if I choose; I had lost a quantity of goods, and refused to let you into my house that night, but told you to go to bed, and next morning you left; you once lost your child, and I said it was probably through your own drunkenness.

ELIZA LOSCOMBE
