. I live at No. 113, Saffron-hill. On the 16th of August the male prisoner sold me a pair of shoes for 5d., and on the 18th another pair for 5d.; I received three child's caps, a woman's cap and tippet from the female prisoner for 8d.
Prisoner. Q. Are your goods exposed for sale? A. Yes, outside and inside the shop; I live thirty-six doors from King.

JOHN GOODMAN
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner on the 21st of August; the man said he did not care, he should easily get over it - I found them in an uninhabited house, in Castle-street, Saffron-hill.

Frederick Finley
. Q. How was it uninhabited? A. It was not rented by any tenant; a person had leave to be in it, and he was cohabiting with her.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Frederick Finley
's Defence. I have endeavoured to elicit from the prosecutor, the fact of a serious quarrel between us, in consequence of his accusing me of having intentionally lost my child - in consequence of this, I availed myself of the information I had of his having bailed Pollock in the name of King, and justifying in the name of Wilson, and informed Mrs. Pollock of it, and she refused to pay him 10s. for having been bail; I believe she wrote to say, if he attempted to make the claim, she would see into it - he received the letter on the Monday, and made this charge; I admit selling the things, but distinctly at his request; his wife as he calls her, not supplying him with funds to procure liquor; if I had stolen them, I should not have sold them so near his house.

FREDERICK FINLEY
. -
GUILTY Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

ANN FINLEY
. -
NOT GUILTY .

2015.
CAROLINE HUGHES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 1 shirt, value 15d. , the goods of
John Parry
.

PHOEBE PARRY
. I am the wife of
John Parry
-we live in Playhouse-yard
; I keep the whole house-a neighbour gave me information - I turned my head and missed the shirt from the ironing-board; I found the prisoner at Worship-street with it; she occasionally called at my house - she is married, but does not live with her husband; it was taken while I left my house for two minutes, as a girl had fetched me.

SARAH PRICE
. I live in Playhouse-yard. I knew the prisoner by sight before this; a girl was sent to tell the prosecutrix she was wanted, and while she was gone I saw the prisoner go inside the door, and put something into her apron - I am quite certain she held her apron up when she went in; I saw her take something white off the ironing-board, and put it into her apron-I went over and told Parry of it; the prisoner was taken in charge at the time for another robbery -I saw her at Worship-street when the shirt was produced.

EDMUND HARGRAVE
. I took the prisoner into custody on the 18th on another charge - I found her in a privy belonging to a court; she ran into the privy on seeing me - I followed her in; this shirt was put into the privy, but would not go down, in consequence of the spont.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the shirt; I did not go farther than the prosecutrix's door, and asked the little girl to go to call her out - I asked if her husband had seen mine - I was taken ill, and went into the privy.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2116.
THOMAS HAMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August , 3 lbs. weight of ham, value 3s. , the goods of
John Loveridge
.

ROBERT DARBY
. I am servant to
John Loveridge
, cheesemonger , Crawford-street, Marylebone
. I saw the prisoner take this ham from the window, and run away - he was stopped by the Policeman.

MARY MORGAN
. I was opposite the shop, and saw the prisoner walking up and down for a quarter of an hour - he then took the ham.

THOMAS HARRIS
. I am a Policeman. I stopped the prisoner, who Darby was pursuing, and found the ham in a bag, under his arm.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Six Months .
First London Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2117.
THOMAS EGAN
was
indicted for a misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .

2118.
JOHN CROCKFORD
was
indicted for a misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2119.
ROBERT WILLIAM HUTTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 1 bag, value 1s., and 1 coat, value 3l. , the goods of
Richard Davies
.

JAMES WILLIAM LYMN
. I am ten years old, and am apprentice to Charles Stocking, Regent-street. On Thursday, the 2nd of August, I was sent by Richard Davies, the foreman , with a coat in a bag, to Finsbury-square - when I got near Waterloo-bridge, Strand
, the prisoner and another came up to me; the other said,"Will you go on an errand for me?" I said Yes - he said he would give me 3d., and that man took the bag to hold while I went; the prisoner could hear and see what passed - the man sent me to some street, and said the name of Painter was over the door; the prisoner came with me to the house, and then ran away - the name of Painter was over the house; when I came back the other man, who was to wait at the court, was gone; I saw the prisoner on the Monday following, in Air-street - both of them were together, one a little way from the other - I informed the officer, who took the prisoner; the other ran away - when I saw them the prisoner was laying down, and the other standing a little way from him; the other spoke to me, and asked me to go to Mr. Bloomfield's - I said I would not; I went home to my master, told him I had seen the man, and then returned with an officer, and pointed the prisoner out, who was still there.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What time of the day was this? A. I started about eleven o'clock in the morning, on Thursday, the 2nd of August; I was about half an hour going to where I lost the bag; when I saw the prisoner some days after he was asleep on the step - I had no conversation with him that day; they were about ten minutes with me when the bag was taken, I think - I observed him particularly; the one who took my bag had a black body coat on - I did not notice his neckerchief; I noticed his face.

COURT. Q. Have you any doubt the prisoner is the man who went with you to Painter's on the 2nd of August, and who you saw in Air-street on Monday? A. He is the man; he had the same coat he has on now, I think- I am confident of his person.

RICHARD DAVIES. On the 2nd of August I delivered Lymn a coat to carry to Mr. Freer, King-street, Finsbury - it was my property; I sent him out a little after eleven o'clock from No. 65, Regent-street; he returned in about two hours, without the bag, with a Policeman, and was crying - on the Monday following he came and took me to Air-street, and pointed out the prisoner; I felt doubtful about him, and desired him to be particular - he persisted, and I gave the prisoner in charge.
Cross-examined. Q. When the boy came home the first day was he not much alarmed and disturbed? A. He was crying, but did not seem particularly frightened; he was certainly confused.

ROBERT CULLEY
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner in Air-street, sitting on the step of a door; he denied the charge, and said before the Magistrate that he should be able to prove the boy had sold the coat some where.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he asleep? A. I cannot say- he was hanging his head down; he appeared asleep - it was about half-past nine o'clock.
Prisoner's Defence. I can prove my innocence by witnesses.

THOMAS EDGINGTON
. I am a sawyer, and live at No. 42, Ham-yard, Windmill-street, Haymarket, and rent a place in the yard. On Thursday, the 2nd of August, I was at home all day, and not out of the yard, and saw the prisoner there - I first saw him coming into the yard abouta quarter to eleven o'clock; he stopped there till after one- Spry, a sawyer, was at work with me.

COURT. Q. What is the prisoner's business? A. He works for the army, making soldier's caps, I believe - he was slack of work, and often came and sat by the timber in our yard when he has had nothing to do; I was there alongside of him the whole time; he sat there while I was eating my dinner - I dine about a quarter-past one o'clock- he had none of my dinner; Mumford and a person named Spearing was there - Mumford and Spry were at work, and Spearing was standing there, doing nothing but walking up and down; he is a farrier, but he had no horses in his shop, which is in the yard - the prisoner lives at No. 43, Ham-yard, at Morgan's house, and is single-Spry and Mumford fined with me on the timber, and had beef and pork; it was cold - Spearing had no dinner; the prisoner did not go away after dinner, for I gave him 1s. to move the stuff out of the way, and he never left till after eight o'clock at night, and was never out of my presence five minutes all day.

Q. What was you doing from eleven o'clock in the morning till that time of night? A. Why, we had a book amusing ourselves with; I was reading the book - I believe they call it the Old Testament; the prisoner was hearing it; we could not read much, for it was a piece thrown out of a firkin of butter - I was the only person who read; I sometimes read to myself, and sometimes to the prisoner - he sat at one end of the timber; it was smeared and dirty - we got a verse here and there; I read for three hours - I had no tea; I did not give him any dinner; I had no supper, except bread and cheese - he had none of that - Mumford and Spry supped with me; they were at work, and had no reading - I was not able to work.

THOMAS SPRY
. I am a sawyer. On Thursday, the 2nd of August, I was at work at the saw-pit in Ham-yard, and saw the prisoner there at half-past ten o'clock, sitting at the end of the deals at the saw-pit; Edgington was there, but was not at work; I never left the saw-pit till half-past two- I had my dinner in the pit; it was corn beef and pork - it was hot: my mate, who was at work, and Edgington eat with me - the prisoner eat nothing, to my knowledge; Edgington was part of the time sharpening a saw; I was not attending to see exactly what else he might be doing; Mumford was sitting on the deals - the prisoner sat very near him; I left at half-past two o'clock, and left the prisoner there.

COURT. Q. Where did you get your hot pork and beef dressed? A. From Spicer's cook-shop, in Crowncourt - it was in one dish; Edgington's brother fetched it- he was my mate; it was not cold, but might not have been taken from the fire that moment; it was pretty hot- I had one plate at the top of the dish; I used my fingers for a fork, and cut it on my bread; neither Spearing nor Mumford work with me; I think Mumford dined with us - he works for us at times, but did not that day - I do not recollect Edgington reading.
Q. Do you remember any thing of a greasy book? A. It was part of a leaf that was sent from the cook-shop - there was no book there; I do not recollect Edgington reading at all.
JURY. Q. Was you on the top of the timber or down in the pit? A. On the top.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Might Edgington be reading and you not see it? A. He might; I was attending to my work.

JOHN MUMFORD
. I am a sawyer by trade. On the 2nd of August I was in Ham-yard during the whole of the day, and saw the prisoner there about ten o'clock; I went to my dinner between twelve and one - I believe the prisoner was then just gone up to his dinner at his own place- I am sure he was in the yard till then; the witness Edgington did not work that day; his brother and Spry were at work; I believe he was cutting timber, sawing it - I was there when Edgington and Spry dined; they had beef and pork - I do not know whether it was hot or cold- I had no work to do that day; I did not observe whether Edgington was reading or not; he might, and I not observe it - I dined at my sister's, which is in the yard, about one o'clock, and was up there about a quarter of an hour- I was in the yard all day.

COURT. Q. Did you dine before Edgington or after him? A. After they had done, before I went up - I believe Spry brought the beef and pork; he fetched it from Crown-court; I was not at work all day - I did not help Edgington or Spry; the prisoner went up to his father's room to dinner; he lives at No. 33, Ham-yard.

Q. What was he doing in the yard that day? A. Smoking his pipe mostly the whole day; he walked from the saw-pit to the farrier's to light his pipe, but was mostly sitting down by the saw-pit - he was not employed at all; I was in the yard till about half-past nine o'clock; I should have seen if he had been at work, and am sure he did not do any thing; I remember it was the day the thunder and lightning was - it thundred and lightened very much between six and seven o'clock, and rained - we all remained in the saw-pit while it rained; it thundered loud, and the lightning was vivid, and it rained heavy.

JOSEPH SPEARING
. I am a farrier; I live in Rupert-street. On Thursday, the 2nd of August, I was at work in my shop in Ham-yard, and saw the prisoner there first about a quarter to eleven o'clock - he came to my shop, and lighted his pipe; I was in and out of my shop, but not out of the yard - the last time I saw the prisoner was about seven o'clock in the evening, when he was sitting on the wood by the saw-pit; I cannot tell where he might have gone all day - I remember the thunder storm; it was towards the afternoon - there was a very heavy clap of thunder; I dined at a public-house at the corner of the gateway, alone - I saw no dinner brought into the yard; I saw John Edgington and his mates at work; I passed the prisoner several times - he was smoking his pipe at the sawpit; he used to come into the yard when he had no work.

COURT. Q. He was in the yard most days when disengaged? A. Yes; I do not recollect where he was on the 31st of July, or the 1st of August, or any other day - I recollect the 2nd, because he came into the shop, and spoke about the thunder; it quite struck him and made him jump off his legs - that was about four o'clock; I was not much in the yard - I generally go outside for a little air, between the heats, but I was pretty well employed - I did not see them at dinner; it was not John Edgington that was at work, but a lusty man they employ - I saw
John Edgington
there several times; I did not see himreading, or with any book - I suppose I came out five or six times between the heats; Edgington and the prisoner were mostly sitting down - I cannot mention where the prisoner was on any other day; the thunder storm lasted five or six minutes.
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 14.
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2120.
JOSEPH POWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 15 yards of linen cloth, value 1l. 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Baker
. - To which he pleaded

GUILTY . -
Confined Six Months .

2121.
ANGELO PHILIP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 11 bronze vases, value 30l., and 5 pieces of bronze, value 20l. , the goods of
Anna Maria Gordon
.

ANDREW CASTELLARI
. I attend the Egyptian Hall, Piccadilly
; I have the management of the business for
Anna Maria Gordon
. I missed eleven vases, and five pieces of bronze on the 11th of August; they are worth 50l. - I have known the prisoner twelve or fifteen months; he was in the habit of coming, as a friend of mine.
Prisoner. He gave me these vases to sell. Witness. No, I did not.
COURT. Q. Did you deliver any pieces of bronze to him to sell? A. No, I did not; I did not employ him to sell any thing.
Prisoner. My Lord, he said to me,
"As soon as you have sold these vases, come and tell me, and who you sold them to. Witness. No, I did not say a word about it.
COURT. Q. Do you mean to say, upon the solemn oath you have taken, you never employed the prisoner to sell any thing, or give him any thing to sell. Witness. I never spoke one word about it.

WILLIAM TILL
. I live in Great Russell-street, Covent-garden; I deal in coins, metals, and anitquities. I bought these articles of the prisoner at different times; I gave about 10l. for them - I observed something particular in their appearance; I went to the Musenm, and saw similar articles - I bought some on the 11th of August, and for three or four days before - there were some tickets on them, and I saw some tickets on those at the Museum; I have kept the tickets of those I bought - they are genuine antiques about 1800 or 1900 years old.

JAMES KENNERLY
(Police-constable C 30). I was on duty in Piccadilly; I took the prisoner on the 13th of August, at the Egyptian Hall, and received these articles from Mr. Till - I found on the prisoner two gold rings, two medals, and some money.

WILLIAM TILL
. I missed these medals and some coins.
Prisoner. I dined with Castellari after I sold these things.

ANDREW CASTELLARI
. I dined two or three times with him, but he did not say he had told the things.
Prisoner's Defence. He has not told the truth, and now I leave it to the Court.

JAMES KENNERLY. When I took the prisoner I took off his hat, and there was a dent in it, in which, probably, some of these things had been, and some hay in it, and some hay was in these things; he said he had been playing with some horses in a stable.

WILLIAM TILL re-examined. Q. How came you to buy of him? A. I had bought some things of him before, of what they call Terra cotta; I then lost sight of him for some time - I then saw him again, and he sold me these things; they ask 4l. or 5l. a-piece for them at the Museum, which is a ridiculous price.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2122.
THOMAS BROWN
was
indicted for embezzlement .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

2123.
JOHN BELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 4 razors, value 5s. , the goods of
George Handley
.

GEORGE HANDLEY
. I live in Crown-street; I am a hair-dresser . The prisoner was occasionally employed in my shop, and was so about one month before the 4th of September; I left fifteen razors in my shop on the 31st of August, and missed four - the next morning I went to the prisoner's shop, in Holywell-lane - I asked what he came to my shop for; he said to sell a couple of boards, which we generally hang outside our doors, and I asked him about the razors - he said he knew nothing about them, but one which my boy took from him.

THOMAS FORD
. I am shop-boy to the prosecutor. On a Friday evening, the prisoner came to the shop; he took a razor out of the rack - I took it out of his hat; he said it dropped in, but I saw him snatch it.

JAMES YOUNG
(Police-constable G 203). I took the prisoner.
Prisoner. I was in great distress, and had two boards to sell - the razor fell into my hat.
GUILTY. Aged 22.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Months .

2124.
ELIZA ALLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 1 pair of boots, value 2s., the goods of
John Davis
, from the person of
Matilda Davis
.

MARY DAVIS
. I am the wife of
John Davis
- he is a weaver , and lives in Hare-court. On the 4th of September I sent my little girl Matilda, and my little boy Joseph to take a walk; they had their boots on when they went out, and came back without them; from what they said I went after the prisoner, and found her in York-street; I asked if she knew any thing of the children's boots - she said No, she did not; I gave her into custody, and she told me where they were.

LEWIS HARRIS
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker, in Brown's-lane. I have a pair of boots, pawned on the 4th of September, in the name of
Ann Watson
- I cannot swear to the prisoner, but this is the counterpart of the duplicate I gave for them.

MATILDA DAVIS
. I am eleven years old. The prisoner took my boots off my feet on the 4th of September, when I was in the street; she told me my mother said I was to have the boots off, and she was to take them home - I was to have another pair for working days, and a new pair for Sundays.

CHARLES EAST
(Police-constable H 33). I received the prisoner, and the boots.

GUILTY. Aged 15. -
Judgment Respited
.

2125.
JOSEPH BLACKBURN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 ring, value 6s.; 1 waistcoat, value 12s.; 1 knife, value 2s.; 1 half-crown, 5 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 2 pence , the property of
Samuel Baker
.

SAMUEL BAKER. I lodge at No.1, Tennis-court, Middle-row, Holborn
; I am a tailor - the prisoner lodged in the same room. On the 20th of August he left the room at half-past five o'clock in the morning; I got up at half-past eight, and missed a ring, a waistcoat, a knife, a half-crown, and some halfpence - the prisoner was brought home the next night: he gave me the ring off his finger and the knife - he said they were my property; but the waistcoat he could not account for, as he had made away with it.

AMBROSE MOSS
. I met the prisoner in Gray's Inn-lane, and took him back to the prosecutor's; he gave up the ring and knife, and wanted to give up two duplicates of clothes of Mr. Haydon's, his master, to make it up with him.

WILLIAM MASON
(Police-constable G 15). I took the prisoner, and have the property.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 41. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2126.
SUSAN BARTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 table-cover, value 18d.; 1 brush, value 1s.; 1 lace-collar, value 1s.; 2 seals, value 6d., and 2 pieces of marble, value 6d. , the goods of
George Vipond
, her master.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

2127.
ANN BRODIE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 purse, value 2d., and one 5l. Bank note, the property of
William Rolfe
, from his person ; against the Statute, &c.

WILLIAM ROLFE. I am a seaman , and lodge at Poplar. On the evening of the 7th of September I was at the Coach and Horses, Shadwell
; I went from there soon after nine o'clock; when I had been out about ten minutes, the prisoner came up to me, clasped me round, and took a red purse out of my pocket, with a 5l. note in it - there was no other person near me; I told her to go away, as I was going home to my wife and family - I am certain I had the purse when I left the house.

Prisoner. Q. Was there nobody in company with you at the Coach and Horses, and the Bull's Head? A. I came out of the house with the money in my pocket, and you were the only person with me afterwards; I did not sleep with any girl that night - I roamed about the street.

JAMES CHRISTIAN
(Police-constable K 196). I saw the prisoner in company with the prosecutor at the Bull's Head, on the night of the 7th of September - he went out and she followed him; he stopped when he had got a few doors off, and said he had lost his bundle - I went out to him, and said, "I understand you have a 5l. note about you:" he said, "Yes, I have in this purse, and I mean to take it home to my wife and family" - the prisoner was close to him at the time; I pushed her away: a young girl came up to her, and said, "Nance, will you stand some gin" - she said, "I have not a blessed farthing, but I shall soon have some money, and I will treat you;" I said to her, "You had better let him alone, you know he has a 5l. note about him" - she said, "No, I will go home with him to night, so help me God."

WILLIAM WHEELER
(Police-constable K 160). I went to a house in Bluegate-fields the next morning - I found the prisoner there; I asked what she had done with the man's pocket-book and purse; she said she knew nothing about it - I said, "What have you done with the man's money?" she said, "I have got no money," but I found on the floor a sovereign and a sixpence, and a woman, who was there, said she had seen her that morning with four or five half-crowns in her hand.

MARY BIGNELL
. I was in the room where the officer apprehended the prisoner; she had come home that morning, and called me at half-past five o'clock or a quarter before six - she said God was good, and she was not without 1l. or some silver - she showed me a sovereign and three or four half-crowns in her hand; I asked her if she had got it honestly, and she said she was as right as the day - she asked me to go and buy some things; we then had a cup of tea, and the officer came and took her.

DIANA CLIFFORD
. I am the wife of Charles Henry Clifford; we keep the Coach and Horses, in Shadwell. -The prosecutor was at my house on the night of the 7th of September; he had a 5l. note, and I offered to take care of it for him.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me with him? A. Yes, you went out with him.

Prisoner's Defence. I went into the Coach and Horses, and saw the prosecutor and several persons drinking with him; he then went to the bar, and wanted this lady to give him his 5l. note; she refused - he then came out, and went to the Bull's Head; I went with him there, and saw no more of him.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2128.
ANN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, and 1 shilling, the monies of
John Neaves
, from his person .

JOHN NEAVES
. I am a glass-cutter , and lodge in King-street, Camden-town. I met the prisoner on the night of the 5th of August, and went with her to a room on the ground floor of a house in Harford-street
- I paid half a crown for the room, and was to give her half a crown - I pulled out my money; I had two sovereigns, one half-sovereign, two half-crowns, and some shillings - I saw the sovereigns and shillings in my possession after I gave her the half-crown; I staid about half an hour, and left at a quarter before ten o'clock - as I passed the threshold of the door I missed a sovereign and a half-sovereign; I charged the prisoner with robbing me - she said she had no money but the half-crown I gave her, and any one might search her; I got the officer.
Prisoner. Q. Did you miss your money till you got out of the house? A. No - I had got out with the prisoner.

JOSEPH STANNARD
(Police-constable E 56). I took the prisoner - she said she had nothing but the half-crown which the prosecutor gave her; I took her to the station, and a woman found the other money on her; she then said it was found on the sofa they had laid on in the room, andshe did not know whether it was the prosecutor's or any other person's.

ESTHER ALLICE LAST
. I searched the prisoner at the watch-house, and found in her shoe one sovereign, one half-sovereign, one half-crown, one shilling, and one sixpence; she said at first that she had no money but the half-crown the gentleman gave her.
Prisoner. I said I had some money, but it was my own. Witness. No. you said you had not.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2129.
EDWARD COLEMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 knife-tray, value 5s. , the goods of
Charles Rowe
.

CHARLES ROWE. I live in Mount-street, Grosvenorsquare
, and am a cabinet-maker . About nine o'clock in the morning on the 13th of August, I was in the parlour, adjoining my shop - I heard a noise, ran out, and saw the prisoner running with a knife-tray under his arm: he ran into a shed, and got behind a cart - I saw him taken with this tray, which is mine.

JOHN HAMPSON
. I am a private in the first Grenadier Guards. I heard the alarm, and saw the prisoner running with the tray; he ran into a shed - I went and took him.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2130.
JOHN DONALDSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 2 sides of a bedstead, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Ewer
.

THOMAS EWER. The prisoner lodged at my house in Short's-gardens
; in consequence of information I followed him on Monday evening, at half-past seven o'clock - he was making an agreement about the sides of a bedstead, which were my property; I had not given him any authority to take them out of my house - I had seen them safe on the Sunday, in a room which he did not occupy.
Prisoner. Q. Were they not under my bedstead? A. No; those under your bedstead are there now - these are part of another bedstead.

WILLIAM PARROTT
. I live in St. Giles'. The prisoner came and told me he had some pieces of a bedstead, and asked if I would buy them - I said I was busy, and could not go to look at them then; he then brought these two pieces.

JOHN BENNETT
(Police-constable F 10.) I took the prisoner - he said he had requested the landlord to remove these from under his bed, and as he would not, he thought he might as well take them, and make something of them; he said at the station that he had done it under the influence of liquor, and we ought not to take advantage of him; he had been drinking.

Prisoner's Defence. I had asked him several times to remove them from under my bedstead, as they were very dirty, and full of bugs; I said if he did not I would throw them out of the window, or take them away myself.

GUILTY .
Confined Ten Days .

2131.
JAMES GUBIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September , 1 necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Asher Levy
, from his person .

ELIZABETH LEVY
. I am the wife of Asher Levy - we live in Hart-street, Covent-garden
. On the 9th of September, about six o'clock in the evening, I was standing at the door with my daughter Mary in my arms - she had a coral necklace; I saw her put her hand to her neck, and saw the prisoner behind us - he ran down a street; I told my husband, who went and brought him back.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What is your husband? A. A fruiterer; he goes by the name of Davis, and always signs it so, but Levy is his proper name.
NOT GUILTY .

2132.
JOHN LYNNARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 muslin tippet, value 1s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
Ellen Mabon
.
The prosecutrix's name being Eleanor, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

2133.
JAMES LANE
and
CATHERINE WILKINSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 2 printed books, value 2s. , the goods of
Christopher Harris
.

CHRISTOPHER HARRIS. I am a bookseller , and live in Bow-street
. On the 7th of August I lost the Materia Medica, in two volumes, from my window; I had seen them safe at two o'clock, and missed them at four.

JOHN PURDY
(Police-constable F 137.) I was in Broad-street, St. Giles', on the 7th of August, about half-past three or four o'clock - I met the two prisoners together; the man had the child in his arms, which he went has now - she gave him two books, with which he went into a pawnbroker's shop - I went in at the front door, and saw him offer them to pawn, for 2s.; they were refused - he took them out again to Wilkinson, and I took them both - these are the books; it was half a mile from the prosecutor's.

Lane's Defence. I met three women, who asked where I was going, and if I had any money; I said I had not - my fellow prisoner was one - she asked me to hold her child, and and then she asked me to take the books to pawn; they would not take them; I brought them back, gave them to her, and the officer took her.

Wilkinson's Defence. I was going to Covent-garden, and met him with two women - I did not know him, but I knew one of the women; she asked me how my husband was; I said, "Very bad" - she said, "We have got something to pawn;" Lane then said, "Shall I carry your child; I let him do it to rest my arms" - one of the women then gave him the books to pawn.

LANE -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

WILKINSON -
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Six Weeks .

2134.
WILLIAM McDONALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 saddle, value 3l. , the goods of
James Wells Partridge
.

HENRY HIGHILL
. I am in the employ of Mr.
James Wells Partridge
, a saddler , of Great Quebec-street
. We lost this saddle on the 31st of August, or the 1st of September, from a rail outside the shop.

WILLIAM IRON
. I am a labourer, and live in King-street, Soho. On the 1st of September I saw the prisoner in Rose-street, with this saddle on his head; there was a boy before him, and another behind him - they went down a street by St. Giles' church; I went close up to them, and one of them said, "You two stop here, and I shall not be long" - I went to the corner of the street, and the officercame up; the prisoner then took the saddle on his head again, and was going off.

JOHN HANDLEY
(Police-constable F 49.) I took the prisoner with this saddle, on the 1st of September, about ten o'clock - it was a mile and a half from the prosecutor's; he put the saddle on his head, and tried to run away with it - the other two ran off.

Prisoner's Defence. I was in Soho-square - a man and two boys asked me to carry this saddle, which one of the two boys had - they promised to give me a few halfpence for it; I set it down to rest, because I was tired - one of them then ran away; I then thought it was stolen; I put it on my head, and walked up the street.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2135.
MARY ROBINSON
was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 bed, value 15s. , the goods of
John Ord
.

ELIZABETH PEARSON
. I am a widow, and live in Shakspeare's-walk, Shadwell. On the 27th of August we lost a bed from No. 1, Glasshouse-place, Stepney
; it was Mr. Ord's property - the prisoner's daughter had been in charge of his house; I asked the prisoner what was to be done about the bed; she said, "What's that to you? I took it, and shall keep it as long as I please."

JANE READ
. I am the wife of James Read - we live within three doors of Ord's. On the 27th of August I saw the prisoner go in there, and a person named Berry came out with the bed on his back - the prisoner came out just after him.

JOSEPH MICKLEFIELD
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Ratcliff. The prisoner left this bed with me as security for a monthly note which she had left with me.

GEORGE HARRISON
(Police-constable K 64). I took the prisoner between eight and nine o'clock in the evening; I found on her the key of Ord's house.

MARIA ORD
. I am the wife of John Ord. The prisoner's daughter learned work of me; I have pawned things for the prisoner, and have lent her things to pawn, but I never had any of the money; I never allowed her to take things without my lending them to her - I did not allow her to take this bed; she had taken my fire-irons and other things.
Prisoner's Defence. My husband has been away two years and five months; when I took the bed, and got the monthly note, I had to wait till half-past seven o'clock before I got the money for it.

GEORGE HARRISON
. The note was found on her, and I was informed she had received a month's money that day.
NOT GUILTY .

2136.
BENJAMIN SHARPE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 scarf, value 4s.; 4 shoes, value 5s.; 1 reticule, value 1s., and 3 yards of ribbon, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Sharpe
.

MARY SHARPE
. I am the wife of Thomas Sharpe, he is at sea ; I live in White Horse-street, Stepney
. On the 14th of August I was at Bell-wharf, Shadwell, talking to my sister; the prisoner crossed over, and asked me for a bed; I said if he would come with me he should have my bed, and I would sleep with my landlady - he did so, and next morning I let him out at half-past four o'clock, and went up immediately; I then saw a new bonnet destroyed on the table; I then missed the shoes, reticule, and scarf - I have seen them since.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. When were you married? A. On the 26th of June, six years ago; I am a dress-maker and tailoress - I had not known the prisoner before, but we both came from the north; he had had a little drink, and I said if he would go home with me, I would give him a bed; I took him to a room up stairs, and left him there; I was not in the room with him long - I did not attempt to go to bed with him; he did not complain of losing any money.

TIMOTHY DONOVAN
. (Police-constable K 154). I met the prisoner at Bell-wharf, about half-past five o'clock in the morning of the 14th of August, about half a mile from the prosecutrix's - I had received the information soon after four o'clock; I found this scarf in his hat, and the shoes and reticule in his pocket; he said he would give me 5s. and the articles to let him go, as he had a large family at Shields; that he had had 10s. in his pocket the night before, and had been robbed of it.

PETER COSTELLO
. (Police-constable K 90). I asked the prisoner if he slept by himself - he said Yes; the prosecutrix is a respectable person.

Prisoner. I had been in company with my brother, and had a good deal of drink; this woman came and took my arm, and asked where I was going - I said,"On board my ship;" she coaxed me to go home and stay with her; I had four half-crowns, and some other money - she pulled off my things; I said, "If I can't sleep by myself, I will go out of the house;" when I awoke in the morning I had not a farthing, and I took these things out of vexation.

MARY SHARPE. I did not pull off his clothes; he pulled off his jacket and trousers, and left on his drawers and shirt; I did not lead him from where I saw him; he took hold of my arm, and spoke to me while I was speaking to my sister; I had been to the doctor for a bottle of stuff for my cough - I did not take him home for improper purposes; when I awoke in the morning, I heard a footstep, and I said I thought it was that man; I asked my landlady for her shawl, I put it on, and opened the door for him; he said,"Good morning," and went away.
GUILTY. Aged 53.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

2137.
SUSANNAH TYRRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 comb, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Samuel Daniels
.

JOSEPH DANIELS
. I live with my father,
Samuel Daniels
, in Red Lion-square, New Inn-yard
; I sell combs at a stall in the street for my father. On the 1st of September the prisoner came to my stall, and asked the price of a small comb - I said 4d.; and at the same time she put a large comb under her apron, and was going away; I said, "Give me that comb, you have under your apron;" she said she had no comb, and I might search her - I was going to search her, and it fell from behind her.

WILLIAM HENRY CLARK
(Police-constable H 43). Itook the prisoner about a yard from the stall; the prosecutor was demanding a comb of her, and began to search her; this comb fell from her, and I took it up.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. My little girl asked me to go and buy her a comb - I had a 6d. in my hand, and 1 1/2d. in my pocket; I touched no comb but the one I asked the price of.

GUILTY . Aged 57. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2138.
JOHN WARD
,
EDWARD PICKARD
, and
DANIEL FOLEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September
, 6 pairs of shoes, value 12s. , the goods
William Hayhow
; and
SUSANNAH SUMMERS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

HENRY LEE
(Police-constable K 262). On the 2nd of September I saw Ward in High-street, Shadwell
; Pickard and Foley were on the other side of the way - they were about fifty yards from the prosecutor's; that was about half-past nine o'clock, and about ten I saw Pickard and Foley at Mr. Thomas' shop; Ward was going towards Cannon-street - I then lost sight of them till I received in formation that Ward had gone up Twinecourt, with something in an apron; I went there, and saw Ward come out of a house - I asked what he had had in his apron, and had taken into that house; he said, Nothing - I went into the house, and saw Pickard trying to get under the bed, and Foley ran up stairs; Summers was in bed - I sent for an officer, who found some shoes in the bed, which could not have been put in while I was there; I did not see Summers touch them.

GEORGE DEWPEN
. I am a shoemaker. I was in Mr. Tilley's shoe shop, in Ratcliff-highway, on the 7th of September; I saw Pickard and Foley handling the shoes - I went and told Mr. Tilley to give notice to the Police-officer - Pickard and Foley then walked away - I afterwards saw them in company with Ward in the highway; Ward said to them, "Run down Union-street, and meet me in the alley;" he then had a black apron on, which he was holding up before him.
Ward. He must have been very close to me to see what I had in my apron - it was a few French beans.
Witness. I cannot say what he had got; he met some girl of the town, and showed her what he had got.

WILLIAM OSMAN
(Police-constable K 61). I assisted Lee at the house in Twine-court; I found six pairs of shoes in the bed, and Summers was laying with the calves of her legs over them - I asked her how they came there; she denied knowing any thing about them; but afterwards said that Ward brought them, and flung them into the bed where she was - Ward was sitting on the bed at the time.
JOHN HOBBS. I am foreman to Mr. William Hayhow, a shoemaker, in Ratcliff-highway. These are his property.

BENJAMIN BRETT
. I am shopman to Mr. Hayhow. These shoes were hanging on his door-post; I saw them safe at half-past eight o'clock.

Ward's Defence. No one saw me with the property, nor with these two boys; when the officer saw me, he asked what I had in my apron - I said Nothing; he knocked first at one door, and then at another, and when Foley opened a door, he ran in, and said, "This is the house you came out of."

Foley's Defence. The officer stated at the Thames Police-office that I ran up stairs; but instantly I opened the door, he laid hold of me, and said there is another of them - I had been with Pickard, and left him, and went home to go to bed; he then came again to ask me to go to swim; I knew nothing of Ward till the officer brought him in.

WARD -
GUILTY . Aged 24.

FOLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

PICKARD -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

SUMMERS -
NOT GUILTY .

2139.
GEORGE WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August , 1 pair of shoes, value 7s. , the goods of
William Hayhow
.

JOHN HOBBS
. I am foreman to Mr. William Hayhow, shoemaker , Ratcliff-highway
. On the morning of the 23rd of August I received information, and was told the prisoner had gone; I followed him - he was running; I stopped him, and found on him this pair of shoes, which I had seen half an hour before hung on the door-post: there were half a dozen pair hanging together, and these were cut down.

JAMES HAWKWITH
(Police-constable K 199). I took the prisoner; he said he had taken the shoes.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Three Months .

2140.
MARY WORKMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 shawl, value 2s., the goods of
James Grubb
, from the the person of
Elizabeth Grubb
.

ELIZABETH GRUBB
. I am the wife of James Grubb - we live in James-street, Bethnal-green. On the 1st of August I was going up Hoxton
: I stepped aside to a court, the prisoner saw me and took me to a privy - I then went with her to a public-house, where we had two quarterns of gin, which I paid for - we walked away to get her; I had been drinking before and was a little tipsy - the boys got round me, and the prisoner took my shawl off my neck and ran away; I saw her in Shoreditch two days afterwards - I asked what she had done with my shawl; she said she had given it to
Mary Skinner
, who had sold it, and she had 5d. of it for her share - she took me to some small house in Hackney-road, but could not find the person who bought it; we found Skinner, who denied all knowledge of it.

WILLIAM HODGE
(Police-constable N 97). I took the prisoner; she admitted taking the shawl and selling it for 5d.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined One Month .

2141.
ELIZABETH STEEL
,
MARY HUM-PHRIES
,
ELIZABETH WILEY
, and
JOSEPH CLARK
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s. , the goods of
Joseph Fennell
.

HENRY COLTON
(Police-constable H 60). On the 15th of August I was in Shoreditch
; I saw the prisoners all together in conversation - I watched them; they went to the prosecutor's shop; Humphries took hold of a pair of shoes which hung on the door-post, and remarked thatthey were a very nice pair - Steel then took them, put them under her shawl under her left arm, and walked away.

Steel. I met these two girls, and asked them to go with me to buy a pair of shoes - Humphries touched this pair - they fell down; I took them up, and before I could put them up the officer took us. Witness. They had got fourteen or fifteen yards from the shop; Clark had a jacket on, and he put his hands into the pockets, and extended his arms as if to conceal them - I found the shoes under Steel's arm; I put her into the shop, and Clark used the most disgusting language, which collected a mob, and I took him - Steel and Humphries stood close together, and the other two close behind them; I had watched them for twenty yards previous to their going to the door.
Humphries' Defence. I was coming down Shoreditch and met Steel; I touched the shoes and they fell down; she picked them up, and the officer took us.

Wiley. I was with Humphries - we met Steel; she asked us to go and buy a pair of shoes - they were a little before me, for I stopped to look at a window; I did not know what was done till the mob collected. Witness. I had watched them for twenty yards previous to their going to the shop; when I took Steel, Clark said I had no business to take her - I said if I did wrong I must answer for it; he was very violent, and a man stepped up and assisted me to take them - Steel then wanted to shuffle the shawl from her shoulders, and I assisted her, in order that the other might come to the station - Clark then took off his hat, and I asked Wiley to carry it for him, which she did; I then met another officer, and we took the other two prisoners.

ELIZABETH CROW. I am servant to Joseph Fennel. I was in his shop, and saw Humphries take hold of the toes of the shoes and turn them round - she said they were a nice pair, and then Steele took them down and put them under her shawl; they had got twelve or fifteen yards before they were taken - I gave an alarm; my master went out and Steel was brought in - I was at the back part of the shop; the shoes were hung on hooks.

JOSEPH FENNEL. About seven o'clock in the evening my servant gave me some information - I went into the street and saw Steel in custody of the officer, who was taking these shoes from under her shawl; they were twelve or fifteen yards off - Clark then came and was taken - they are my shoes, and worth 4s.
HENRY COLTON. I had seen all the prisoners together in deep conversation for twenty minutes before; and I had seen the whole four together before that evening,

STEEL -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

HUMPHRIES -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

WILEY -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

CLARK -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2162.
ANN SWEENY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 tippet, value 4s. , the goods of
Mary Ann Waters
.

MARY ANN WATERS
. I am single ; I live at No.35, Frith-street
- the prisoner was servant to a lodger in the house; I lost my tippet on the 2nd of August from a back parlour -I saw it again on the prisoner on the 30th of August.

ELIZABETH HOEPFNER
. My husband keeps the house in Frith-street. Waters is my servant - the prisoner is servant to Mrs. Rymer, a lodger; this tippet and a gown of my own were taken on the 2nd of August, when the prisoner's mistress took her to Margate; I described my gown to her mistress, and she found it on her person.

FANNY RYMER
. This tippet was in possession of the prisoner on the day we returned from Margate.

JAMES WARD
(Police-constable C 172). I took the prisoner at the prosecutor's house on the 30th of August; this tippet was under her gown and petticoat, tied round her waist. Property produced and sworn to.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2143.
ANN SWEENY
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 gown, value 8s.; 1 cap, value 1s. 6d., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
John Augustus Andrus Hoepfner
.

ELIZABETH HOEPFNER
. I am the wife of John Augustus Andrus Hoepfner - he keeps the house No.35, Frith-street
; the prisoner was servant to my lodger. I lost my gown on the 2nd of August, and the cap about a week after.

JAMES WARD
. I am a Police-constable. I found this gown on the prisoner on the 30th of August.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Transported for Seven Years longer .
There was another indictment against the prisoner.

2144.
MARGARET MURRAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st September , 1 gown, value 2s., 1 pair of stockings, value 9d., and 1 shawl, value 6d. , the goods of
Michael Crawley
.

MARY CRAWLEY
. I am the wife of
Michael Crawley
; we live in the parish of St. George, Hanover-square
. I hired the prisoner to mind my children; she came on the 1st of September - I had my tea with the prisoner at five o'clock, and then went out to market, telling her to put the children to bed - when I came back I missed these articles from the front kitchen.

JOSEPH KENDRICK
. (Police-constable F 42). I took the prisoner at two o'clock the next morning, in Bowl-yard, St. Giles'; she had this shawl on, which is all that has been found.
Prisoner. She allowed me to wear the shawl on that Saturday afternoon, and then got me to mind her things while she had her tea.
MARY CRAWLEY. No, I never lent her any article of dress; she agreed to stop with me for 1s. a week.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2145.
JOHN LAWRENCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 27 yards of carpet, value 12l., and 1 hearth rug, value 10s., the goods of
Thomas Dowbiggin
and another .

MICHAEL DRISCOLL
(Police-constable H 133.) On the 18th of August, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I was on Tower-hill - I saw the prisoner with a parcel on his shoulder; he was going on between a walk and a run - I suspected all was not right, and followed him; he dropped the parcel - I called to two men to take care of it; I followed and took him in the Minories.

SAMUEL EMMERSON
. I am clerk to Mr. Thomas Dowbiggin and another, of Mount-street, Grosvenor-square - this parcel contained the articles stated, and is their goods; I gave it to one of our porters to pack, and he gave it to two carmen - it is addressed to Lord Kinnoul, Duplen-castle, Perth.
THOMAS COLLINS. I was driving the caravan on that Saturday afternoon - I cannot say where I lost this parcel; I missed it when I got to the wharf - it had been tied to the van with some more.

JAMES BRUCE
. I am a porter. The officer was talking to me, and he ran off and left me, calling to me to mind the parcel, which I saw on the prisoner's shoulder.

Prisoner's Defence. I was crossing Tower-hill; I saw the van going on rapidly - the tail-board was down, and this bale fell out; I called to the carman, who did not hear me - I was dragging it towards the light, to see the direction, and the officer took me.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2146.
JAMES LONG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch chain, value 6d.; 2 seals, value 2l.; 1 watch-key, value 8d.; and 1 ring, value 10s., the goods of
William Short
, from his person .

WILLIAM SHORT. I live with Mr. Gregson. On the 23rd of August I fell in with the prisoner at a beer-shop in Shoreditch; he was with another person, whom I knew - I have known the prisoner twelve years; the other person asked me to drink, and I sat down and drank out of a glass of ale - it was then between eight and nine o'clock, and I stopped till ten o'clock, but I was not intoxicated - we then all left and went to another house in Church-street, and had some beer there; we then went to Whitechapel, and there had a quartern of rum; that was between eleven and twelve o'clock - the other person paid the reckoning; the prisoner said he had no money - we then went with some females to the door of a house in Baker's-row
, but I did not go into any house; I complained of being sick - the prisoner said,"Don't fear, I will protect you, no harm shall happen to you;" but before that he said, "Take care of your watch, or you will lose it" - I took my watch out of fob, put it into a glove, and put it into my coat pocket- there were no girls there then; I then sat down on a step in Baker's-row - the officer came and told me to go away; the prisoner said, "It is all right, let us stay a little while" - the officer said, "I don't know that it is all right;" I then distinctly felt the prisoner put his hand into my pocket, take out my watch, and run off - the officer was there at the time, but I did not give an alarm; I called Jem! Jem! I then went with the other person to the prisoner's father, but he was not come home - the watch has not been found.
Prisoner. Q. What is the reason you did not give an alarm? A. I did not think you meant to rob me, as we had been particular friends.

JOHN STEVENS
. I was with the prosecutor and the prisoner - we all sat on the step, and the prisoner in the middle; I fell asleep in a short time - Short touched me, and said that Long had taken his watch and ran off - we went to the corner, but lost sight of him - I heard the prisoner caution him about his watch in Shoreditch, and he put it into his pocket.

GEORGE DEVEREUX BOLTON (Police-constable H 49). At three o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner and the other two in company with a prostitute - as they passed me the prisoner said "It is all right, Bolton;" I said I did not know that it was, they had better go on - they went to Rose-court, and stood talking together; I went past them, returned, and they were still there - I desired them to go on; I went on, and when I returned a third time, they were asleep on a step in Baker's-row - the prisoner said, "It is all right, let us sleep a while." - I said, No, go about your business" - he then started up, and before I could well turn round, he was out of sight; the prosecutor looked about and called Jem! and asked if I saw which way he ran; I said No - he afterwards went to the station, and gave notice.

JOHN BURROUGH
(Police-constable H 97. I took the prisoner on the 24th; I told him it was on a charge of stealing a watch-chain and seals - he said he knew all about it.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he was innocent, and that all he said to the officer was, "I know what it is about."
NOT GUILTY .

2147.
EDWARD CROWDER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 watch, value 1l. 10s.; 1 seal, value 1s.; 2 watch-keys, value 1d., and 1 chain, value 1s. , the goods of
James Marshall
.

JAMES MARSHALL
. I am a porter , and live in Garden-row, Brick-lane
. On the 17th of August, at eight o'clock in the evening, my watch was in my bed-room - the prisoner lodged there that night, but not in my bed-room; I got up in the morning, between five and six, and went out, leaving my watch in my bed-room, on the first floor - I returned between twelve and one, and missed it: the prisoner was then gone - he had not given notice, but said he should take the lodging by the week, and remain there.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you any other lodger in the house? A. No; I had shut the door when I went out that morning.

ELEANOR MARSHALL
. I am the wife of
James Marshall
. My husband's watch was on the mantel-piece in the bedroom - the prisoner slept in the next room; I got up about seven o'clock in the morning, and shut the door when I came out; the prisoner came down about five minutes before nine, and went out.

MICHAEL SCANTLING
(Police-constable G 118.) I took the prisoner in Old-street, on a charge of stealing a pair of sheets - the watch has not been found.
NOT GUILTY .

2148.
EDWARD CROWDER
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 1 truck, value 2l. , the goods of
Jasper Johnson
.

JASPER JOHNSON
. I live in Wood-street, Goswell-road
. The prisoner came on the 11th of August, and hired my truck, in the name of Davis - I had some knowledge of Davis, and let him have it; I asked if he knew what it was for - he said to fetch five kits of salmon - he went away with it, and never brought it back.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you ever seen him before? A. I cannot say that I had - I remember him by the peculiarity of his dress; a young man who was passing by knew him, and took me to his parents.
RICHARD DAVIS. I am a town carman. I know the prisoner, but I did not send him for the truck.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2149.
EDWARD CROWDER
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 1 pair of sheets, value 5s. , the goods of
Samuel Wood
.

ELIZA WOOD
. I am the wife of Samuel Wood. The prisoner hired a lodging at my house, on the 8th of August, at 3s. a week - he slept there that night, and never came again; we missed the sheets off the bed as soon as he left the house - there was no other person there.
Cross-examined. Q. Do not you know that your husband and he went out at the door together? A. He stood talking with us at the parlour-door for two or three minutes - the sheets have not been found.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years longer .

2150.
WILLIAM JENNINGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 12 ozs. weight of leather, value 2s. , the goods of
Eusebius Smith
.

JOHN LEACH
. I live with Eusebius Smith, a leather-seller , in Kingsland-road
. On the 20th of August I was in the shop - the prisoner came in; he asked for some half soles; I put the box on the counter - he turned them out, and looked at them; while I was serving another customer I saw him secreting something in a bag, which he had on the counter - I kept my eyes on him, and observed him put some half soles in the bag a second time; he then looked out a pair - I pressed them for him, and he paid me- I then said, "What have you in your bag?" he said Nothing; I said, "You have some half soles;" he then said, "I will pay you for them" - the officer happened to come in; he took him, and found these half soles in his bag.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he must have put the goods into his bag by mistake.

GUILTY . Aged 49. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2151.
HENRIETTA HANAGAN
and
MARY CARBEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 17 yards of printed cotton, value 8s. , the goods of
William Shearman
.

THOMAS CHURCH
. I was passing Mr. Shearman's shop, in Chiswell-street
, on the 11th of August, about twelve o'clock, and saw the two prisoners looking at some prints at his door - I watched them, and saw Carbey put her hand under the print, and Hanagan walked round the shop- they then walked up to the print again; Carbey held up her apron, and Hanagan pulled this print down into her apron; Carbey walked off quick with it, and came towards me - the other prisoner was close behind her; I stopped Carbey, and when Hanagan came up I took her also - I took them to the shop.
WILLIAM SHEARMAN. I am a linen-draper , in Chiswell-street. This is my print.
Hanagan's Defence. I was going past the shop, and the print fell down - she took it up to take it to the shop; this witness took her; I went to ask him what for, and he took me.

HANAGAN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

CARBEY -
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2152.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
John Smith
, from his person .

JOHN SMITH. I live in the Commercial-road, and am a captain of a vessel . On the 8th of August, at half-past ten o'clock in the evening; I was walking in Grenada-terrace, Commercial-road
- I felt a tug at my pocket, I turned and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand; I said, "You scoundrel what are you about?" he immediately ran away - a young gentleman took him; I went up and found him in possession of the officer: I took up my handkerchief.

THOMAS SMITHERS
(Police-constable K 101). I was on duty, and saw the prisoner running - I took him; this handkerchief was picked up.
Prisoner. Q. Did I turn the corner with it? A. I did not see you drop it; I saw you run and turn one corner: they were pursuing you - I did not lose sight of you.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2153.
SAMUEL HILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , one 5l. Bank note, the property of
John Head
, from his person .

JOHN HEAD. I am a smith , and live at Maidstone. I was in Robert-street, Grosvenor-square, about the middle of July, 1831; I cannot tell the day - I had seen the prisoner before, when he had called at my shop, and asked if I had a job for him; he was a stone-mason : on the day in question he asked me, if I had a set of iron-work for an oven to sell - I said I had; he said if I would go with him and a gentleman, he thought he could get a customer, and a good job for himself - we went along Piccadilly, and he said, "We will have something to drink;" I said, "No, we will go and have our business done first," but he went into a public-house, and I had a glass of porter - we then went on to Westminster, and he showed me some premises in Tothill-street; I looked at them, and told the person not to have any thing to do with them, without he had 100l. to spare, and 100l. to lay out - we then all went to the Cock, in Tothill-street
; the other person spent half a crown in bread and cheese, and beer - the prisoner called for gin and water; I said to him, "Don't call for any thing without you have money to pay for it" - he went to countermand the order, but the landlord brought it, and I said, "It is a shame you should have this, we have had enough, but as it is come, I will pay for it:" I took out a 5l. note, and said to the landlord, "Can you give me change?" he said Yes; I wrote my name on it, and his wife called out at that moment -"You know we can't, we paid the brewer this morning;" the prisoner jumped up, snatched the note from my hand, and said, "I can get it changed:" he went off, leaving his hat, stick, and all behind him - he has been away from his wife and family for twelve months.

PHILIP WEBSTER
. I was with the prosecutor in August last; we saw the prisoner standing against the Sawyers' public-house: we went up to him; I said, "I suppose you know what we want you for?" he said,
"I have sent my friend to him several times to pay the money, and he could not see him;" he afterwards said, "I consider part of the money as mine, as we were in partnership."

Prisoner's Defence. I was sitting by his side and hegave the note into my hand, and said he had no more silver; I took it by his request - I have sent the money to him, and his wife and sister would not take it.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2154.
EDWARD HOUSE
,
JOSEPH HOWARD
, and
CHARLES HOWARD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 1 pair of boots, value 5s. , the goods of
Charles Smith
.

RICHARD VINNOR
. I am a baker. On the 18th of August I was in Lisson-grove
; I saw the three prisoners at Mr. Charles Smith's shop - he is a shoemaker ; Lewis was conversing with me, and pointed them out: and said they had taken a pair of boots - they all ran off together; I followed, and took them - I saw House buttoning up his trousers; I said to him, "What are you about?" he said, Nothing, and in the rear of his trousers I found these boots concealed.

JOHN LEWIS
. I am a shoemaker, and live near the prosecutor. I saw the three prisoners go to his shop - there were several persons serving customers; the prisoners took the opportunity, and one of them, but I cannot say which, took the boots - it was between seven and eight o'clock in the evening.

JOHN BYRNE
(Police-constable D 30). I took the prisoners, and have the boots.

CHARLES SMITH
. These are my property; I was at home, but busy in my shop - these were taken from the side of the door.

HOUSE -
GUILTY . Aged 12.

J. HOWARD -
GUILTY . Aged 8.

C. HOWARD -
GUILTY . Aged 10.
Whipped and Discharged.

2155.
SARAH ANN DIXON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 coral necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Michael Skallan
, from the person of
Catherine Skallan
.

SARAH SKALLAN
. I am the wife of Michael Skallan; we live in Hemlock-court
. On the 19th of August my daughter Catherine, who is six years old, went out to play; she had a coral necklace on - she called me about five o'clock, and said a woman wanted me; I went out, and missed the necklace - I saw the prisoner at Bow-street, in custody.

MARY ANN
IRONSIDE. I live in Hemlock-court. On Sunday, the 19th of August, I saw the little girl, about four o'clock, with the necklace - I missed her all at once, but about five o'clock I was going down the court, and saw the prisoner bring her to No.19, and go in there; I sat down at my door, and the prisoner brought the child out of No.19 again, and I took her to her own mother's door, and said to her, "Go and tell your mother I want to speak to her," and then she went away; the child had no necklace on then.

JOHN CLARK
. I keep a lodging-house. I have seen the prisoner frequently; on that Sunday night she brought me the coral necklace, and asked me if I would let her have 1s. on it, as she had had nothing to eat all day, and there was no pawnbroker's open - I let her have 1s., out of compassion, and the next morning she came and said her old man, who is a coachman, would not go out without his breakfast, and would I lend her another shilling, which I did, and the officer came and took the necklace.

JOHN Mc GRAH
(Police-constable F 160). I received this necklace from Clark.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2156.
SAMUEL CHANT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August , 1 pair of trousers, value 5s. , the goods of
Richard Law
.

RICHARD LAW
. I live in Hoxton Old-town
. On the 22nd of August I observed the prisoner standing by my parlour window; he then left the window, joined another man, and they both came running by the window - I went into my shop, told one of my young men I suspected them, and told him to go after them; he did so, and I was afterwards sent for to the watch-house, where I found these two men.

JOHN BLANCHARD
. I am a green-grocer. I saw the prisoner running, and several persons after him; I followed, and saw him take these trousers from under his jacket - he tried to throw them over a wall - they lodged upon a shed; I caught and held him till the officer came and took him - the trousers were then got down.

WILLIAM TAYLOR
(Police-constable N 179). I heard the alarm; Blanchard had caught the prisoner, and I came up and took him.

JOHN WINTLE
. I am a constable. I heard the alarm, and went to the place; I saw a boy take these trousers off the shed, and not knowing him, I took them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I did it through distress.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Six Months .

2157.
HENRY CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, and 3 shillings, the monies of
Robert Cooper
, from his person .

ROBERT COOPER. I am a paper-stainer , and live in Wellington-street, Kingsland-road; I had seen the prisoner several times, but I do not know what he was On the 18th of August I called in at the London Apprentice; I met the prisoner there - it was about twelve o'clock; I had received my wages at ten, and had in my pocket, one sovereign, one half-sovereign, and 5s. - he asked if I would give him a glass of ale, and I gave him one which I was drinking; he then asked me to go with him, and we called at one public-house going along - we then went to Collingwood-street
, and as I was very tired I fell asleep in about a quarter of an hour after I got into the house; in about an hour two young women awoke me up, and said my friend had taken my money out of my pocket - I got up, and they asked what I had lost; I said 1l. 15s. - the watchman was called in, and I gave charge of the prisoner; my money had been loose in my waistcoat pocket - the prisoner took off his coat, threw it down, and said, "You may search me;" the watchman took up his coat, and found in it, one sovereign, and one half-sovereign tied up in a silk handkerchief - there was some silver found in his breeches pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Are you married? A. Yes; I was not in the public-house five minutes, for it was time for them to shut up - I had only one glass of ale there; we had two glasses of rum a-piece - I knew in the morning where I was; I did not know that night - I did not know the number of the house, nor the name of thestreet - I was sensible - there was one young woman there when we got there, and another afterwards, and a young man who belonged to the house.

SUSAN HIGGINS
. I am an unfortunate girl, and live at No.7, Collingwood-street. On the 19th of August, about two or three o'clock in the morning, the prisoner came there, and the prosecutor with him - the prosecutor laid on the sofa, and went to sleep; the prisoner said, "I will go and see what money my friend has got;" he put his hands into both his waistcoat pockets, and took some money out -I saw some silver, but I did not see any gold; he put it into his trousers pocket - the prisoner then wanted to go up stairs with my friend Miss Slater, but she would not have any thing to say to him; he then went out, brought in two Policemen and the watchman, and said that Miss Slater had robbed him; the prisoner took off his coat, and threw it down at one end of the room; the watchman took it, and found in it an old silk handkerchief with a sovereign and a half tied up in it.

Cross-examined. Q. What house is this? A. A lodging house - there were myself, Slater, and Mr. Farley the landlord there, besides the prisoner and the prosecutor; they did not come to see us - they came, and wanted something to drink; the prisoner went up stairs with Slater, but he did not stop - we were all there when he took the money from the prosecutor's pocket; we did not say any thing to him; I saw some silver in one of his hands - he turned one of the prosecutor's pockets out.

WILLIAM FARLEY
. I was in the room, and saw the money found.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. A painter and glazier - I let the house in different apartments not to young women in particular - there was one man in the house named Size; the prisoner came to see him - I do not know what trade Size is; I believe these young women see gentlemen, but when I found what house it was I left it altogether - I was not there when the prosecutor and the prisoner came; I came down when the prisoner was making a great disturbance, and begged him to be quiet - I saw a sovereign and a half found in the coat.

JOHN YABSLEY
. I am a private watchman. I went, and found the sovereign and a half in the handkerchief in the coat.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you search the coat? A. In the parlour of the house - it is a brothel; when I said I should search the prisoner, he took some silver out of his trousers pocket, and it laid on the table; there were 8s. or 10s., there was no Policeman there then.

ISAAC GOUGEON
(Police-constable N 27). I took the prisoner, and found on him 11s. 6d.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the prosecutor - he knew perfectly well where he was going, for he named it to me; these two girls and this man were in the room - one of the girls went up stairs, and I after her, leaving the prosecutor on the sofa asleep; I then missed a sovereign and a half from my pocket, and being in liquor, I suppose I took it out of my fob and tied it in the handkerchief - I then called in the Policeman; we went into the parlour - the prosecutor was still asleep; the watchman came in, awoke him, and asked if he was robbed - he said No; he said,"You had better feel," and then he said, "I have lost 1l. 15s." I said,"Well, I will be searched," and I pulled off my coat; the girls said, "Serve him out;" they then beat me, and gave me a black eye.
NOT GUILTY .

2158.
JOSHUA CHAMBERLAIN
and
PHILIP CHAMBERLAIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of July , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
John Carter
.

CHARLES BREWER
. I take care of horses in a hackneycoach-yard; this coat is Mr.
John Carter
's property - he was taken ill on the Sunday morning, and I drove his coach - this coat was on the box; I had the care of it - one of the horses slipped down at the corner of Brick-lane, Church-street
, between two and three o'clock in the morning - I got down to get the horse up, and when I looked for the coat, it was gone.

JAMES WALTON
(Police-constable H 85). I was in Wentworth-street, and saw Philip Chamberlain come up a little court - he then turned, and went back; I thought something was wrong; I ran up, and saw him speaking to his brother Joshua, who then had a large coat on, and a stick in his hand - there was at that time a noise of some labourers going out to work; I turned to look at them, and the two prisoners were gone, but I knew them both; and soon after I saw Joshua come and speak to his brother without the great coat; two officers came up at the time, and I told them of it.

CHARLES RANDALL
(Police-constable H 68). Walton informed me of this; I went and took Joshua Chamberlain in Essex-street, and found this coat in a dust-hole, up a court, not far from where he had been standing, and this stick not far from him: the other officer took the other prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to).

Joshua Chamberlain
's Defence. I got up at a quarter past five o'clock to go to work; the gates of the yard were shut - I was waiting for some of the workmen, and this officer took me.
Philip Chamberlain's Defence. I came out with my brother - the gates were not open - I said, "We will go and call our shopmates."

J. CHAMBERLAIN -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

P. CHAMBERLAIN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

2159.
ELIZABETH MYNOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of August , 1 printed book, value 12s. , the goods of
Peter Wright
.

JOHN POYNTON
. I am son-in-law of Mr. Peter Wright, bookseller , High-street, St. Giles'
; I was at his shop accidentally, on the 2nd of August; I broke my watchglass, and went home to get another; while I was gone I was sent for, and missed this book, which I know is his.

MARTHA WELFORD
. I was passing the shop door a little after five o'clock in the afternoon, on the 2nd of August; I saw the prisoner take the book from the door - I followed, and took her and the book nearly opposite the church; I said, "You have stolen that book;" she dropped it - I took it up, and brought her back.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I saw a woman drop it, and I gave it to the officer.
MARTHA WELFORD. I saw the prisoner take it, she put her apron and shawl over it, and when I spoke to her, she dropped it.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2160.
CATHERINE MANCLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of April , 2 towels, value 2s., and 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
Richard Webb
.

MARGARET WEBB
. I am the wife of Richard Webb, and am a laundress - we live on Church-hill, St. Pancras
. I have known the prisoner twenty years - for the last few months she was in the habit of washing for me; I missed two towels.

JAMES BOURNE
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Brewers-street, Somers'-town. I have two towels, pawned for 8d., on the 21st of May - to the best of my belief, by the prisoner; I knew her well by her coming to our shop.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. And yet you have seen her frequently? A. Yes, but my employer took these in.

CHARLES MERCER
. I am in the employ of a pawnbroker. I have a handkerchief - I do not know who pawned it.

CHARLES MUMFORD
(Police-constable E 162). I took the prisoner at No.9, Manchester-street, Gray's Inn-road; I found the duplicates there.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose she was only a lodger? A. I believe it was an empty house, and an old person was there to take care of it - the prisoner directed me there; she said the duplicates were in the middle drawer, and that they were hers.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY. Aged 37.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

2161.
JEREMIAH NEALE
and
WILLIAM READ
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , 2 gallons of wine, value 30s., and 2 bottles, value 10d. , the goods of
Thomas Cotterell
.

THOMAS COTTERELL
. I live in Little Queen-street, Holborn
. At the next house to me there were some bricklayers' repairs going on at the back of my premises; on the 9th of August Read came and asked me to allow him to go down stairs and remove a large stone at a place which they were going to break up - I went down into my cellar with him, and helped him to remove the stone; I did not see Neale at that time, but between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, I saw Neale, who was the labourer, drunk- I had allowed him to fetch water from the pump in my cellar: I went down in about an hour, found my winecellar door open, and missed between two and three dozen of wine.

WILLIAM BURNHAM
. I am pot-boy to the prosecutor. I went down into his cellar, and found the wine-cellar had been forced open, but I did not know that any wine was gone; the prisoners were working in Mr. Robinson's cellar on the other side of the brick wall - they could get from one cellar to the other; I saw that Neale was tipsy when he came into our kitchen for water - he broke part of the dresser; he said he was not tipsy - I said he was, and I would not go away: their master then came there, and when he was gone I asked them how they got so tipsy - they said they had been drinking some porter; I asked where - they told me, and then I found they had been drinking some finings; I then went to look at our taps, to see if they dripped, and knocked down a bottle of wine which stood there; I asked where they got that from - they said from where the bottled ale stood; I said it was wine, and I gave it to them to smell - they threw it behind them into Mr. Robinson's cellar; I then asked them how much more they had taken - Read said five bottles - he told Neale to give me back what he had, and he gave me back three - one of them was ale, and the cork had been drawn.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You stopped a long time in the cellar? A. Yes; I did not take any myself; they were both tipsy, and hardly knew what they were saying; I saw no bottle of wine but the one that was broken.

SAMUEL WISE
(Police-constable A 86.) I was sent for, and informed the cellar had been broken; I watched to see if any thing was taken away - I saw one of them come up and look, and then I saw Neale come up with a hod on his shoulder - I stopped him, and found in the hod four bottles of wine; I took two of them - he threw the others down and tried to get off.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he not tipsy? A. He had been drinking, but he could walk and run very well; he walked to Bow-street afterwards - he was not tipsy.

THOMAS COTTERELL
. I found ten bottles of wine in all, but I missed more than two dozen.

Cross-examined. Q. What could become of the two dozen? A. I do not know; four of the ten I found were broken, and six are here - there had been a cork drawn of the ale, but I believe they had only just tasted that; they might have taken some wine at dinner time.
Neale's Defence. I know nothing about it, only Read brought me the stuff, and told me to drink it.
The prisoners received a good character.

NEALE -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

READ -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined One Year .

2162.
JOSEPH PITT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 18lbs. weight of ham, value 8s. , the goods of
Charles Charlton
.

GEORGE RUSSELL
. On the 28th of July I stopped the prisoner, in consequence of information; I found this ham on him, and took him - he said he took it from Charlton's, and was ready to pay for it.

JOSEPH RICHARDSON
. I live with Mr. Charles Charlton. It was his ham, and was on a board outside his window.
