Prisoner's Defence. I had been up to Notting-hill; a man had given me four or five glasses of liquor - on my return home I came near this shop, and I suppose I took it, not knowing what I was doing.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Confined Seven Days .

2163.
THOMAS STEVENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 truss of hay, value 2s. , the goods of
John Richards
.

JAMES COLE BERRY
. I keep a school at Finchley
. -On the 8th of September, about half-past two o'clock in the morning, I was at my own door, and heard the footsteps of a man approaching; I took particular notice, and observed that he turned into Mr. Richard's yard - I had just come off a journey, and taken off my shoes to puton another pair, and without saying any thing to my family, I went out, and saw the prisoner with a truss of hay, going from the prosecutor's yard; I followed him, and said he was very early employed that morning - he said he was employed by a gentleman to carry it; I said he should not go any further till he had satisfied me where he got it - he then said he picked it up, and had more right to it than any one, and he would not he stopped by me; I said he should not go any further, and insisted that he should take it back to where he got it from; he, after some time, took it back to Mr. Richards'; I called him up, and kept the prisoner in sight till he was taken.

JAMES GREGORY
. This is Mr. Richards' hay - he is a farmer ; I know it is a truss which I bound on Friday forenoon - it was taken the next morning; I had left it with a load tied for market - the prisoner had worked there formerly, and knew the place.

JAMES FROST
. I was called to take the prisoner - he has lived there for several years.
JOHN RICHARDS. I had hay of this quality, and have no doubt this is mine.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2164.
JULIA SENTRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 16 sovereigns, the monies of
Mary Ann Holland
, from her person .

The
prosecutrix did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 15.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2165.
THOMAS RICKLES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , 1 looking-glass, value 40s. , the goods of
Thomas Woodward
.

THOMAS JOHNSON
. I am a Policeman. About a quarter-past three o'clock in the afternoon I met the prisoner in Broad-street, St. Giles', with this glass - I followed him to Lincoln's Inn-fields, then said, "Halloo! you have a fine glass there" - he said Yes, and that he had brought it from Hawes, a broker, of No. 25, Wardour-street - I went and found a doctor lived there.

SARAH WOODWARD
. I am the wife of Thomas Woodward, a broker , of Carnaby-market
. This is our glass, and was taken off a chest of drawers - the prisoner is a stranger.
Prisoner's Defence. I was employed to carry it.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Confined Three Months .

2166.
SARAH JOHNSON
and
MARY JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 sovereign, 1 half-sovereign, 1 half-crown, and 4 shillings, the monies of
William Bews Harris
, from his person .

WILLIAM BEWS HARRIS. I am a carpenter - I live in Forest-row, Dalston. On Saturday night, between eleven and twelve o'clock, I met the prisoner in Bishopsgate-street- I had been drinking, but was in my senses; they accosted me; I went to two public-houses with them, and drank -I had a quartern of rum at the second house - a baker came in, and insulted me; he went away, and at that moment my purse was safe - I had taken it out of my fob in the prisoner's presence, to pay for the liquor; I had a sovereign, half a sovereign, half a crown, and 4s. in it - I went away, and was going home; the prisoners followed me, and came to me again; Johnson was on my left-hand side, and Jones on my right; she left me suddenly -Jones loitered rather behind, and Johnson called her, which excited my suspicion - I felt, and missed my purse from my left-hand pocket; I directly seized Johnson, and said she had robbed me - a Policeman came up; I told him - my bag of money was found concealed on Jones.

SILVANUS GILL
. I am a Policeman. The prosecutor accused the prisoners of robbing him; I took them both to the station - my wife searched them.

MARY ANN BEST
. I searched the prisoners, and found a bag on Jones, concealed in a certain part of her person.

SARAH GILL
. I am the Policeman's wife. Jones resisted being searched; the purse and money were found concealed where Best has stated.

WILLIAM BEWS HARRIS
, This is my purse, and the money was in it.
Johnson's Defence. I know nothing of it.

JOHNSON -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Life .

2167.
JOHN JONES
was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 coat, value 10s.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 8s.; 2 waistcoats, value 7s.; 1 pair of braces, value 3d., and 1 half handkerchief, value 2d. , the goods of
Joseph Humphrey
.

JOSEPH GALLOWAY
. I am an officer. On the 20th of August, about four o'clock in the morning, I heard a cry of Police! and apprehended the prisoner in a boat alongside a ship, in Ratcliff-cross tier
- I found this property on him.

JOSEPH HUMPHREY. I am master of the vessel . I lost my coat out of the cabin, and my pantaloons and two waistcoat from the state-room, where I sleep - the prisoner was taken in my ship's-boat, which was moored to the vessel; I know nothing of him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2168.
JOHN JONES
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 watch, value 3l. , the goods of
John Stock
.

JOHN GALLOWAY
. I found this watch on the prisoner.

JOHN STOCK. I belong to the Lord Teignmouth
, which was about four ships from Humphrey's; I lost this watch, which hung over my head in the bed-cabin of the Helen.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for 7 Years longer .

2169.
HELEN KAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 watch, value 3l.; 2 seals, value 10s.; 1 key, value 6d., and 1 chain, value 6d., the goods of
William Porthouse
, from his person .

WILLIAM PORTHOUSE. I am a cabinet-maker , and a married man. On Tuesday, the 26th of August, between twelve and one o'clock, I was going home and met the prisoner; I went to a house with her in Little Sutton-street, Soho
; after being with her, she went down stairs for some water, and did not return - I called the landlady, and gave information to Burton; I went with him, and found her at a public-house in Hanway-street, and saw him take the watch from her bosom.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GEORGE BURTON
. I am a Policeman. The prosecutor pointed the prisoner out to me; he was sober - I found the watch in her bosom.

Prisoner's Defence. He accosted me; he took me tothis house, and then would not give me any money, saying he had none - I said I would kick up a row; he wanted to go out - I put my back to the door, and began to cry; he said he was a married man, and did not want a row, and put the watch into my hand; he then brought it out again - I said I would disgrace him if he did not give it to me; he gave it to me again - I gave him my address, in Vine-street; he was to come for it.

WILLIAM PORTHOUSE
. I had 2l. in my waistcoat pocket; I said nothing about giving her my watch.

GEORGE BURTON
. He had got 2l.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2170.
GEORGE LUDMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 4 handkerchiefs, value 2s. , the goods of
Adam Randwell
.

IVAN HOPPEE
. I saw the prisoner with another young man; the prisoner took these handkerchiefs from Randwell's door, he held them up, and then put them into his bosom - I ran and stood before him, and he was secured.

WILLIAM FULLER
. I live with Adam Randwell, a linen-draper . These are his handkerchiefs, and were taken from the door.
Prisoner's Defence. I was running, hearing an alarm, and they took me.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2171.
THOMAS MELTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 1 gross of curtain-rings, value 4s. , the goods of
Robert Robertson
and
James Robertson
.

JOHN ALLMET
. On the 8th of August I was with Hitchings, and saw the prisoner pass with another young man; Hitchings turned after them, and they both ran away - I saw the prisoner drop a parcel from under his coat, which I took up.

CHARLES HITCHINGS
. I am a Policeman. I was with Allmet; I saw the prisoner drop this parcel of rings, and secured him; he was nearly three-quarters of a mile from I took up.

CHARLES HITCHINGS
. I am a Policeman. I was with Allmet; I saw the prisoner drop this parcel of rings, and secured him; he was nearly three-quarters of a mile from the prosecutors'.

ROBERT ROBERTSON
. I live in Bedford-place, Commercial-road
. These rings belong to my brother James and myself; they were in my father's house - a young man had come into the shop, and asked for locks, and taken them.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2172.
MARY OWEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 crown, 8 half-crowns, 25 shillings, and 9 sixpences, the monies of
Henry Bone
, from the person of Mary, his wife
.

MARY BONE
. I am the wife of Henry Bone, who lives in Adam and Eve-court, Whitecross-street
- he is a private watchman ; the prisoner rented a room of us in the next house, and had no business in my room. On Wednesday the 29th of August I had this money in a bag; there was a French shilling in it - I put it into my pocket, and put my apron over my face, and went to sleep between four and five o'clock in the afternoon; I was suddenly awoke, and the prisoner stood in the room; I said, "Oh, dear, why do you come creeping up here?" she stood a moment, then put her hands together, bent herself half double, and said,"Oh, you don't know my trouble; John is gone a walking with Mary Gray, and holding an umbrella over her;" John is her husband - I told her to go away; she went, and between nine and ten o'clock next day a person came to receive some money, and I missed it from my pocket - the prisoner came up about half an hour after I missed it, and seemed to feel for me very much, and wished very bad wishes on the person who took it; she came again about three o'clock, and said, "Oh, Mrs. Bone, my dear woman don't fret, for you will never see it any more;" I received information, and at last sent for an officer - 2l. odd of the money was found between the bricks of a cellar belonging to the prisoner.

MARY ANN GREEN
. I am the wife of Thomas Green. I had seen the Policeman looking about the prisoner's cellar, and shaking the mats, but a person said something which made go and take a light down into the cellar - I there picked up this bag with the money in it.

SOPHIA GRAY
. I live in the same house as Bone. On the 30th of August, at five o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner come out of her own cellar, with silver in her hand - I told a Policeman, and the cellar was searched; I saw her go to the gin-shop, and have three half-quarterns of gin, which she paid 6d. for.

JOSEPH GREGORY
. I am a Policeman. I received the bag from Green; it contains 2l. 8s. 3d., besides a French shilling - I found nothing on the prisoner.

MARY BONE
. This is my purse.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, declaring that she had never had the money in her possession, and that Green must have put the bag in the cellar.

MARY BONE
. I was not out of doors - other people had access to the cellar.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Confined Six Months .

2173.
JOSEPH LYE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 2 pairs of shoes, value 5s. , the goods of
James Corss
.

JAMES CORSS
. I am a shoemaker , and live in Shoreditch
. I was not at home when this happened.

JOHN HARPER
. I am a Policeman. On the 21st of August I saw the prisoner about two hundred yards from Corss' shop, and suspecting him I took him - I found these shoes on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 15. * -
Transported for Seven Years .

2174.
JOHN POOLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 jacket, value 2s.; 1 waistcoat, value 6d.; 1 cap, value 6d., 3 shillings, 1 sixpence, and 5 pennies , the property of
George Peters
.

GEORGE PETERS. I live with my father, who is a gentleman's butler. On the 5th of September I was bathing in the Regent's-canal, Regent's-park
, and left my clothes on the bank; the prisoner was fishing there - I got out, and put on my shirt and trousers; I saw the prisoner take up my jacket, take some money out of the pocket, and run away with my jacket, cap, and waistcoat - I called out and he was taken; he said he never took my money, but 2s. 6d. was found in his stockings; I had 3s. 11d., and lost 1s. 1d.

Prisoner. Q. How far was I from where your jacket was when I was stopped with it? A. About three yards, but you ran away with it - you threw them down, and was going to strike Lewis, and ran off, but I said you had stillgot some money - I had seen you take it out of my pocket; you did not ask me for it.

WILLIAM PETERS
. I was with my brother, but on the opposite side of the canal, standing by the prisoner's side; I saw him with the jacket in his hand rummaging the pockets - I saw him take some money out, and put it in to his bosom; my brother called out - he threw the things down, and said, "There is your money, it has fallen out of your pocket;" 2s. 6d. was found between his stockings and drawers when he was searched.

RICHARD LEWIS
. I was by the canal, and saw the prisoner fishing - I went up the hill, and saw him go and take up these clothes and make off with them; I turned, and ran after him - seeing me, he threw them down; I secured him, as Peters said he had the money; we scuffled; I heard money rattle in his breast - he stripped to his trousers, and said he had no money, but 2s. 6d. fell from his person; he resisted, and we both fell together - he got from me; I followed him, and told him to give me up the 1s. 1d. - he said he would; he then pulled out a knife, and attempted to strike me - but the crowd prevented him.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not threaten to throw me into the canal if I did not give up the 1s. 1d.; I then told you to mind, for I had a knife? A. Not a word of it is true.

CHARLES HENRY WOODHAM
. I am a Policeman. I received him in charge, with this dinner knife.
Prisoner's Defence. I had the knife for fishing, but never intended to rob any body.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2175.
THOMAS WALTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of May
, 14 quarts of milk, value 3s., the goods of
Henry Cleeve
, and another ; and
JOHN BEAVAN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen .
MR. CLARKSON conducted the prosecution.

JOHN BAKER
. I live in the Edgware-road
, where the business of the West London Dairy is done - I am clerk to Henry Cleeve and William Wilberforce, the proprietor s; Walton was in the service of the company - it was his duty to carry milk on the 23rd of May to the Middlesex-hospital; they were to have eight gallons and two quarts - the cans would hold more; I do not know how much he took out, but in consequence of information I and Batten watched him - he left the premises about ten minutes or a quarter to six o'clock, in the cart; he went first to Marylebone-workhouse, left milk there, and then to Beavan's house, which is in Great Portland-street, within one door of the corner of Mortimer-street; I stood at the corner of Mortimer-street, and saw him stop at Beavan's, and pull off the lid of the can from under the bar, which is locked down to prevent the milk being adulterated; Beavan had come out and got into the cart before he did that - Walton had two pails; he took milk out of the can and put into a pail; Beavan then got out of the cart - Walton handed the pail of milk out to him; I then seized the pail - Mr. Cleeve was out of town at the time; I took the milk home and measured it - there were fourteen quarts; I did not take the prisoners into custody at the time - Walton came home about half-past seven o'clock, and absconded directly

Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Did you not know he was living with Mr. Caudwell ever since? A. I did not; it happened about twenty-five minutes past six o'clock - I believe the milk was delivered right at the Middlesex-hospital; Mr. Cleeve manages the business - I did not see the milk put into the can; it was warm when I took it out - I cannot say water was not mixed with it, because the prisoner was trusted to measure it - I took it from Beavan's hand, just under his window; he keeps a milk-walk.
Re-examined. Q. Did you know him before? A. Yes, he dealt with the concern about two months before, and knew Walton was in their service - the hospital people keep a key of the can.

WILLIAM BATTEN
. I went with Baker to watch; his evidence is true in every particular.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know Beavan was in Mr. Caudwell's employ? A. No, I never saw Walton after he absconded.
MR. DONNE called -

MARK CAUDWELL
. I am a cow-keeper and dairyman, and live in Peter-street, Wardour-street. Walton was in my employ for nine weeks, till he was apprehended - my cows are kept in the Regent's-park, and his nearest way there was to pass the prosecutor's premises.

WALTON. -
GUILTY . Aged 37.

BEAVAN. -
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Seven Years .

2176.
JAMES PHILLIPS
&
WILLIAM BRYAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August, four printed books, value 10s. , the goods of
John Rodwell
.

EDWARD JONES
. I am a Policeman. On the 20th of August, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I met Phillips in Marylebone-lane, with four books under his arm; I asked where he was going - he said to his father's to read, and that he had brought them from a bookseller in Bond-street; I said he must show me the place, and as we went towards Bond-street, he stopped short and said the books were stolen - I took him to the station; he said he got them from
Bill Bryan
; I went and took Bryan, and asked if he had seen Phillips that morning - he said he had; I asked if he knew any thing about the books - he said not; I took him to the station, and told Phillips to repeat what he had said to me; he then said "You gave me the books;" Bryan said "Well, I did;" I knew them to be companions.

THOMAS LORAIN WILKIN
. I am in the employ of
John Rodwell
, bookseller , of Bond-street
. These books are his, and were taken off a shelf opposite the door, and about twelve yards from it - I never saw the prisoners.
Bryan's Defence. I met Phillips in Marylebone-lane; I had a pair of boots to sell - I went to sell them, and the Policeman took me when I got home.

PHILLIPS -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

BRYAN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Six Weeks .

2177.
WILLIAM WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 1 pocket, value 6d.; 1/2 oz. of stoneblue, value 1d.; 1 shilling; 1 sixpence; 3 pennies, and5 halfpence, the property of
Ann O'Dell
, from her person .

ANN O'DELL
. I go out washing. On the 15th of August, I had been to Tabernacle-walk - I had some ale given to me, which I am not used to, and was used very ill by some prostitutes; when I left home I had two shillings, a sixpence, three pennies, and five halfpence, in my pocket, with a bit of stone-blue; my pocket strings were broken, and the pocket snatched off by a man who came up to me, and said something abusive; the Policeman came up and asked where I lived; I know I had half an ounce of stone-blue in my pocket - I do not know the prisoner.

WILLIAM LAW
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty in Shoreditch
, soon after eleven o'clock. The prosecutrix was rather in liquor - some girls said something to her; she said, "D - n them, d - n the whores;" they run after her, knocked her down, and made her nose bleed -I took care of her; in Church-street the prisoner came out of a public-house, looked under her bonnet, and said,"Halloo, what is the matter?" I said, "Do you know her?" - he said Yes, and said to her, "Do'nt you know your Billy?" she said, "Yes, I know you Billy,," and he walked away with her.

SAMUEL MOORE
. I am a Policeman. I saw the prisoner in Church-street, with his arm round the prosecutrix's waist; I was looking after him, as it was suspected he would rob her - I saw him run from her, and run down Club-row; she called out, "You have got my pocket" - she was in liquor, but sober enough for that; I then pursued him, but he got away; Shippey, a private watchman, took him in about an hour, and gave him to me - I searched, and found on him two penny-pieces, and some stone-blue; Shippey picked up a pocket; he must have gone down where it was found.

ROBERT SHIPPEY
. I am a private watchman. I saw the prisoner come out of the public-house, and say "Come along with your Billy" - I knew the prisoner very well, and followed about fifteen yards distant, and when they had walked about one hundred yards, I heard her say,"You b - y villaim, give me my pocket;" he ran towards Club-row - I ran in the direction he took, and picked up the pocket.

ANN O'DELL
. This is my pocket, which was cut off; I had a piece of stone-blue in it, exactly like this - the prisoner was a perfect stranger to me.
Prisoner's Defence. I am quite innocent.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2178.
LOUISA WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 20 yards of ribbon, value 5s. , the goods of
James Walker
.

JAMES WALKER
. I am a haberdasher , and live in Blackmoor-street, Clare-market
. On the 8th of September the prisoner and another came, and asked to look at some gauze ribbons; I placed a box on the counter before them; both took up different pieces, what I call crosshanded; I replaced them as quick as possible, and observed a vacancy - I observed the prisoner's left arm confining her shawl, and saw a projection; she moved to the other side of her companion - I opened her shawl, and took this piece of ribbon from under it; I jumped over the counter - her companion said, "What have you been doing, how could you think of such a thing?" they were both taken to the station - her companion was discharged, on promising to attend at Bow-street at eight o'clock, to produce the pattern of a ribbon they had bought before, but she never came.
Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. You did not see her take it? A. No; she conducted herself otherwise very properly.

Prisoner's Defence. I met a young woman in Drury-lane, who asked me to go with her; she looked at several ribbons, and told me to look at this piece at the door; the shop being dark I did so, then came back, and laid it on the counter - she saw none she liked; I took it up again to see if she would have it, and the gentleman snatched it out of my hand; he said I wanted to rob him, and he would make me suffer for all.

JAMES WALKER. I said I recollected her being there a few days before when I lost a piece of ribbon, and suspected her, and now she must suffer for all; I had missed this ribbon two or three minutes before I took it from under her shawl.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Fined One Shilling and delivered to her former mistress .

2179.
JOHN WALLACE
and
MARGARET WALLACE
were indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 29th of July , of an evil-disposed person, 14 pairs of stays, value 2l., the goods of
William Thomas
, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute.

WILLIAM THOMAS. I am a wholesale stay-manufacturer , in Cheapside
. The prisoner John Wallace was in my employ about eighteen months, and left about four months ago; since which I have continually seen him loitering about the door; my stock is very extensive - I could not miss these articles; they are not quite finished, and not in a state for sale.

ABRAHAM ISAACS
. I keep a slopseller's shop in Rosemary-lane - one shop is for women's apparel. On the 19th of July, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I was present when the prisoner John Wallace came to my wife, in the women's shop, with eight pairs of stays, which he asked 26s. for; she offered 24s., which he agreed to take - I asked who was the maker; he said his mother, that his sister stitched them, and they gave them to him to hawk about the shops - I asked if he would go to his mother with me; he said Yes - we went; when he got up one pair of stairs he called Mother! the female prisoner came down, and walked thirty or forty yards with me; I asked if she was the maker of the stays - she said, "Yes, I make them, my daughter stitches them, and I give them to my son to hawk" - I then took him home to my shop; my wife gave him 24s., and he gave a receipt, in the name of Wallace - two or three days after I found his name was Murphy - on the 29th of July, about nine o'clock in the morning, he brought eight pairs of stays in a basket; I took him into the parlour, and said, "You have deceived me; your name is not Wallace, but Murphy" - he said, "No, it is Wallace;" I said, "Well, I am a headborough, and insist on knowing how you came by them;" he said, "For God's sake don't hurt me; a young man gave them to me to sell, and they came from a warehouse" - I asked where theyoung man was to be found, and where the warehouse was- he gave me no answer; I gave him in charge - I had five pairs of the eight he sold me left - the daughter was tried last Tuesday.

JOHN DALE
. I am a Policeman. I took charge of John Wallace; he said he got the stays from a lad who worked for a City warehouse, but would not say who he was.

WILLIAM DICKINSON
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the mother; she told me she made the stays, that they were her own, and she gave them to him for sale.
The property was here produced and sworn to by several of the prosecutor's work people.
MR. THOMAS. I can swear these are my property, they have never been sold; I have twenty or thirty work people in my warehouse.

J. WALLACE -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

M. WALLACE -
GUILTY . Aged 37.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

2180.
JOHN WELSH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 1 watch, value 2l., the goods of
Daniel Goode
, from his person .

DANIEL GOODE
. I am a farmer's labourer , and live at Hornsey. I was in Canonbury-fields
; I felt tired, and fell asleep - I awoke in a few minutes, and found the waist band of my breeches open, and my watch gone from my fob; it was in the day-time.

Prisoner. Q. Do you recollect being in my company? A. I was not - he is a perfect stranger to me; I had been up all night at master's business with his cows, as I went along a person represented himself as a sailor in distress, and asked me to give him a quartern of gin, which I did; but whether it was the prisoner I do not know.

THOMAS HOBBS KING
. I am a Policeman. I was with my brother officer in Canonbury fields; we went to relieve two other officers, and as we stood talking together, I saw the prisoner laying on his belly by the prosecutor - knowing the prisoner, I watched and saw him get up and leave, and just as he got by us, he threw away a stick, which belonged to the prosecutor, and ran up the field - I ran and asked the prosecutor if he knew the man who had been laying by his side - he said nobody had been by his side; his trousers were undone - he felt and missed his watch; I ran after the prisoner: my brother officer ran one way and I the other, and in the Lower-road I met him in custody.

JAMES CANTY
. I am a Policeman. King told me of this robbery; I went and saw the prisoner running out of the field; I secured him opposite the Queen's-head, and found the watch on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that he had found the prosecutor laying on the ground at Islington, and after assisting him, he took him to a public-house, and gave him gin, then desired him to go on with him; on getting into the fields, he gave him his watch to mind, and sent him for a coach, which he was going for when the Policeman stopped him.

THOMAS HOBBS KING
. The prosecutor was in liquor, but knew what he was about; it was church time, and we let him remain at the station - he went to sleep there; the prisoner did not say the watch was given to him, but denied knowing any thing of him.

CHARLES HAYWARD
. I keep the Two Brewers, Lower-road, Islington. I recollect the two men coming to my house on a Sunday morning; after I served them the prosecutor used bad language, which I told him not to do, or I should call the Police - the prisoner said, "Leave him to me, Mr. Hayward, I will take care of him;" the prosecutor paid 6d. for what was drank, and the prisoner took him away - they were about ten minutes in my house.

DANIEL GOODE
. I never gave him my watch to take care of.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2181.
JAMES ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 1 shirt, value 2s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 6d.; 2 bags, value 1s.; 1 brush, value 3d.; 1 pair of scissors, value 6d.; 1 tea-canister, value 6d., and 1 towel, value 2d. , the goods of
Thomas Goslin
.

THOMAS GOSLIN. I live in Philip-street, St. George's
. I have known the prisoner some time; he came to me, stating that he was in distress for a lodging; I let him sleep in my room - next morning he asked me to let him have the key to let himself in; I did so - I returned about eight o'clock in the evening, and could not get in; I was going to break the door open, and the key fell from the top of it - I opened it, went in, and missed these articles; all the rest of my things were packed up, ready to be carried away.

JAMES HARRIS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shirt, which was pawned by the prisoner.(Shirt produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I only took the shirt, as I had no bread to eat.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Three Months .

2182.
RICHARD WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 sovereign , the money of
William Brown
.

WILLIAM BROWN. I am apprentice to a jeweller . Last Saturday-night I gave the prisoner a sovereign, telling him to get it changed and bring it to me; he is a pot-boy - he went away and never returned; I found him in Covent-garden watch-house on Monday.
Prisoner's Defence. I met a young man and drank with him; I was tipsy, and made away with the sovereign.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Six Weeks .

2183.
MARGARET VURNALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , 1 pair of boots, value 3s., the goods of
Ellen Connell
, from her person .

The
prosecutrix did not appear NOT GUILTY
NEW COURT. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 15.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2184.
GEORGE PICKERING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 truck, value 40s. , the goods of
Peregrine Peck
. - To which the prisoner pleaded

GUILTY . -
Confined Three Months .

2185.
JAMES SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on on the 6th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Samuel Bennett
, from his person .

JOSEPH SHACKELL
. (Police-constable A 10). I was at South Mimms race-course
, on the 6th of September; Isaw the prisoner attempt several gentlemen's pockets; he at last got to Mr. Samuel Bennett's, of No. 38, High-street, and drew this handkerchief from his pocket; I know Mr. Bennett, but he is not here - I tapped him on the shoulder - he missed this handkerchief, and claimed it; the prisoner said he did it through want; I saw him at first with another person, and then alone.
Prisoner. I am a bricklayer's labourer . I have had nothing to do for a long time; I saw the gentleman's handkerchief partly out of his pocket, and I took it.

GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Three Months .

2186.
JAMES THOMAS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of August , 1 waistcoat, value 4s.; 1 tablecloth, value 2s.; 1 pair of scissors, value 2s.; 1 jacket, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pair of trousers, value 1s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
Charles Goodman
; and that he he had been before convicted of felony .

CHARLES GOODMAN. I live in Margaret-court, Oxford-market
, and am a tailor . I lost these things on the 23rd of August - they were worth about 12s.; they had been safe in my house the night before, and I missed them between six and seven o'clock in the morning from the back room, at the top of the house, where I work, and where my children sleep.

GEORGE JOHN RESTIEAUX
(Police-constable E 49). I took the the prisoner into custody on the 23rd of August, between six and seven o'clock in the morning; he had in his basket the articles stated in the indictment; and he had, concealed in his sleeve, three keys and a purse, with 12s. 6d.; one of the keys opens the door of the house in which the prosecutor lives - it is a latch-key; I asked how he got the things, but he would not say any thing, but pretended to cry - he was particularly reserved.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN VENNEL
(Police-constable S 140). I have a certificate of the conviction of the prisoner, which I got from Mr. Clark's office; I was present when the prisoner was tried on the 16th of February - he is the person, and was three months in Newgate.

GUILTY . Aged 37. -
Transported for Life .

2187.
SELINA TURNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 half-crown and 1 shilling, the monies of
William Tocknell
, from his person .

WILLIAM TOCKNELL. I live in Blenheim-street, Oxford-street, and am an engraver . On the 1st of September I was near a dead wall in Old-street-road
; the prisoner was there talking to another person - I passed her; she came and asked me to go home with her - she put her hand under my arm and put her hand into my trousers pocket; she took out a half-crown and a shilling; I asked her to give me what I had lost- she asked me several times what it was, and kept walking with me till we came to a public-house; she went in there, and asked what I would take - I asked for my money; she got between two men and got out- the men prevented my following her, but I got out at another door; I gave an alarm, and the officer took her - I am certain she is the person.

Q. Have you not before said that you saw a female, and you really believed she was the person who robbed you? A. I have said so, but I am certain she is the person - she was taken and one half-crown, a shilling, a sixpence, and some halfpence were found on her; I had felt it safe ten minutes before I lost it - in my way home a young man followed me from the station as far as Finsbury-square, and he offered to lay down his life if I would take the money of him, and offered me double and treble the amount - he spoke so feelingly, that I took 3s. 6d. from him, and he wanted me to take more - I went to the Police-office after that, but I thought it would be all settled; I did not mean to go any more, but I was sent for on Wednesday.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you meet the prisoner? A. On Saturday, about eleven o'clock; I did not say I would not be sure she was the woman - I expressed some doubt of her identity; I went by her dress as much as any thing at the time, but I know quite well she is the person - she had another dress on, but I can be positive as to her features,

Q. Did not the gentleman who came up to you say it was not the prisoner who took the money? A. No, he said he was not present at the transaction; I took the 3s. 6d. of him, and I might have had a larger sum.
COURT. Q. Was your doubt respecting her dress? A. Yes, I had no doubt about her person - I saw her under the wall, and again at the public-house.

GEORGE KEMP
(Police-constable N 82.) I was applied to on the night of the 1st of September to take the prisoner - I had before heard a cry of Stop thief! and ran, and the prisoner ran by me; I knew her well- the prosecutor was following two or three yards behind; he said that was the person, and I pursued and took her to the station, after great resistance - I searched her, and took her pocket from her; I found a half-crown piece, a shilling, a sixpence, and some copper in it.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2188.
JOHN TYLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 4lbs. weight of beef, value 2s. , the goods of
John Harradence
.

JOHN HARRADENCE. I keep a butcher's-shop in Goswell-road
. On the 1st of September the prisoner purchased a piece of beef, and paid 1s. 8 1/2d. for it -I had been watching him - he brought in one piece to be weighed, but had taken two off; I saw him put the other piece in his jacket - when he had walked out I followed, and took him into custody; I found the other piece of beef on him, tied in a handkerchief - it weighed 3 lbs. 2 ozs. - I knew it from its appearance.

Prisoner. When I went into the shop I asked him what it was a pound - he said 7 1/2d.; I said, "If I take two bits will you let me have them for 7d.?" he said No - I took one piece, and put it into the scale; he then said, "You shall have the two pieces for 7d.;" he said they came to 3s. 9d. - I gave him two half-crowns, and he gave me 1s. 3d. out. Witness. It is not true; I never sold him the two pieces - he brought it under his coat, and did not pay for it.

WILLIAM CLIFTON
(Police-constable N 143.) I stopped the prisoner, and found on him two pieces of beef - they were produced before the Magistrate, and sworn to; the prisoner said he had bought them both.

JOHN HARRADENCE. The prisoner took two pieces of beef, but only paid for one, with one half-crown; he then went over the way, and tied up the two pieces in a handkerchief - he then went and had some oysters: I followed him till I saw the officer.

GUILTY . Aged 44. -
Confined Three Months .

2189.
WILLIAM THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
James Hunt
, from his person .

JAMES HUNT. I live in Edgware-road, and am a corn-chandler . On the evening of the 8th of September I was in Broad-street, St. Giles'
- the officer came to me; I felt and missed a handkerchief, which I had used just before - this is it.

WALTER CAMPBELL
(Police-constable E 95.) I was on duty in Broad-street, and saw the prisoner in company with another boy, within about a yard of the prosecutor -I saw the prisoner draw his hand as if from the prosecutor's pocket; I took hold of him, and he dropped the handkerchief - the other got away.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. It was about half-past seven o'clock; there was another boy in company with me, and when he saw the Policeman he made his escape; I had not seen the handkerchief.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Three Months .

2190.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 1 snuff-box, value 3l., the goods of
Joseph Steffanoni
, from his person .

JOSEPH STEFFANONI. I am an upholsterer , and live at Holborn-bars. On the 18th of July I was near Red Lion-street
; I felt a hand in my coat pocket - I turned, and took hold of the prisoner; I charged him with stealing my snuffbox, which I had just missed; he said he had not got it, but he put his hand behind him, and threw the box into the middle of Holborn.
Prisoner. There were three or four more persons there. Witness. I did not see them; I believe there was one more, but I am certain the prisoner threw it.

JOHN VAUGHAN
. I am a horse-dealer, and live in Providence-place, Finsbury. I was with the prosecutor, and when he seized the prisoner I saw him throw the box behind him; a gentleman took it up.
THOMAS BUTTRESS (Police-constable E 142.) I took the prisoner, and have the box.

GUILTY . Aged 19. * -
Transported for Seven Years .

2191.
JOHN LEARY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 1 shovel, value 2s. 3d. , the goods of
William Plumridge
.

WILLIAM PLUMRIDGE. Last Monday night I was at the Belgrave hotel
, and saw the prisoner, whom I had known some time; my shovel was inside the settle in the tap-room - I did not leave the room till I missed it.

JAMES SIMPSON
. I was near the door of the Belgrave hotel, and saw the prisoner with this shovel, just by the door - I had seen him half an hour before; he uses a shovel, but not one like this.

JOHN PETTY
(Police-constable B 102). I took the prisoner near the Belgrave hotel last Monday night - he said he lived at No. 4, Little Ebury-street; I went there, and found this shovel and another - the prosecutor identified this.

JAMES WEATHERHEAD
. I saw the prisoner come to the Belgrave hotel that night - he had no shovel then.(Property produced and sworn to.
Prisoner's Defence. I got a drop too much - I went to this house, and took this shovel, I suppose, thinking it was mine.
JAMES SIMPSON. I know he worked just by - he might be a little in liquor.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Confined Two Months .

2192.
JOHN JONES
and
WILLIAM BONNER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 4 shillings, 1 sixpence, 3 pence, and 4 halfpence, the monies of
Moses Odam
, from the person of
Catherine Odam
.

CATHERINE ODAM. I am the wife of Moses Odam - we live in Cleveland-street, Fitzroy-square; he is a cabinetmaker . On the 11th of September I was standing at Westminster-bridge
, when there was a crowd looking at a rowing-match; the prisoners came up to me, and shortly afterwards I saw Bonner draw his hand from my right side pocket - I then heard him call to the other prisoner, who was just behind him; I saw him put the money into Jones' hand, and they walked on; I missed 4s. 6d. and 5d. in halfpence - my husband was near me; I told him - he followed the prisoners - I looked for a constable, and gave them in charge; they were walking at the other end of the bridge.

ROBERT GLASGOW
(Police-constable P 21). I took the prisoners: I found on Jones one half-crown, one shilling, and 4 1/2d., and on Bonner one half-crown, and 3 1/4d.

CATHERINE ODAM
. The prisoners were taken from five to ten minutes afterwards - I had no half-crowns; my money was in shillings and sixpences.
Jones' Defence. I was going to see the rowing-match; Bonner touched me, and asked me to go over the bridge- he said he was going to a boat.
Bonner's Defence. I saw Jones, and went with him to try to borrow a boat, to follow the rowing-match; I was cutting an apple, and the officer took us.

MOSES ODAM. My wife told me what had happened, and that the prisoners had her money - I watched them, and told her to get an officer; they walked along the bridge, and got a little past the middle - a third person joined them, and after a conversation of a minute or two, he left them, and they set down - I watched till my wife brought the officer.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

BONNER -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Twelve Months .

2193.
WILLIAM HERSWELL
and
ALFRED KRELLE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Gwyllym
, from his person .

WILLIAM COLTON
. I am a broker, and live at Westminster-place, Battle-bridge. On the 9th of September I was with
John Cadby
- I saw the two prisoners following the prosecutor and a lady, while I was passing Bushill-row; I saw something taken from the prosecutor's pocket in Finsbury-square
- then they run off; I went tothe gentleman, and asked if he had lost any thing; we followed the prisoners, and in Cross-street I saw them looking at the handkerchief, under a lamp: Krelle put it on his neck - he ran off; he took it off his neck as he run, and threw it down - I took it up, and took him; Cadby brought back Herswell.

JOHN CADBY
. I am a constable. I was with Colton; I have heard what he said - I saw Kreele throw down the handkerchief, and I took Herswell; at the station, Krelle said that the other prisoner picked it up, and gave it to him.
THOMAS GWYLLYM. This is my handkerchief; it has my name on it - I lost it in Finsbury-square; I cannot say that I saw the prisoners running - I saw some persons running; perhaps they were among them.
The prisoners received a good character.

HERSWELL -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

KRELLE -
GUILTY . Aged 12.

Confined Fourteen Days and
Whipped .

2194.
RICHARD HUDSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 waistcoat, value 5s.; 1 pair of shoes, value 4s., and 1 hat, value 4s. , the goods of
William Henry Dickinson
.

WILLIAM HENRY DICKINSON
. I am a shoemaker , and live with my mother,
Mary Hudson
, who is the prisoner's mother - I am the prisoner's half brother; I am the elder brother; the prisoner lodged with my mother in Luntly-place, Brick-lane
; we slept in the back room first floor. On the 3rd of September I went out, locked the parlour door, and had the key - I found the door had been forced open when I returned; I missed my coat, waistcoat, hat, and shoes from my bed-room - the prisoner was then out, and did not return till Thursday morning; he then came home, and denied taking the things; I had not lent them to him.

JOSEPH HAWES
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce a coat, waistcoat, and shoes, pawned on the evening of the 3rd of September, by the prisoner - I am confident he is the man; it was between seven and eight o'clock.
Prisoner. Last Monday week I was at Barnet-fair between eight and nine o'clock, which is the time he said at the office that I pawned them.

JOHN BROOKS
(Police-constable H 64) I took the prisoner at his mother's, where he lodged.
GUILTY. Aged 19.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Confined Six Months .

2195.
AMELIA DEBNEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 purse, value 6d.; 5 sovereigns, and 1 crown, the property of
Charles Stewart
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

2196.
JOHN EVANS
and
ANN PRESSER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 pillow and case, value 3s.; 1 sheet, value 2s., and 1 flat-iron, value 1s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Reily
.

ELIZABETH REILY. I live in Little Windmill-street, St. James'
; I am a widow . The prisoners took a furnished room of me as man and wife - they slept there that night, and the following; and when they came the third night I got an officer, who took them, and we missed the articles, which had been in the room when they took it.

DANIEL CHAPMAN
(Police-constable C 38). I received the two prisoners; I asked if they had pawned the property, and if they had got the duplicates, to give them up: Presser put her hand into her bosom, pulled out the duplicates, and gave them to me.

GEORGE TURNER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet, which I took in of a female on the 7th of September, in the name of
Mary Evans
, No. 3, Windmill-street - I do not remember whether it was the prisoner; one of the duplicates was the one given.

SAMUEL HOSLOCK
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pillow-case, pawned on the 8th of September, in the name of Ann Evans, No. 7, Earl-street; this is the duplicate I gave.
Evans' Defence. I knew nothing about them till I came home at night, and then I said they should be fetched out directly.
Presser. I pawned them, but intended to get them out that evening, but it was too late.(Property produced and sworn to.)

EVANS -
GUILTY . Aged 37.

PRESSER -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

2197.
JOHN ELMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 1 jacket, value 10s., and 1 handkerchief, value 18d. , the goods of
Henry Alexander Reatt
.

WILLIAM HARK
(Police-constable C 34). On the morning of the 11th of July, at two o'clock, I stopped the prisoner in Regent-street, and asked what he had under his coat; he said Nothing - I pulled it open, and found this jacket, and the handkerchief in the pocket of it - these are the articles the prosecutor swore to at the office, but he is not here; he gave his name as Henry Alexander Reatt.
Cross-examined by MR. DONNE. Q. Were there any other persons about? A. Yes, several.

MARY ANN JONES
. I live in St. Martin's-street, and do needle-work. I saw the prisoner take the jacket off the flags in Regent-street
- there was another person with him when he took it; I saw Mr. Reatt there - he took the jacket off, and gave it to another person, who put it on the rails; it fell off the rails, and the prisoner took it - he was pursued, and taken.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know any thing of Mr. Reatt? A. I was in company with his brother, who is not here; I heard the prosecutor called by the name of Henry Alexander Reatt - I only knew him by the name of Henry; I always said I saw the prisoner take it.

COURT. Q. What is Mr. Reatt? A. I do not know; he had no other jacket on - he had a scuffle with some other person; he took his jacket off, it fell, and the prisoner came and took it - he ran away, and I told of it.

WILLIAM HARK. Reatt is a young gentleman, about sixteen or seventeen years old - I believe he had been struck, and he took his jacket off to return it; he gave his address in Charlotte-street - I went there, and heard he was gone abroad.
Prisoner's Defence. I never ran away with the jacket - I was walking along.

WILLIAM HARK. He was walking away, and a gentleman came up and said, "That man has stolen a jacket from my friend;" I said, "What have you got?" he saidNothing; he showed a deal of consequence, and said he was a gentleman; I said, "Whether you are or not I shall see what you have got" - I opened his coat, and found this jacket.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

2198.
ELLEN CLEARY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; 6 shillings, and 6 sixpences, the property of
James Marshall
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

2199.
MARY BATES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 7 sovereigns, and 10 shilings, the monies of
Henry Fraser
, from his person .

HENRY FRASER. I live in Windmill-street, Finsbury-square, and am a mariner . On the 30th of June, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I met the prisoner in Old-street-road, and went with her to a house in the Vinegar-yard
; she sat on the bed, and I felt her feeling in my pocket, but I did not know she had any intention of robbing me - in about a quarter of an hour she left the room, leaving her bonnet behind her; I then missed from my pocket seven sovereigns and ten shillings - I had counted my money before I sat on the bed; I ran down stairs, and as soon as I got out of the door, I was thrown down by a man - I ran after the prisoner, and met a Policeman, whom I told of it; I did not see the prisoner again till last Monday evening - I am certain she is the person.

JOHN SCRIVEN
(Police-constable G 172). I was in Chiswell-street on the 10th of September; the prisoner was pointed out to me by the prosecutor - she denied the charge.

Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing of the robbery, and had not been out of doors that evening - he stated that he had been with two females, one of whom is here; I had never seen him in my life before last Monday, when I was taken - he had others taken.

HENRY FRASER
re-examined. Q. Did you have any other persons taken? A. No; the officer had information, and took one who had been in company with her that night - I have no doubt whatever of her being the person; I heard her speak in the room, and in the street.

MARY BAKER
. On the 30th of June I was walking down the City-road with Sarah-Edwards; the prosecutor came up and spoke to us - he was very much in liquor, and asked us to take a glass of any thing to drink; we walked to the Castle public-house, and had a glass of wine each - he went with as to Edwards door and there said he would go home with me for the night - I would not let him; I went home, and about one o'clock I heard a knock at my door - I got up, and then saw the prosecutor and three Policemen; one of them put his light before my face, and the prosecutor said he was sure I was the girl; they came in and turned out my drawers - then he said it was not me, it was a fairer girl.
HENRY FRASER. The Policeman went in search of the prisoner, and they would search the house, but I said Baker was not the girl.

SARAH EDWARDS
. On the 30th of June I was in the City-road - the prosecutor came, and asked me and Baker to have something to drink; we went to the Castle, and each had a glass of wine, for which he paid - this was about ten o'clock; in about an hour afterwards I was out, and met him with the officer - he said, "This is the woman;" I was taken and searched - they asked where Baker lived, and I told them; he has been home with me since.
HENRY FRASER. Yes I have, but I did not see her that night, nor have any wine with her.
NOT GUILTY .

2200.
CHARLES BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of July , 1 window sash, value 5s. , the goods of
John Riel
.

JOHN RIEL
. I live in Beaumont-street, Mile-end-road; I deal in building materials . I lost a sash, which I bought in St. Martin's-lane
; it was inside one of the houses.

PHILIP LONG
. I am a labourer. I stopped the prisoner carrying the sash on the 23rd of July, at a house at the corner of St. Martin's-lane - he was running across the road with it; he said a man gave it to him - it was then about twenty minutes before eight o'clock; I asked him to show me the man - he said he could not; he was going towards Whitechapel - it is a good way from the prosecutor's.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went up to Charing-cross - a man came with two iron weights in his hand, he asked if I was in work, I said No, and he said he would get me two or three days work - he went into the house and came out with another man; they went to a gin-shop, and then he came and gave me this.

GUILTY . Aged 36. -
Confined Two Months .

2201.
JOHN BECKET
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of September , 1 pair of shoes, value 4s., and 1 pair of boots, value 2s. , the goods of
William Edward East
.

WILLIAM EDWARD EAST
. I live in Barossa-place, Chelsea
, and am a shoe-maker . On the 1st of September I missed a pair of shoes from my shop, which I afterwards saw at
Elizabeth Smith
's shop; I went with the officer, and took the prisoner at his lodgings - he worked for me at the line they were taken.

ELIZABETH HENER SMITH
. I live in Leader-street, Chelsea; I sell bonnets and shoes - I have lived there seven years. I bought these shoes of the prisoner on Friday, the 31st of August; I had bought shoes of him before - he said he had made them himself, and they were old standards I might have got 3s. for them if I had sold them -I bought a pair of little boots of him three or four weeks before.
Prisoner. She never bought these of me; I had sold her a pair about three weeks before.

FRANCES SMITH
. I live with Mrs. Smith's. I was present when the prisoner brought these articles and am certain these are what he brought.

HENRY BARNES
(Police-constable T. T 176). I took the prisoner, and he denied knowing Mrs. Smith as where her house was, but he afterwards said he did sold her some shoes, but not these.
Prisoner's Defence. I certainly, did not have theseshoes; they are wrong in saying I did - I never took a pair from the prosecutor.

GUILTY . Aged 67. -
Confined Six Months .

2202.
JAMES BURNS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of September , 1 waistcoat, value 3s , the goods of
Anselom Jewell
.

ANSELOM JEWELL. I live in High-street, Shadwell
, and am a slop-seller . On the 20th of September, 1831, the prisoner came to my house and asked me to cash an advance-note for the ship Trusty; I agreed to do so - he looked out some shirts and other things; I gave him a sovereign, and some silver out of the note - I took the goods he bought on board the Trusty; I then missed a waistcoat - I never saw him again till the 11th of September last, when he had the waistcoat on; I said, "You are a pretty sort of fellow to come and get my things from me; and leave me a cash-note of which I could make no use, as you left the ship directly" - he said he had come home from Antigua, and if I would go with him I should find where they were to be paid; he walked me round the dock twice, but I refused to go any further, and took him into custody - I am quite certain he is the man. I went back to the ship - he had taken these things he bought of me, and was gone; I cut out vthis waistcoat, and know it well - this is the note he gave me.

GEORGE DIX
. I am a Thames Police-constable. I took the prisoner with this waistcoat on.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw this man in the Londondocks; he asked why I did not go in the ship - I said,"What ship?" as I did not know him again, as he had an old frock-coat on; I said, "You are not the man that cashed my note:" he said, "Yes, I am;" I said, "If you are, I will make it up with you" - I did not tell him I came home in a ship from Antigua; I came in the Cato, from Grenada.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined Three Months .

2203.
GEORGE ALLEN
&
WILLIAM ELFORD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August
, 1 hat, value 10s.; 1 pouch, value 2d.; 1 half-sovereign, 2 sixpences, and 4 pence, the property of
William Dalton
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

2204.
MARY REYNOLDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , 3 yards of printed cotton, value 3s. , the goods of
John Brown
.

JOHN COLLINS
. On the afternoon of the 11th of September I was in Pickett-street
, holding a horse for a gentleman; I saw the prisoner and another woman at Mr. Brown's shop window - I think the prisoner called her Ann-Crawley; they looked in at the window, found that nobody perceived them, and the other woman put her hand over the rail and untwisted a piece of cotton some persons came by and she could not succeed, and then the prisoner tried - the other woman then took it, and gave it to the prisoner, who did it under her shawl, and walked towards Fleet-street; I went after the prisoner, and sent a person to tell Mr. Brown.

GEORGE WHIPONS
. I am shopman to John Brown of Picket-street, a linen draper . I saw the print safe on the afternoon of the 11th of September; it was twisted round the legs of some wooden steps - in consequence of some information I missed it; I went out and followed a woman, was who pointed out to me - I came up with the prisoner near Temple-bar; she was carrying the print under her arm - I believe she was drunk.

JAMES ADAMS
(Police-constable F 62). I took the prisoner - I went to the address she gave to a person I know very well, but she was not at home.

Prisoner's Defence. I had not concealed it - I had it in my hand; my husband is ill in St. Giles' with the cholera, and I have buried two children with it - the woman said she bought it, and told me to pawn it for 2s.
GUILTY. Aged 40.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

2250.
THOMAS JEPSOM
and
GEORGE BARRETT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of May , 107 lbs. of segars, value 100l. , the goods of
Henry Broughton Parry
.
MR. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

HENRY BROUGHTON PARRY
. I am proprietor of a tobacconist-shop on the north side of the Piazza, Covent-garden
; I had one or two hundred pounds worth of cigars. On the night of the 29th of May I secured my premises myself; I had a shop, but no dwelling-house there - I left the premises secure about three o'clock in the morning of the 30th - and the same morning my servant came to my dwelling-house, in Villiers-street, and informed me of the robbery; I went to the premises, found the place had been broken open, and the property stated was gone - I saw it again at Bow-street the same day; I have every reason to believe the cigars are mine - they were contained in two sacks, and an apron belonging to my shopman.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Three in the morning is rather a late hour? A. Yes, rather later than usual; these cigars have been kept by the Excise since the Magistrate delivered them up - I am certain they were not removed at three o'clock in the morning for fear of the Excise; I was detained there by two gentlemen from the Piazza-hotel, sitting smoaking there, and it would not do for me to turn them out - I am an Englishman; I have adopted the name of Henriquez, which is over my window, owing to my connexion with the Havannah and Spanish America - I have given receipts in that name.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you go before the Magistrate after Barrett was in custody? A. Yes, with my witnesses; he was allowed to go by giving sureties.

WILLIAM READ
. I am a porter in Covent-garden market. On the morning of the 30th of May, between three and four o'clock; I was near the Piazza-coffee-house - I saw Jepsom and another man; they were dodging in and out from the Piazza to the market - I should know the other man again; I observed them till between six and seven o'clock - they were in the road fronting Mr. Parry's shop, thirty or forty yards from it; the prisoner Barrett drew up a coach about six o'clock - it was then broad day; I knew him before he drew up in front of Mr. Parry's (from twelve to fourteen feet off, only the width of the pavement) - I then saw Jepsom and the other person go up to Mr.Parry's; they had been a few yards nearer to James-street - some gentlemen came to the door of the Bedford-coffee-house, and stood there about three minutes, and Jepsom and the other man moved towards James-street again, but directly the gentlemen went away, they went to the shop door and went in - they were in about ten minutes, and then came out with two bags and a white parcel; Jepsom carried one bag - they walked quick, and put them into the coach; Barrett was sitting on the steps of the coach, with his face to the shop-door - he did not help any of the parcels into the coach; I went off towards the station and met the officer - I do not know which way the coach went- I told the officer what I had seen, and he went the way the coach did - I went with him; he stopped Barrett with the coach ten or twelve yards from the place, where it had stood - we found these bags and this parcel in it; I had seen Barrett at the coach-stand at the corner of Charles-street - I knew Jepsom; I had passed him fifty times a day in the market.

COURT. Q. Did you observe what Jepsom and the other man did at the shop door? A. No; they went to it, and it opened at the instant - I had known Barrett before, but I do not know that I had seen him on a coach - I had known Jepsom by sight for twelve months.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. And saw him fifty times a day? A. Yes, but I cannot tell what day it was; I have a constant place - I have before been in shops, and at various places; I never was in business: I do not know
Henry Palmer
; I swear I never heard of the name: I was here once for taking some goods of my master's, and was sent to the House of Correction for twelve months; I worked at the tread-mill.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Where had you seen Barrett? A. Attending his duty as a waterman, at the corner of Charles-street, and when he was discharged, he came again there.

WILLIAM MORGAN
. I vam street-keeper of Covent-garden market. On the morning of the 30th of May I saw Read, about seven o'clock - from what he said I went to the Piazza, near the prosecutor's shop; I saw Barrett driving the hackney-coach; I stopped it, and found these two bags of segars, and five bundles tied in an apron - I took them to the station, and gave information to the prosecutor; I found the shop closed; we could not get in- I believe it was fastened with a latch; I knew both the prisoners, and had seen them about the coach-stand, among the hackney-coachmen and cads, but I do not know that I ever saw Barrett drive a coach before.

COURT. Q. Have you seen the prisoners in company? A. I do not recollect that I have - Barrett was driving a coach, No. 154, belonging to Mr. Bird, of Rathbone-place - I took it to the Green-yard, but I believe it has been restored.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Were you perfectly sober? A. I was; I have known Barrett six years; he drove a hackney-coach five years ago, and since then he has been a sort of cad - I have seen him about I cannot tell how lately before. I took him; when I took him, he said he had been engaged by two gentlemen in James-street, to drive round to the Plazzs, and to stop at the Piazza coffee-house - he said he was driving Shirley's coach for him while he got his supper; I believe he said her Shirtley-deshed him to drive one fare, and then return; he did not say that Shirley had then sent him with another fare, nor that he drove a fare to Islington; Mr. Bird and his man (who I believe is Shirley) attended at the office, but I do not think he was examined - I put the coach and horses into the green-yard - I have heard a deposit was left, and they were given up - I attend the market as a street-keeper; I did not apprehend Barrett at all - I indicted him, and a true bill was found, I believe, on the last day of last Session.
MR. BARRY. Q. Did you go of your own accord before the Grand Jury? A. No Sir.

EVERHARD MOSHARD
. I was shopman to Mr. Parry in May last; I know the prisoner Jepsom - I had seen him at our shop before the segars were stolen; he had bought segars several times, and he came on the 29th of May and bought some - he did not ask me any questions that night, but a friend of his did, who came in with him some time before, but he was not in the shop at that time.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you ever see Jepsom, and the persons you call his friends, in company? A. Not in our shop; he had just gone out when they came in - I have seen them at Mr. Smart's public-house, in Drury-lane; I lived five months with Mr. Parry; his is not a divan, but persons smoke there sometimes - we shut up at twelve or one o'clock, or sometimes later; I left about one o'clock on the night of the 29th of May - there was no one there smoking then.

COURT. Q. Why you give information to your master as soon as you came and found what had happened? A. Yes; I told my master that Jepsom had been the night before, and that another person had before made some inquiries in the shop.

WILLIAM ADAMSON
. I am an inspector of Police. I took Jepsom in Scotland-yard, near the archway - Read was with me; I took him in consequence of what he said; I found on him a brief for Barrett's defence - it was last Wednesday morning, about twelve o'clock; Barrett was in custody at the time.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you find any property on him? A. Yes, this watch and some notes, which Mr. Minshull desired me to keep, as they relate to another charge.
The brief found upon the prisoner Jepsom being read, contained instructions for the defence of Barrett.

WILLIAM BABBAGE
. I am an Excise-officer. I took possession of the segars, and produce them here.
MR. PARRY. I can identify these segars, and this apron is my man's.
Witness for the Defence.

CHARLES BLOODWORTH
. I live at No. 11, Vauxhallwalk, and am an earthenware and stone-manufacturer. I have lived there forty-eight years, and been in business twenty-five - it is within a quarter of a mile of Vauxhall-gardens; I have a daughter named Susan - she became of age on the 29th of May, and we went to Windsor; Mrs. Wood, myself, and my two daughter in a chaise - Mr. Wood and the prisoner Jepsom in a gig - we left Vauxhall-road about six or seven o'clock in the morning, and we got home again about two in the morning of the 30th - we stopped at Windsor till late, and then went to Hampton, where I have several friends; we took tea there, and did not leave till eleven at night, and in consequence of that we were so late in town; the whole party came to myhouse, and stopped there an hour - Mr. and Mrs. Wood are tenants of mine, and live next door; they and Jepsom left my house together about a quarter or twenty minutes after three - Jepsom was asked to stay, but he refused, as he lived in town.

COURT. Q. Is that daughter here? A. No, she is in Staffordshire; my youngest daughter is at home - Mr. Wood is here, but I believe not Mrs. Wood: she is ill - I saw her at my house this morning: I do not know where Jepsom lived in town - he came with Wood that morning; my daughter was Christened at Lambeth church - I have not brought the register of her haptisin: we got to Windsor about eleven o'clock - we dined there, but I cannot say at what inn: we left about eight o'clock in the evening; I think we dined about two - we got to Hampton at halfpast nine or ten; the ladies had tea, and Jepsom, Wood, and I had two or three glasses of brandy and water - I have the bill now in my pocket; I know Hampton - I went to take a son of mine to the Bell there some time before, but that night we went to the Lion, kept by Mr. Lawrence - I got this bill on the day I paid it; I had it accidentally in my pocket to-day - I believe it is not usual to have bills marked "Paid" at public-houses.

MR. BARRY. Q. What had you drank in the day? -A. We took our own provisons, and half a dozen of wine and two bottles of brandy; we had four glasses of brandy and water at Hampton - we had not finished our own brandy; we brought one bottle home, and I think three bottles of wine; I have only known Jepsom since Wood took my house at Lady-day last - I have seen him come backwards and forwards; I understood he bought and sold, but I do not know what - I do not know his character or his circumstances; Mr. Wood asked him to go with us that day, I did not - I do not know that my house was searched last night; the officer was there, just to ask where Mrs. Wood lived - I did not know another person named Wood; Mr. Wood's house was searched last night - I am quite sure it was past three o'clock before Jepsom left my house on the 30th of May; it was past two before we got home - we were sober enough to know what we were about, to take the horses out, and put them up - we went to bed as soon as Mr. and Mrs. Wood went home: I was told I should be wanted to give evidence soon after Jepsom was taken; Wood told me of it; I will swear I have not got this bill since Jepsom was taken.
MR. PHILLIPS . Q. It was not your house was searched last night ? A. No, Wood's ; no charge was ever made against me .

NICHOLAS WOOD
. I have been brought here by habeas; I was taken on a charge not yet investigated - I am a commercial traveller , and am a tenant of Mr. Bloodworth; my wife is not here . On the 29th of May I went with Mr . Bloodworth , his daughter , my wife , and Jepsom , the prisoner, to Windsor - it was a holiday , on account of Miss
Susan Bloodworth
being of age; I invited Jepsom to go; on our way home , we stopped at Hampton ; I think we got there between seven and eight o'clock, and to Mr. Bloodworth's between eleven and twelve ; we stopped at his house, I think , till about two o'clock - the females had some tea , and we had some grog and some segars at the Red Lion, at Hampton ; Mr. Bloodworth called for the bill, and he had it - Jepsom , my wife , and myself , left Mr. Bloodworth's house together , and Jepsom slept at my house ; we made him up a bed, and I saw him go to his bed-room - I locked my door that night , which I always do ; I called Jepsom up the next morning , and we breakfasted between nine and ten o'clock - I left him there, when I went out between eleven and twelve.
Jepsom's Defence. I am innocent - Morgan is the foundation of it all , and has got Read to swear against me.

JEPSOM -
GUILTY . Aged 25.

BARRETT -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .
